Patient 2 presented at age 13 years with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with excess blasts and a somatic NRAS mutation (G12D; {164790.0007}) at 37% allelic frequency. She also had facial dysmorphism and mildly restricted pulmonary function. After undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplant, she developed significant complications with graft-versus-host disease, necrotizing pneumonitis, recurrent infections, and pulmonary fibrosis. She died of multiorgan failure 11 months post-transplant. The unaffected father and sister of P2 also carried a RPA1 mutation, suggesting incomplete disease penetrance. Patient 3 had early hair graying and onset of progressive pulmonary fibrosis at age 58 years. Two sisters of P3 were also diagnosed with pulmonary fibrosis and died of the disease; no DNA was available. P4 was a 3-year-old girl who presented at birth with prematurity, failure to thrive, lymphopenia, and hypogammaglobulinemia. At age 3, she was stable on IgG replacement therapy. Telomere length, assessed by different methods, was decreased in the blood cells of all patients.
disease_name+syn: ['Pulmonary fibrosis and/or bone marrow failure syndrome, telomere-related, 6', 'RPA1', ' PFBMFT6']

disease_name: Ichthyotic keratoderma, spasticity, hypomyelination, and dysmorphic facies
disease_des/def: Ichthyotic keratoderma, spasticity, hypomyelination, and dysmorphic features (IKSHD) is characterized by epidermal hyperproliferation and increased keratinization, resulting in ichthyosis; hypomyelination of central white matter, causing spastic paraplegia and central nystagmus; and optic atrophy, resulting in reduction of peripheral vision and visual acuity ({2:Mueller et al., 2019}). In addition, patients exhibit mild facial dysmorphism ({1:Kutkowska-Kazmierczak et al., 2018}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Kutkowska-Kazmierczak et al. (2018)} reported 2 unrelated Polish boys, aged 13 years (patient 1) and 4 years (patient 2), who both exhibited progressive skin dryness with hyperkeratosis and lower extremity spasticity. Other features included rotary nystagmus and sensorineural deafness, as well as mild facial dysmorphism, with wide eyebrows, long nose with bulbous tip, long philtrum, full lips, and relatively large ears. Intellectual development was normal. Brain MRIs showed globally impaired myelination, supra- and infratentorially; MRI at age 13 years in patient 1 showed slight atrophic progression involving the cerebral hemispheres and corpus callosum. The older boy was wheelchair-dependent, but the younger could walk with orthoses. The authors designated the disease to be a syndrome of 'ichthyotic keratoderma, spasticity, mild hypomyelination, and dysmorphic features (IKSHD).'

Independently, {2:Mueller et al. (2019)} studied the same 2 Polish boys reported by {1:Kutkowska-Kazmierczak et al. (2018)}, ages 15 (patient 1) and 5 years (patient 2), who had dry, scaly, and thickened skin over the entire body, particularly over extensor joints, with hyper- and hypopigmented areas. Parents in both families mentioned an intermittent 'strange' body odor. The older patient also had thickened fingernails that split into horizontal layers; palms, soles, scalp, and mucous membranes were spared. Biopsy of affected skin from patient 1 showed ichthyosis, with thickening of the stratum corneum and spinosum, and electron microscopy revealed numerous lysosomes filled with lipopigment. Both patients also had progressive high frequency hearing deficit with onset in the first decade of life, and both exhibited horizontal nystagmus. Patient 1 had marked photophobia, progressive difficulty with night vision, and visual field constriction. Spectral domain-optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) showed thinning of the peripapillary retinal nerve fiber layer in both patients; electroretinographic responses were normal. Both patients were wheelchair-dependent and had dysarthric speech. Neurologic examination of patient 1 at age 14 years revealed hyperreflexia, upgoing plantar reflexes, contractures of large joints, and equinovarus foot deformity. His arms were less severely affected, but showed some some contractures and muscle atrophy, although he was an elite wheelchair athlete. Patient 1 also reported intermittent stool incontinence and incomplete bladder voiding, and urodynamic investigation showed neurogenic bladder with detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia. Cranial MRIs showed nonprogressive hypomyelination in the posterior limb of the internal capsule and in the optic radiation in both patients, and somatosensory and acoustic evoked potentials were consistent with a brainstem and central conduction defect.

{3:Takahashi et al. (2022)} reported 2 sibs, born of consanguineous Turkish parents, with IKSHD transmitted in an autosomal recessive pattern. The patients, who were 9 and 5 years old, had delayed motor development with progressive tremor, spasticity of the lower limbs, involuntary movements, and pyramidal signs resulting in the inability to walk. Other features included cerebellar dysarthria, horizontal nystagmus, and ataxic tremor of the extremities. Motor and sensory nerve conduction studies were normal. Both patients also had sensorineural hearing loss at high frequencies and ichthyotic and hyperkeratotic skin lesions. Dysmorphic features included wide forehead, downslanting palpebral fissures, tubular nose with anteverted nares, low-set ears, long philtrum, and thin upper lip. Brain imaging showed cerebral and cerebellar hypomyelination; cognitive development was normal.
disease_name+syn: ['Ichthyotic keratoderma, spasticity, hypomyelination, and dysmorphic facies', 'ELOVL1', ' SSC1', ' IKSHD']

disease_des/def:
Asthma-related traits include clinical symptoms of asthma, such as coughing, wheezing, and dyspnea; bronchial hyperresponsiveness (BHR) as assessed by methacholine challenge test; serum IgE levels; atopy; and atopic dermatitis ({3:Laitinen et al., 2001}; {2:Illig and Wjst, 2002}; {7:Pillai et al., 2006}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of asthma, see {600807}.
disease_name+syn: ['Asthma, susceptibility to, 1', 'PTGDR', ' AS1', ' ASRT1']

disease_des/def: White-Kernohan syndrome (WHIKERS) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by global developmental delay with variably impaired intellectual development, hypotonia, and characteristic facial features. Some patients may have abnormalities of other systems, including genitourinary and skeletal (summary by {1:White et al., 2021}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:White et al. (2021)} reported 8 unrelated patients, ranging in age from 1 to 17 years, with a similar neurodevelopmental disorder. The patients were ascertained through the GeneMatcher program after undergoing exome sequencing; the phenotypes were assessed as a cohort. All patients had global developmental delay with mildly delayed walking by 2 to 3 years of age, speech and language delay, and variably impaired intellectual development. About half had neonatal complications, such as poor feeding, hypoglycemia, and hypotonia. Some patients were able to understand or speak more than one language and attend special education schools. One patient had an IQ of 69, and another patient had hearing loss. Other variable features included nystagmus, joint laxity, and distal anomalies of the hands and feet, such as brachydactyly, clinodactyly, proximally placed thumbs, and cutaneous syndactyly of the toes. Three of the older patients were obese. All patients had some characteristic facial features, including full cheeks, maxillary hypoplasia, retrognathia, epicanthal folds, telecanthus, deep-set eyes, lateral extension of palpebral fissures, abnormally long or short palpebral fissures, short nose with hypoplastic alae nasi, depressed nasal bridge, large and fleshy low-set ears, strabismus, horizontal straight eyebrows with synophrys, hirsutism, thin and tented upper lip, and short neck. Four patients had genitourinary or gastrointestinal defects, including horseshoe kidney, vesicoureteral reflux, hydronephrosis, bicornuate uterus, anterior anus, rectovaginal fistula, and gastroesophageal reflux. Brain imaging, performed in 5 patients, showed nonspecific abnormalities, including enlarged ventricles, thin corpus callosum, and delayed myelination.
disease_name+syn: ['White-Kernohan syndrome', 'DDB1', ' WHIKERS']

disease_des/def:
Familial partial lipodystrophy type 8 (FPLD8) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by abnormal distribution of subcutaneous adipose tissue. Affected individuals showed selective loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue from the limbs, resulting in a muscular appearance, beginning around 13 to 15 years of age. There is also abnormal accumulation of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the dorsal neck and face, as well as in the posterior thoracic and abdominal regions. The disorder is associated with metabolic abnormalities, including diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia ({1:Garg et al., 2016}).

For a general description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of familial partial lipodystrophy (FPLD), see {151660}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Garg et al. (2016)} reported an African American family (FPLD 122) in which a 62-year-old woman and 2 of her sons, 46 and 39 years of age, had onset of atypical partial lipodystrophy around 13 to 15 years of age. They had marked loss of subcutaneous fat and increased muscularity of the upper and lower extremities and excessive fat accumulation in the dorsocervical region, requiring surgical removal of fat in this region in 2 of the patients. Some had accumulation of adipose tissue in the lower face. As adults, all developed diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia with increased triglycerides. The 46-year-old proband also had acanthosis nigricans, hepatomegaly, elevated creatine kinase, and increased uric acid. Full-body MRI of the brothers showed loss of subcutaneous fat from the scalp, orbits, and anterior truncal region, but preservation of posterior subcutaneous, perirenal, and intraperitoneal fat. Total body fat was reduced in all.
disease_name+syn: ['Lipodystrophy, familial partial, type 8', 'ADRA2A', ' ADRA2R', ' FPLD8']

disease_name: Intellectual developmental disorder, autosomal recessive 80, with variant lissencephaly
disease_des/def: Autosomal recessive intellectual developmental disorder-80 with variant lissencephaly (MRT80) is characterized by global developmental delay with mildly to moderately impaired intellectual development and behavioral abnormalities. Speech delay and motor abnormalities, such as hypotonia, may also be present. Brain imaging shows lissencephaly with pachygyria and mild cortical thickening in the frontotemporal lobes ({1:Uctepe et al., 2024}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Uctepe et al. (2024)} reported 7 patients from 5 unrelated families with a similar neurodevelopmental disorder associated with cortical brain malformations. The patients, who ranged in age from 6 to 26 years, were ascertained through the GeneMatcher Program after exome sequencing identified biallelic mutations in the CASP2 gene. Four of the families were consanguineous (of Turkish or Iranian descent). The patients had global developmental delay with mildly to moderately impaired intellectual development, sometimes with speech delay. Most had behavioral abnormalities, including autistic features, ADHD, aggression, and intolerance to frustration. Brain imaging performed in 3 patients showed lissencephaly with bilateral pachygyria and mild cortical thickening in the frontotemporal lobes. One patient had prominent subcortical perivascular spaces and another had hydrocephaly. More variable features included seizures (1 patient), hypotonia, weakness, spasticity (1 patient), abnormal and uncoordinated gait (1 patient), and optic atrophy (1 patient). One patient was noted to have dysmorphic facial features, including synophrys, upslanting palpebral fissures, prominent nasal tip, thin upper lip, and low-set, posteriorly rotated ears.
disease_name+syn: ['Intellectual developmental disorder, autosomal recessive 80, with variant lissencephaly', 'CASP2', ' NEDD2', ' ICH1', ' MRT80']

disease_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with impaired language, behavioral abnormalities, and dysmorphic facies
disease_des/def: Neurodevelopmental disorder with impaired language, behavioral abnormalities, and dysmorphic facies (NEDLBF) is characterized by global developmental delay, speech delay, variably impaired intellectual development, behavioral abnormalities, and dysmorphic facial features. The phenotype and severity of the disorder is heterogeneous, ranging from borderline to severe. Brain imaging is usually normal. More variable additional features include early feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, short stature, mild visual impairment, hypotonia, seizures (particularly febrile), and distal skeletal defects of the hands and feet ({1:Jia et al., 2022}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Jia et al. (2022)} reported 12 unrelated individuals with variable neurodevelopmental concerns associated with de novo heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the UBAP2L gene identified through exome sequencing. The patients, who ranged from 4 to 16 years of age, were ascertained through international collaborative efforts, including the GeneMatcher program. All patients were referred for neurodevelopmental concerns, including delayed development, speech delay, variably impaired intellectual development, motor delay, hypotonia, and various behavioral abnormalities. Some had early feeding difficulties with failure to thrive or short stature. Intellectual disability ranged from borderline to severe, and all had some type of speech/language problem. Behavioral abnormalities included autism spectrum disorder, autistic features, ADHD, repetitive behavior, anxiety, and aggression. Seven patients had seizures, often febrile, but only 3 had a formal diagnosis of epilepsy. A few had visual impairment with ocular anomalies such as esotropia, exotropia, myopia, hypermetropia, and astigmatism. Brain imaging was essentially normal in the patients studied. Most individuals had variable dysmorphic facial features, including round face, flat face, long face, high broad forehead, microretrognathia, deep-set eyes, abnormal palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, strabismus, deep and prominent concha, synophrys, broad nasal bridge, bulbous nose, long philtrum, low-set posteriorly rotated ears, and thin upper lip. Some patients had skeletal anomalies, including scoliosis/kyphosis, joint stiffness, brachydactyly, fifth finger clinodactyly, nail hypoplasia, broad halluces, flat feet, and finger joint contractures.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodevelopmental disorder with impaired language, behavioral abnormalities, and dysmorphic facies', 'UBAP2L', ' NICE4', ' NEDLBF']

disease_des/def: Autosomal dominant intellectual developmental disorder-74 (MRD74) is characterized by global developmental delay, including delay of gross and fine motor skills and speech delay, and variable subtle dysmorphic facial features ({1:Niggl et al., 2023}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Niggl et al. (2023)} reported 13 unrelated patients, ranging from 17 months to 15 years of age, with global developmental delay and variably impaired intellectual development who were ascertained through the GeneMatcher program after exome sequencing identified de novo heterozygous variants in the HNRNPC gene. Five individuals (Ind1-Ind5) carried a recurrent de novo heterozygous 9-residue in-frame deletion in the HNRNPC gene ({164020.0001}). These 5 patients had mildly impaired intellectual development (IQ range from 54 to 72 in 2 patients), variable speech delay with articulation problems, and delayed gross and fine motor skill acquisition. Some had early feeding issues and poor overall growth with small head circumference; Ind3 had microcephaly (-3.54 SD). Other features included hypotonia (in 3), hypertonia (in 1), motor tics (in 2), hyposensitivity to pain (in 2), and sleep difficulties (in 4). Most patients had a happy demeanor, often with poor attention span. All had variable subtle dysmorphic features, including brachycephaly, deep-set eyes, hypo- or hypertelorism, prominent nose, smooth philtrum, and thin upper lip. None had seizures or significant brain imaging abnormalities. Another 7 individuals had heterozygous frameshift (4 patients) or missense (3 patients) variants in the HNRNPC gene, and 1 patient (Ind10) had a larger deletion that included the HNRNPC gene and extended into adjacent genes. Overall, these individuals had similar features as Ind1-Ind5, including mild to severely impaired intellectual development with poor or absent speech, hypotonia, delayed walking or inability to walk, poor fine motor skills, and sleep issues. Three patients had seizures. Some had feeding problems, including 3 patients who required a feeding tube. Most also had dysmorphic facial features, including asymmetric head, round face, broad forehead, broad nasal bridge, deep-set eyes, downslanting palpebral fissures, smooth philtrum, hypertelorism, micro- or retrognathia, and thin upper lip.
disease_name+syn: ['Intellectual developmental disorder, autosomal dominant 74', 'HNRNPC', ' HNRPC', ' MRD74']

disease_des/def:
Retinitis pigmentosa-92 (RP92) is characterized by relatively mild disease, with onset of night blindness and vision loss in the third to sixth decades of life. Patients show abnormal pigmentation of the retina and have reduced scotopic responses on electroretinography ({1:Zhang et al., 2018}).

For a general phenotypic description and discussion of genetic heterogeneity of RP, see {268000}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Zhang et al. (2018)} reported 2 unrelated Chinese men with retinitis pigmentosa and mutation in the HKDC1 gene. The first proband was a 71-year-old man who developed night blindness at age 54 years, after which he experienced vision loss and had only hand-motion visual acuity by age 65. Fundus examination showed pigment deposits in the retina, and he had severely reduced rod responses on full-field electroretinography (ffERG). The second proband was a 39-year-old man who noted night blindness at age 29 years. He had a 2-year history of reduced vision, with visual acuities of 20/40 and 20/50 in the right and left eyes, respectively. Fundus examination showed irregular pigmentation patterns, mainly in the posterior pole and along the arcade vessels bilaterally. Visual field testing showed peripheral vision defects in both eyes. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) revealed discontinuous ellipsoid and interdigitation zones in both eyes, as well as a disrupted retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) layer. On ffERG, severely reduced rod responses and oscillatory potentials were observed bilaterally, with a mild reduction in combined and cone responses.
disease_name+syn: ['Retinitis pigmentosa 92', 'HKDC1', ' RP92']

disease_des/def: Autosomal dominant deafness-79 (DFNA79) is a nonsyndromic form of progressive sensorineural hearing loss with age of onset ranging from 20 years to 65 years. Affected females appear to have milder hearing loss than males ({1:Lu et al., 2020}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Lu et al. (2020)} studied a large 5-generation Chinese family (family 60) in which 19 members had nonsyndromic progressive bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Age at onset ranged from age 20 years to 65 years. Audiograms showed a variable pattern: 5 affected individuals had descending hearing curves, whereas 3 had steep drop-type hearing curves, with normal hearing at low- and mid-range frequencies, and moderate to profound hearing loss at high frequencies, with a steep drop at 4 kHz or 8 kHz. In addition, 2 female patients experienced mild hearing loss that was significantly less severe than in male patients of the same age or younger. Analyzing the relationship between age and audiogram findings, the authors observed that patients with steep drop-type hearing curves were younger than those with descending hearing curves, indicating that high-frequency hearing was damaged first, with subsequent gradual progression of hearing loss over all frequencies. In addition, many family members reported that they could not hear others clearly even at a young age or had mild hearing loss as evaluated by pure tone audiometry test, consistent with central auditory processing disorder. None of the affected individuals had vestibular symptoms, and there were no other abnormalities in these patients.
disease_name+syn: ['Deafness, autosomal dominant 79', 'SCD5', ' ACOD4', ' DFNA79']

disease_des/def: The pathogenesis of HIV infection and the progression from infection to AIDS vary significantly between exposed individuals. Infection occurs after the virus, which has macrophage (M)- and T lymphocyte (T)-tropic strains and more than 12 subtypes, survives an array of nonspecific, nongenetic environmental and host factors.
disease_name+syn: ['AIDS, delayed/rapid progression to', 'KIR3DL1', ' NKAT3', ' NKB1', ' AMB11', ' KIR3DS1']

disease_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with language impairment and behavioral abnormalities
disease_des/def: Neurodevelopmental disorder with speech impairment and behavioral abnormalities (NEDLIB) is characterized by impaired intellectual development or developmental delay, behavioral abnormalities including autistic features, and language impairment. Other features include seizures and developmental regression ({1:Salpietro et al., 2019}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Salpietro et al. (2019)} reported 25 unrelated patients, ranging from 3 months to 31 years of age, with a neurodevelopmental disorder. The patients were ascertained through collaboration of several research centers who shared data from whole-exome, whole-genome, or targeted sequencing that identified GRIA2 mutations. The phenotype represented a spectrum of neurologic deficits, including global developmental delay, impaired intellectual development with poor or absent speech, and behavioral abnormalities, such as autism spectrum disorder, repetitive behaviors, stereotypic movements including hand-flapping, obsessive-compulsive traits, and hyperactivity. Some patients had normal early development, but then showed regression with impaired social and language skills. About half of patients developed early-onset focal or tonic-clonic seizures, most of which were refractory to treatment. Several patients had head growth deceleration, 4 patients were unable to walk, several had gait abnormalities, incoordination, ataxia, or dystonia, and about half were nonverbal. Brain imaging tended to be normal, although some patients had nonspecific abnormalities, such as cerebral atrophy, cerebellar atrophy, and white matter changes. Two patients died in infancy.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodevelopmental disorder with language impairment and behavioral abnormalities', 'GRIA2', ' GLUR2', ' NEDLIB']
['Fasting plasma glucose level QTL 5', 'GCKR', ' GKRP', ' FGQTL5']

disease_des/def:
Schizophrenia is a psychosis, a disorder of thought and sense of self. Although it affects emotions, it is distinguished from mood disorders in which such disturbances are primary. Similarly, there may be mild impairment of cognitive function, and it is distinguished from the dementias in which disturbed cognitive function is considered primary. There is no characteristic pathology, such as neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer disease ({104300}). Schizophrenia is a common disorder with a lifetime prevalence of approximately 1%. It is highly heritable but the genetics are complex. This may not be a single entity.

Schizophrenia and bipolar disorder (see {125480}) are generally considered to be separate entities, but patients who exhibit multiple symptoms of both disorders are often given the hybrid diagnosis schizoaffective disorder ({13:Blacker and Tsuang, 1992}).

<Subhead> Genetic Heterogeneity of Schizophrenia with or without an Affective Disorder

SCZD4 ({600850}) is associated with variation in the PRODH gene ({606810}); SCZD9 ({604906}) with variation in the DISC1 gene ({605210}); SCZD15 ({613950}) with variation in the SHANK3 gene ({606230}); SCZD16 ({613959}) with a chromosome duplication involving the VIPR2 gene ({601970}); SCZD17 (see {614332}) with variation in the NRXN1 gene ({600565}); SCZD18 ({615232}) with variation in the SLC1A1 gene ({133550}); and SCZD19 ({617629}) with variation in the RBM12 gene ({607179}).

For associations pending confirmation, see MAPPING and MOLECULAR GENETICS.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
Schizophrenia is characterized by a constellation of symptoms including hallucinations and delusions (psychotic symptoms) and symptoms such as severely inappropriate emotional responses, disordered thinking and concentration, erratic behavior, as well as social and occupational deterioration. It often develops in young adults who were previously normal ({2:Andreasen, 1995}).

In his first description of dementia praecox, Kraepelin identified subtypes of schizophrenia: hebephrenic, catatonic, and paranoid ({43:Diefendorf, 1902}). The utility and validity of these subtypes was long a subject of debate. {94:Kendler et al. (1994)} sought to clarify differences in outcome and familial psychopathology among these 3 subtypes in the Roscommon Family Study of severe mental illness conducted in a rural county in western Ireland. They found that the subtypes did not 'breed true' within families. They concluded that from a familial perspective the subtypes are not etiologically distinct syndromes.

{93:Kendler and Hays (1982)} compared a group of 30 patients with familial schizophrenia (defined as having an affected first-degree relative) and a group of 83 cases of sporadic schizophrenia. No difference in the intensity of (1) flattened, depressed, or elevated affect, (2) auditory hallucinations, or (3) delusions was found; however, more of the familial (56.7%) than of the sporadic (18.1%) schizophrenic patients had severe thought disorders. EEGs performed while the patients were taking neuroleptics showed abnormality in 72.3% of sporadic cases and 43.3% of familial cases.

Extrapyramidal signs such as bradykinesia, rigidity, or dyskinesias in patients with schizophrenia are usually attributed to antipsychotic drugs, many of which are dopamine-receptor antagonists. {26:Chatterjee et al. (1995)} prospectively studied 89 patients presenting with a first episode of schizophrenia who had never taken neuroleptic medications. Using the Simpson Dyskinesia Rating Scale, they found 16.9% (15) of these individuals to have significant extrapyramidal dysfunction on presentation. Twelve of the patients had akinesia, 6 had rigidity, 1 had cogwheeling, and 1 had mild spontaneous dyskinesia. These observations gave support to earlier proposals that the basal ganglia may be involved in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.

{102:Kunugi et al. (1994)} found no significant difference in head circumference at birth between 64 infants who later developed schizophrenia and 45 of their healthy sibs. {136:Nopoulos et al. (1995)} demonstrated decreased volume of the frontal lobe and increased volume of the intersulcal CSF in 12 males and 12 females presenting with a first episode of schizophrenia, compared to 24 controls matched for age, height, weight, parental social class, and paternal and maternal education.

Eye movement disturbances have been found in about 40 to 80% of patients with schizophrenia, about 25 to 40% of their healthy first-degree relatives, and in less than 10% of healthy control subjects ({78:Holzman, 2000}).

Schizophrenia and bipolar disorder ({125480}) are generally considered to be separate entities, but patients who exhibit multiple symptoms of both disorders are often given the hybrid diagnosis schizoaffective disorder ({13:Blacker and Tsuang, 1992}). The clinical features of such patients supported the argument that schizophrenia and bipolar disorder are variant expressions of a diathesis, in part because of the similar disease frequencies, ages at onset, and absence of sex bias in the 2 disorders.

{70:Hallmayer et al. (2005)} pointed out that {100:Kraepelin (1909)} viewed the disorder he termed dementia praecox as a cognitive disorder. Coining the term schizophrenia to replace dementia praecox, {15:Bleuler (1920)} emphasized that it 'is not a disease in the strict sense, but appears to be a group of diseases...Therefore we should speak of schizophrenias in the plural.' {70:Hallmayer et al. (2005)} stated that the inherent heterogeneity originally recognized has been obfuscated in modern diagnostic classifications, which are designed to meet the needs of patient management, not fundamental research, and which may not target phenotypes anchored in the biology of the illness. Limited understanding of phenotypic heterogeneity is a common challenge in genetic studies of complex disorders.
disease_name+syn: ['Schizophrenia', 'DISC2']

disease_des/def: The ABO system, discovered in 1900 by {8:Landsteiner (1900)}, is one of the most important blood group systems in transfusion medicine. The ABO system consists of A and B antigens and antibodies against these antigens. There are 4 major groups in the ABO system (A, B, AB, and O) that result from 3 major alleles (A, B, and O) of the ABO gene ({110300}). Additional ABO subgroups are produced by dozens of ABO subgroup alleles. The A and B antigens are carbohydrate rather than protein antigens and are synthesized by a series of reactions catalyzed by glycosyltransferases. The final step in their biosynthesis is catalyzed by the A and B glycosyltransferases, which are encoded by the A and B alleles of the ABO gene, respectively. Individuals with blood group O do not produce functional A or B glycosyltransferases and therefore lack A and B antigens. Unlike many other blood group systems, the presence of naturally occurring antibodies against A and B antigens in individuals who do not express those antigens causes an adverse and potentially fatal outcome at the first mismatched transfusion. Because the A and B antigens exist in cells other than red blood cells, ABO matching is also important in cell, tissue, and organ transplantation, and ABO blood groups are important in forensic science (review by {19:Yamamoto, 2004}).
disease_name+syn: ['Blood group, ABO system', 'ABO']

disease_name: Calvarial doughnut lesions with bone fragility with or without spondylometaphyseal dysplasia
disease_des/def: Calvarial doughnut lesions with bone fragility (CDL) is characterized by low bone mineral density, multiple spinal and peripheral fractures beginning in childhood, and sclerotic doughnut-shaped lesions in the cranial bones. Some more severely affected individuals exhibit neonatal onset of fractures, severe short stature, marked cranial sclerosis, and spondylometaphyseal dysplasia (CDLSMD) ({6:Pekkinen et al., 2019}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Bartlett and Kishore (1976)} described multiple hyperostotic or osteosclerotic lesions of the calvaria in a man and 3 of his sons, each by a different mother. One of the affected sons also experienced recurrent facial nerve palsy. Two other sons and a daughter were presumed unaffected. The authors mistakenly interpreted the genetics as 'incompletely dominant sex-linked.'

{2:Baumgartner et al. (2001)} reported the sporadic case of a 16-year-old boy with this rare autosomal disorder. They emphasized that many pathologic fractures, lumps on the head, elevated serum alkaline phosphatase levels, and dental caries are the main characteristics of the disorder. Their patient had had 10 pathologic fractures between age 6 weeks and 15 years. An elevated serum alkaline phosphatase was found at age 11 and skull lumps at age 15. Radiography showed frontal and parietal round radiolucencies surrounded by sclerotic bone resembling doughnuts. Because the findings were reminiscent of osteogenesis imperfecta (see {166200}), collagen types I, III, and V were analyzed in fibroblasts and shown to be normal. They found that MRI of the skull could detect skull lesions at an early stage, even before palpable lesions appeared.

Patients reported by {3:Colavita et al. (1984)} and {5:Nishimura et al. (1996)} had clinical features suggestive of CDL or gnathodiaphyseal dysplasia (GDD; {166260}).

{4:Jaakkola et al. (2009)} studied a Finnish family in which a 13-year-old girl, her father, and paternal grandmother had vertebral and peripheral fractures as well as multiple doughnut lesions, hyperostosis, or sclerosis in the skull. The proband sustained low-energy fractures of the right radius and humerus at age 6 and 11 years. Lumbar spine BMD Z-score was -1.9 at age 11, and x-rays showed a compression fracture at T12 and sclerotic lesions in the skull. Plasma alkaline phosphatase was elevated, consistent with increased bone turnover. Transiliac bone biopsy revealed thin and structurally abnormal cortical bone and thin trabeculae, and osteoclast activity was increased. Her father sustained multiple fractures beginning at age 4 years, involving the skull, clavicle, radius, ulna, metacarpal and carpal bones, tibia, and fibula. He also experienced peripheral facial nerve palsies, and transient episodes of oculomotor and trochlear nerve paresis beginning in the fifth decade of life. MRI and CT showed no narrowing of the bony cranial nerve canals. Skull x-rays revealed CDL. The proband's 85-year-old paternal grandmother had severe osteoporosis and had sustained at least 14 nonvertebral fractures as well as multiple vertebral compression fractures. Skull x-rays showed irregular diffuse thickening but no clear doughnut lesions. She also experienced transient peripheral facial nerve beginning in the sixth decade of life, and abducens nerve palsies at age 82 years. The proband was diagnosed with glaucoma at age 3 years and had secondary uveitis and cataracts, and the grandmother was diagnosed with chronic congestive glaucoma at age 58, but the father had normal intraocular pressures. The authors concluded that CDL with osteoporosis segregated in this family with dominant inheritance and high penetrance, although they noted that the severity of the condition varied between family members.

{6:Pekkinen et al. (2019)} described 10 patients from 4 unrelated families with CDL (families 1 to 4), including the Finnish family reported by {4:Jaakkola et al. (2009)}, who exhibited low bone mineral density combined with multiple childhood-onset peripheral and/or vertebral fractures, often but not always associated with the mild cranial sclerotic lesions characteristic of CDL. Several patients experienced recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy or other neurologic manifestations. {6:Pekkinen et al. (2019)} reviewed transiliac bone biopsies from 2 unrelated Finnish patients (families 1 and 2), which showed reduced mineral content, increased heterogeneity in matrix mineralization, and a highly increased proportion of low-mineralized bone compared to controls. Polarized light microscopy showed bone matrix predominantly formed by haphazard arrangement of collagen fibrils.

<Subhead> Clinical Variability

{6:Pekkinen et al. (2019)} studied a 43-year-old Dutch mother and her 7-year-old son (family 5), as well as an 11-year-old boy of Hispanic ancestry (family 6), who had multiple spinal and long-bone fractures of neonatal onset, severe short stature, and metaphyseal changes associated with marked platyspondyly and scoliosis on x-ray, consistent with spondylometaphyseal dysplasia. In addition, these patients showed a more severe degree of cranial sclerosis than others with CDL. All 3 had episodes of facial paresis, and the Dutch woman experienced other neurologic symptoms, including diplopia, sensory neuropathy, ataxia, absent patellar and Achilles reflexes, and decreased arm reflexes. The Dutch woman and the Hispanic boy also had mixed hearing loss. The authors reviewed a femoral bone biopsy from the Dutch boy, in which polarized light microscopy showed bone matrix predominantly formed by haphazard arrangement of collagen fibrils.
disease_name+syn: ['Calvarial doughnut lesions with bone fragility with or without spondylometaphyseal dysplasia', 'SGMS2', ' SMS2', ' CDL']

disease_des/def:
Attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is the most common childhood-onset behavioral disorder, affecting approximately 5 to 10% of children and adolescents ({41:Wolraich et al., 1996}). In this condition, persistent inattention and/or hyperactive-impulsive behavior results in impaired social and/or academic functioning. Boys are affected about 8 times more frequently than girls ({44:Zametkin et al., 1990}).

<Subhead> Genetic Heterogeneity of Attention Deficit-Hyperactivity Disorder

Susceptibility to ADHD7 ({607478}) may be conferred by variation in the TPH2 gene ({607478}) on chromosome 12q21. ADHD8 ({619957}) is caused by mutation in the CDH2 gene ({114020}) on chromosome 18q12.

Several loci for susceptibility to ADHD have been mapped, including ADHD1 ({608903}) on chromosome 16p13, ADHD2 ({608904}) on chromosome 17p11, ADHD3 ({608905}) on chromosome 6q12, ADHD4 ({608906}) on chromosome 5p13, ADHD5 ({612311}) on 2q21.1, and ADHD6 ({612312}) on 13q12.11. Also see MOLECULAR GENETICS.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
By means of positron-emission tomography (PET) of the brain using (18F)-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose, {44:Zametkin et al. (1990)} found that global cerebral glucose metabolism was 8.1% lower in adults with hyperactivity than in normal controls. Glucose metabolism was significantly reduced in 30 of 60 specific regions of the brain. Among the regions with greatest reduction were the premotor cortex and the superior prefrontal cortex. This study was done in adults because of ethical considerations about exposing children to a radioactive tracer; however, each of the 25 hyperactive adults was the biologic parent of a hyperactive child. {7:Biederman et al. (1990)} reported that 28.6% of the biologic parents of hyperactive children also had a history of hyperactivity. The parents in this study continued to have symptoms as adults.

{35:Smalley (1997)} reviewed studies of the genetics of ADHD and autism ({209850}). {43:Zametkin and Ernst (1999)} reviewed the diagnostic criteria, differential diagnosis, and treatment of ADHD.

{20:Kuntsi et al. (2004)} found that 86% of the association between ADHD symptom scores and IQ, and 100% of the association between ADHD diagnosis and IQ was accounted for by genetic influences that are shared by ADHD and IQ. In a large population-based sample of 5-year-old twins (both monozygotic and dizygotic), they assessed twins individually on IQ tests, and data on ADHD symptoms were obtained from mothers' and teachers' ratings. The correlation between ADHD symptoms and IQ was -0.3 (on average ADHD diagnosed children obtained an IQ score 9 points lower than comparison children).
disease_name+syn: ['Attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, susceptibility to', 'DRD5', ' DRD1B', ' DRD1L2']

disease_des/def:
Retinitis pigmentosa-89 (RP89) is characterized by classic features of RP as well as features of ciliopathy, including postaxial polydactyly and renal and hepatic disease. Onset of symptoms is within the first decade of life ({1:Cogne et al., 2020}).

For a general phenotypic description and discussion of genetic heterogeneity of RP, see {268000}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Cogne et al. (2020)} studied a 5-year-old boy (family A) with retinal degeneration consistent with retinitis pigmentosa (RP), who also exhibited features suggestive of ciliopathy. He was born with postaxial hexadactyly of both hands and the right foot, and at 12 months of age, he showed failure to thrive and hepatosplenomegaly. Ultrasound at 18 months showed a dysmorphic liver with dilatation of intrahepatic biliary ducts; liver biopsy revealed micronodular cirrhosis with modification of global hepatic architecture by annular fibrosis and persistence of peripheral biliary neoductules. By 24 months of age, he had developed esophageal varices and thrombocytopenia. Cardiac ultrasound showed a bicuspid aortic valve. At age 4 years, the parents reported that the proband had difficulties moving about at night. Funduscopy was unremarkable, but fundus autofluorescence showed a modification of the peripheral autofluorescence and hyperautofluorescent perimacular points. Electroretinograms showed alteration of the flicker and the scotopic responses. Upon reexamination at age 5 years, funduscopy showed retinal thinning with an increase in the visibility of the choroidal vascularization on the retinal periphery and on the temporal macula. The authors also studied a 6-generation Ashkenazi Jewish family (family B) segregating autosomal dominant RP, with more than 19 affected members. Affected individuals exhibited classic features of RP, with an average age of onset in the first decade of life. Postaxial polydactyly was present in 2 affected family members, and 1 had kidney dysfunction.
disease_name+syn: ['Retinitis pigmentosa 89', 'KIF3B', ' KIAA0359', ' RP89']

disease_name: Inflammatory poikiloderma with hair abnormalities and acral keratoses
disease_des/def: Inflammatory poikiloderma with hair abnormalities and acral keratoses (IPHAK) is characterized by mottled hyper- and hypopigmentation of the skin as well as sparse scalp hair and eyelashes, sparse or absent eyebrows, and palmoplantar keratoses ({1:Han et al., 2022}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Han et al. (2022)} reported 3 Pakistani sisters (family 1, patients 1, 2, and 3) and an unrelated Indian woman (family 2, patient 4) with poikiloderma, hair abnormalities, and acral keratoses, and mutation in the LTV1 gene. In family 1, all 3 sisters exhibited mottled hyper- and hypopigmentation that was particularly marked on the limbs but was also prominent over the lower trunk, flanks, and forehead. Eyebrows were absent and eyelashes were sparse; scalp hair was normal in patient 2, but in patient 3 was thin in patches and was generally sparse in patient 1. Patient 1 was initially examined at age 2 years, at which time she exhibited marked livedoid erythema of the limbs in a reticulate pattern. Skin biopsy from the thigh of patient 1 at age 3 years showed mild lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate in the papillary dermis with melanophage accumulation and pigmentary incontinence. At ages 21, 26, and 30 years, the pigmentary changes had faded, but the sisters avoided sun exposure, which caused erythema within 2 hours; acral scaling and punctate keratoses persisted. In family 2, patient 4 developed skin changes at 6 months of age that began acrally and progressed proximally. By age 6 years, she had mottled hyper- and hypopigmentation of the face, buttocks, and limbs, including palmar and plantar surfaces, as well as reticulate scaly erythema on the limbs. Hair, eyebrows, and eyelashes were sparse. Skin biopsy from the ankle region of patient 4 at age 4 years showed hyperkeratosis, focal parakeratosis, mild superficial dermal chronic inflammatory infiltrate extending focally into the epidermal basal layer; the papillary dermis showed scattered melanophages and focal vascular dilation. At 18 years of age, she had mottled hyper- and hypopigmentation and acral keratoderma with the same appearance and distribution as the affected sisters in family 1. The authors designated the condition as 'poikiloderma with hair abnormalities and acral keratoses,' but noted that the phenotype might be more accurately described as 'reticulate poikilodermatous dyschromatosis.'
disease_name+syn: ['Inflammatory poikiloderma with hair abnormalities and acral keratoses', 'LTV1', ' IPHAK']

disease_des/def: Folate-responsive megaloblastic anemia (MEGAF) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder characterized by megaloblastic anemia resulting from decreased folate transport into erythrocytes. Although serum levels of folate are normal, there is folate deficiency in tissues, including erythrocytes and possibly nerve cells. Serum homocysteine levels are increased and vitamin B12 levels may be decreased. Treatment with oral folate corrects the anemia and normalizes homocysteine (summary by {2:Svaton et al., 2020})
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {2:Svaton et al. (2020)} reported a 15-year-old boy with an unremarkable medical history who presented with severe anemia, mild hemolysis, hyperhomocysteinemia, and low vitamin B12. Serum folate levels were normal, but erythrocyte folate levels were decreased. He reported poor eating habits. The anemia responded well to treatment with cyanocobalamin and folate, but he returned at age 17 with a second similar episode of anemia associated with hemolysis and increased bilirubin. At this time he had onset of lower limb weakness associated with decreased conduction velocities on electrophysiologic testing, consistent with a peripheral neuropathy and demyelination. Bone marrow aspirate and peripheral blood smear showed megaloblastic erythroid precursors, schistocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils. The findings were consistent with impaired maturation and ineffective hematopoiesis. Folate levels were decreased in patient erythrocytes, although serum levels were normal. The hematologic abnormalities were corrected by adding oral folic acid. The authors postulated that inadequate folate intake combined with increased demand for folates in adolescent males may have contributed to the episodes of anemia in their patient. He was also noted to have EMG findings consistent with peripheral demyelination, compatible with tissue-specific folate deficiency.
disease_name+syn: ['Megaloblastic anemia, folate-responsive', 'SLC19A1', ' FOLT', ' MEGAF', ' IMD114']

disease_des/def:
The sense of bitter taste is mediated by a group of bitter taste receptor proteins that reside on the surface of taste cells within the taste buds of the tongue. These proteins are 7-transmembrane domain, G protein-coupled receptors that are encoded by the TAS2R gene family (see TAS2R10; {604791}), which contains at least 25 functional genes ({22:Kim et al., 2005}).

Humans worldwide display a bimodality in sensitivity to the bitter taste of PTC, with approximately 75% of individuals perceiving it as intensely bitter, whereas the rest perceive it as tasteless. This difference has been the basis of study of taste perception in humans for over 70 years. {21:Kim and Drayna (2004)} provided an historical review of the subject.

Propylthiouracil (PROP) and PTC are members of a class of compounds known as thioureas. The compounds carry the chemical group N-C=S, which is responsible for their characteristic bitter taste ({3:Bartoshuk et al., 1994}; {10:Drewnowski and Rock, 1995}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
Variation in the ability to taste PTC was discovered by {12:Fox (1931)}. Supplementation of the standard test using quinine in the intermediate cases was suggested by {16:Kalmus (1958)}. There has been a suggestion that PTC tasting in man is related to a component of saliva: {5:Cohen and Ogdon (1949)} claimed that PTC tasters can taste PTC only if it is dissolved in their own saliva. If the tongue is dried and then presented with PTC dissolved in someone else's saliva, it is tasteless. {15:Jones and McLachlan (1991)} described a technique for fitting mixture distributions to data on PTC sensitivity.

It has long been proposed that there is a relationship between athyreotic hypothyroidism ({218700}; formerly called athyreotic cretinism) and PTC nontasting (e.g., {32:Shepard, 1961}). Both PTC and PROP are structurally similar to the naturally occurring antithyroid substance l-goitrin; all members of this class of chemicals have antithyroidal activity and are not tasted by PTC nontasters ({32:Shepard, 1961}). Nearly all individuals with athyreotic hypothyroidism are nontasters.

{35:Tepper (1998)} reviewed the literature for the ability to taste PTC and PROP and the implications for food preference and dietary habits. {35:Tepper (1998)} discussed the classic explanation for the persistence of the PROP polymorphism, i.e., a selective advantage for avoidance of harmful compounds in the environment that are often bitter tasting ({10:Drewnowski and Rock, 1995}). This taste aversion may have special relevance for the avoidance of certain bitter-tasting vegetables. PROP and PTC are chemically related to the isothiocyanates and goitrin, bitter-tasting compounds that are present in cruciferous vegetables such as cabbage, broccoli, brussels sprouts, turnips, and kale. When eaten in large quantities, these compounds interfere with iodine metabolism, producing thyroid enlargement and goiterlike symptoms. {35:Tepper (1998)} noted that the incidence of thyroid deficiency disease is relatively rare among PTC tasters. In modern society, however, avoidance of bitter-tasting foods may have health disadvantages, since epidemiologic studies indicate that diets low in fruits and vegetables and high in fat may be associated with increased risk of heart disease and cancer.

{23:Kinnamon (2000)} reviewed the role of taste receptors in taste transduction.
disease_name+syn: ['Phenylthiocarbamide tasting', 'TAS2R38', ' T2R61', ' PTC', ' THIOT']

disease_des/def: Rheumatoid arthritis is an inflammatory disease, primarily of the joints, with autoimmune features and a complex genetic component.
disease_name+syn: ['Rheumatoid arthritis, progression of', 'IL10', ' CSIF', ' GVHDS']

disease_name: Intellectual developmental disorder, X-linked syndromic, Pilorge type
disease_des/def: The Pilorge type of X-linked syndromic intellectual developmental disorder (MRXSP) is characterized by global developmental delay with variably impaired intellectual development, speech delay, and behavioral abnormalities, including autism spectrum disorder (ASD). More variable features include motor incoordination, seizures, and ocular abnormalities (summary by {1:Marcogliese et al., 2022}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{2:Pilorge et al. (2016)} reported 2 unrelated male patients with autism spectrum disorder and other neurologic deficits associated with hemizygous mutations in the GLRA2 gene. Patient 1 had language delay, low-average IQ of 82, and some motor coordination difficulties. He had no dysmorphic features or seizures. As a young adult, he lived with his parents and worked in a sheltered environment. Patient 2 had severe language delay, mild intellectual disability (IQ of 63), and onset of generalized tonic-clonic seizures starting at 18 years of age. He lived by himself in a sheltered home environment and could care for personal needs. Patient 2 had a sister, who did not carry the GLRA2 mutation, with autism, more severe intellectual disability, and an episode of psychosis.

{3:Piton et al. (2011)} reported a girl with autism, loss of acquired words, seizures, mild motor developmental delay, macrocephaly, and hypothyroidism associated with a heterozygous variant in the GLRA2 gene. The variant was inherited from her unaffected mother.

Using online matchmaking software, including GeneMatcher, {1:Marcogliese et al. (2022)} identified 13 patients with variable developmental delay who had mutations in the GLRA2 gene. The authors had identified the GLRA2 gene through studies in Drosophila as having a role in behavior, which they postulated could extend to humans. Eight females (patients 1-8) all had de novo heterozygous mutations, and 5 males (patients 9-13) had hemizygous mutations. The 8 females, who ranged from 6 months to 6.7 years of age, had developmental delay with intellectual disability. Some had hypotonia or incoordination. One was diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder, 1 had psychosis, 4 had inattention/hyperactivity, and 3 had sleep disturbances. Four had early-onset seizures with EEG abnormalities and 1 had EEG abnormalities suggestive of epilepsy. Patient 2 had early-onset epileptic encephalopathy between ages 6 months and 2 years when the seizures remitted, patient 4 had infantile spasms and seizures and died at age 7 months secondary to complications of COVID-19, patient 6 had infantile spasms with hypsarrhythmia on EEG, consistent with a diagnosis of West syndrome, and patient 7 had infantile spasms that evolved to atonic and tonic-clonic seizures. The severity of neurologic impairment was variable: some patients (patients 1 and 8) were able to attend school, although they had learning difficulties. Other patients had severe speech delay or absent speech, poor concentration, and ataxic gait. Four had microcephaly and 1 had borderline microcephaly. Ocular features included nystagmus, myopia, astigmatism, exotropia, strabismus, and oculomotor apraxia. Brain imaging was normal in 4 patients and showed variable nonspecific abnormalities in the others, including cortical atrophy, delayed myelination, thin corpus callosum, and white matter abnormalities. Some had nonspecific dysmorphic facial features. All the females carried de novo heterozygous missense mutations in the GLRA2 gene.

The 5 males reported by {1:Marcogliese et al. (2022)} ranged from 11 months to 35 years of age and had developmental delay with mildly delayed walking, motor difficulties such as hypotonia and incoordination, variable intellectual disability, and speech delay. Three patients had ASD and 1 was suspected to have autism; the fifth patient, at 11 months old, was too young for evaluation. Some patients had inattention, hyperactivity, impulsivity, agitated behavior, or anxiety. A few patients were able to attend school with special aids and therapies. The 35-year-old had cognitive and social difficulties, but no seizures, and was able to complete high school. Three patients had various types of seizures, including generalized tonic-clonic, absence, and myoclonic. One patient showed developmental regression after seizure onset at age 2.5 years. Ocular abnormalities, including myopia, strabismus, astigmatism, and reduced visual acuity were also observed. Three patients were noted to have variable dysmorphic features, including long face, high anterior hairline, epicanthal folds, downslanting palpebral fissures, broad eyebrows, long eyelashes, bulbous nose, and broad nasal tip. Brain imaging, performed in 4 patients, was normal in 2 patients and showed T2-weighted signal abnormalities in the other 2 patients. Four patients inherited a hemizygous GLRA2 mutation from an unaffected mother, whereas 1 (patient 12) inherited the mutation from a mildly affected mother who had skewed X inactivation (60:40). The unaffected mother of patient 9 also had skewed X inactivation (82%).
disease_name+syn: ['Intellectual developmental disorder, X-linked syndromic, Pilorge type', 'GLRA2', ' MRXSP']

disease_des/def:
Familial partial lipodystrophy type 9 (FPLD9) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder characterized by the loss of adipose tissue resulting in a lean appearance with muscular hypertrophy, usually most apparent in the limbs and trunk. Some patients have more generalized lipoatrophy, whereas others have abnormal fat accumulation in the face and neck regions and show cushingoid or acromegalic facial features. The disorder is associated with insulin-resistant diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, low HDL, and hepatic steatosis. Symptom onset is usually in the first decade. Females tend to have hirsutism and polycystic ovary syndrome, whereas males have gynecomastia. Most patients also have neurologic involvement, including demyelinating polyneuropathy (in most) and delayed development with intellectual disability (in about half) ({1:Schuermans et al., 2023}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of familial partial lipodystrophy (FPLD), see {151660}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Schuermans et al. (2023)} reported 7 patients from 4 unrelated consanguineous families (family 1 of Turkish descent and families 2 to 4 of Algerian descent) with lipodystrophy and neurologic abnormalities. The patients, who ranged from 11 to 42 years of age, developed variable symptoms of the disorder between 1 and 19 years. Features included lipodystrophy, muscle hypertrophy, lean body habitus, insulin-resistant diabetes mellitus, hypertriglyceridemia/dyslipidemia, low HDL, and hepatic steatosis, often with hepatomegaly. The pattern of lipodystrophy was variable: most patients had lipoatrophy of the limbs with muscular hypertrophy, and many had accumulation of adipose tissue in the face, neck, and submental region, resulting in a cushingoid appearance. Subcutaneous veins were prominent in some. At least 1 patient (P5) had a more generalized pattern of lipodystrophy. Additional more variable features included acanthosis nigricans, generalized musculoskeletal pain, hypertension, subclinical hypothyroidism, precocious puberty, kyphoscoliosis, lordosis, Achilles tendon contractures, foot deformities, and short stature (which may have been familial in some). Most of the females had hirsutism, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovary syndrome, and the males showed gynecomastia. Some patients had dysmorphic facies, including prominent nose and chin, low-set ears, prominent forehead, prognathism, short neck, and acromegaloid features. Most patients also had neurologic abnormalities, including demyelinating polyneuropathy (5 patients), areflexia (5 patients), developmental delay (3 patients), abnormal or spastic gait (3 patients), and migraine (1 patient).
disease_name+syn: ['Lipodystrophy, familial partial, type 9', 'PLAAT3', ' PLA2G16', ' HRASLS3', ' HRSL3', ' HREV107', ' FPLD9']

disease_des/def: Eosinophil peroxidase deficiency is a rare abnormality of eosinophil granulocytes characterized by decreased or absent peroxidase activity and decreased volume of the granule matrix (summary by {10:Romano et al., 1994}). {4:Nakagawa et al. (2001)} noted that there are no clinical symptoms and the diagnosis is made solely by cytochemical analysis.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
In Yemenite Jews in Israel, {7:Presentey (1969)} and {6:Presentey and Szapiro (1969)} described a 'new' anomaly of eosinophils characterized by nuclear hypersegmentation, hypogranulation, and negative peroxidase and phospholipid staining.

{3:Lepelley et al. (1987)} described the Presentey anomaly in twin sisters; one had refractory anemia, which may have been coincidental and merely the symptom that brought the twins to attention.

In contrast to myeloperoxidase deficiency ({254600}), in which all neutrophils and monocytes are affected, isolated deficiency of eosinophil peroxidase is very rare ({8,9:Presentey, 1970, 1984}; {5:Presentey and Joshua, 1982}; {11:Schaeffer et al., 1977}).

{1:Hoffmann and Tielens (1987)} reported the case of an affected 4-year-old boy of Turkish ancestry whose parents were 'consanguineous in the second degree.' {1:Hoffmann and Tielens (1987)} commented on the fact that the use of automated flow-cytochemical analyzers in the hematology laboratory had stimulated interest in peroxidase activity of granulocytes and brought many cases of hereditary and acquired deficiency to attention. It was in this way that their case was detected. {12:Valdes and Calero (1987)} described a patient with deficiency of eosinophil peroxidase detected by flow cytochemistry.

Electron microscopic analyses of peroxidase-deficient eosinophils showed an increase in the ratio between the size of the matrix and the core of the specific granules ({3:Lepelley et al., 1987}; {2:Lejeune et al., 1988}). {13:Zabucchi et al. (1992)} found 5 eosinophil peroxidase-deficient subjects among 131,000 peripheral blood samples examined by routine automated methods. All met the main criteria: absent or strongly decreased reaction for peroxidase, absent or strongly decreased staining with Sudan Black, and an increased ratio of the granule core volume to the total granule volume. {13:Zabucchi et al. (1992)} demonstrated that the increased core-matrix ratio was caused mainly by a decrease of the volume of the matrix and that 2 other matrix proteins, eosinophil cationic protein ({131398}) and eosinophil-derived neurotoxin ({131410}), appeared to be present in normal amounts.

{4:Nakagawa et al. (2001)} reported a 62-year-old man who was found to have EPO deficiency during routine peripheral blood testing for investigation of colon polyps; he had no history of recurrent infection or allergy.
disease_name+syn: ['Eosinophil peroxidase deficiency', 'EPX', ' EPXD']

disease_des/def: Immune dysregulation, autoimmunity, and autoinflammation (IDAA) is an immunologic disorder characterized by anemia and thrombocytopenia associated with circulating autoantibodies, positive Coombs test, and increased levels of proinflammatory cytokines due to constitutive activation of immune-related signaling pathways ({1:Tao et al., 2023}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Tao et al. (2023)} reported a 10-year-old girl with a history of chronic thrombocytopenia since 7.5 years of age and anemia since age 3 years. Features included recurrent skin ecchymosis, epistaxis, and gingival bleeding. Physical examination showed cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy. She did not have recurrent infections, fever, arthritis, hepatosplenomegaly, systemic involvement, or other abnormal findings. Laboratory work-up showed severe thrombocytopenia, anemia, and increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate; C-reactive protein ({123260}) was normal. Mildly decreased levels of complement C3 ({120700}) and C4 (see {120810}) were also noted. She had significant levels of circulating autoantibodies, including positive anti-nuclear antibodies, anti-SSA, anti-nucleosome, and anti-platelet glycoprotein IIb ({607759})/IIIa ({173470}) antibodies, as well as a positive Coombs test. Bone marrow biopsy was hypercellular, but showed impaired platelet production. Treatment with transfusions and immunosuppressive agents resulted in clinical improvement and a stable course with only mild and persistent anemia.
disease_name+syn: ['Immune dysregulation, autoimmunity, and autoinflammation', 'PLCG1', ' PLC1', ' IDAA']

disease_des/def:
Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis-6 (PFIC6) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by elevated liver transaminases, cholestasis, and congenital diarrhea ({1:Gao et al., 2020}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of PFIC, see PFIC1 ({211600}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Gao et al. (2020)} reported a boy, born of consanguineous Pakistani parents, with a history of chronic malabsorptive diarrhea, easy bruising, episodes of prolonged bleeding that required blood transfusions, and failure to thrive. Laboratory testing at age 2.5 years showed elevated liver transaminases and alkaline phosphatase. Liver biopsy demonstrated portal and periportal fibrosis and hepatocytes with foci of hepatocytic cholestasis. Analysis of bile acids in a blood spot were normal. The patient was started on ursodiol and cholestyramine at 5 years of age. The coagulopathy resolved and his growth was adequate, but his liver transaminases, direct bilirubin, and GGT levels remained elevated.
disease_name+syn: ['Cholestasis, progressive familial intrahepatic, 6', 'SLC51A', ' OSTA', ' PFIC6']
['Leprosy, protection against', 'TLR1', ' TIL. LPRS5']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:De Ligt et al. (2012)} reported a boy with severe intellectual disability with myopia, strabismus, short stature, flat face with narrow forehead, long palpebral fissures, arched eyebrows, sacral dimple, short hands, brachydactyly, and short feet. He walked at age 5 years and started to speak at age 4 years. He also had behavioral abnormalities, including self-mutilation. Laboratory studies suggested mitochondrial dysfunction without mitochondrial gene defects. {2:Proietti Onori et al. (2018)} provided follow-up of the patient reported by {1:de Ligt et al. (2012)}. At age 16.5 years, he had severely impaired intellectual development (IQ less than 35) and very poor speech. He did not have seizures; juvenile-onset glaucoma was noted. Brain imaging showed no structural abnormalities.

{2:Proietti Onori et al. (2018)} reported a 5-year-old boy who presented in infancy with generalized hypotonia and developmental delay with impaired speech and language, as well as autism. He had mild dysmorphic features, including relative macrocephaly, prominent capillary vascular malformations on the forehead and glabella, tall forehead, tubular nose with upturned tip, large ears, round cheeks, and facial hypotonia. He did not have seizures, and brain imaging was normal. The authors noted that both this patient and the patient previously reported by {1:de Ligt et al. (2012)} had some facial dysmorphisms, though not strikingly similar.
disease_name+syn: ['Intellectual developmental disorder, autosomal dominant 59', 'CAMK2G', ' CAMKG', ' MRD59']
['Diabetes mellitus, insulin-dependent, 22', 'CCR5', ' CMKBR5', ' CCCKR5', ' IDDM22']

disease_name: Aerodigestive tract cancer, squamous cell, alcohol-related, protection against
disease_name+syn: ['Aerodigestive tract cancer, squamous cell, alcohol-related, protection against', 'ADH1B', ' ADH2']

disease_des/def: Autoinflammatory-pancytopenia syndrome (AIPCS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by severe anemia and thrombocytopenia apparent from early infancy, hepatosplenomegaly, and recurrent fevers associated with a hyperinflammatory state. Additional systemic features may include chronic diarrhea, proteinuria with renal disease, liver fibrosis with elevated liver enzymes, deforming arthropathy, and vasculitic skin lesions. Some patients may have motor delay or learning difficulties associated with subcortical white matter lesions on brain imaging. Laboratory studies show increased levels of proinflammatory cytokines and increased expression of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs), consistent with a type I interferonopathy ({5:Rodero et al., 2017}). Treatment with a JAK (see {147795}) inhibitor (baricitinib) may be effective ({1:Hong et al., 2020}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{5:Rodero et al. (2017)} reported 3 children from 2 unrelated families who presented at birth with severe anemia and thrombocytopenia requiring transfusions. Family 1 was consanguineous and of Algerian ancestry (patients 1 and 2), whereas family 2 (patient 3) was European Italian with no known consanguinity. The patients were from a cohort of patients with increased expression of ISGs. The infants also had hepatosplenomegaly and cholestatic hepatitis that resolved in the first few weeks. All 3 patients experienced recurrent fevers starting between 5 and 7 years, followed by onset of proteinuria between ages 6 and 10 years. Renal biopsy of 1 patient from family 1 and the patient from family 2 showed membranoproliferative glomerulosclerosis; renal immune complex deposition with C1q accumulation was observed in 1 of these patients. These 2 patients also had fibrosis detected on liver biopsy. The older sister in family 1 was clinically asymptomatic at age 10 years, although she still had mild thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, and proteinuria. Her neurologic development was normal. Her younger brother, who was 8 years old, and the other patient, who was 17, had mild learning difficulties in school associated with small subcortical white matter abnormalities on T2-weighted brain imaging. All had increased ESR and fluctuating titers of anti-DNA antibodies.

{1:Hong et al. (2020)} reported a 14-year-old Somali girl, born of consanguineous parents, with a history of neonatal anemia. She presented at 6 years of age with recurrent fevers, a history of pancytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive. She required multiple red cell and platelet transfusions. Intestinal biopsy identified pseudogranulomas with lymphoid tissue showing phagocytosis of DNA fragments. Bone marrow studies showed macrophage infiltration with associated hemophagocytosis. At age 9 years, the patient had a severe EBV infections and met the criteria for HLH (hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis) for which she was treated and partially responded. She continued to have pancytopenia with anemia and lymphopenia, diarrhea, hepatosplenomegaly with elevated liver enzymes, and poor overall growth. She also had motor delay, and brain imaging showed deep white matter abnormalities. Laboratory studies showed increased levels of proinflammatory cytokines in patient sera, fibroblasts, and macrophages, including TNF ({191160}), IFNB ({147640}), IFNG ({147570}), and IL18 ({600953}). These findings indicated induction of a type I interferon signature pattern. Treatment of the patient with a JAK (see {147795}) inhibitor (baricitinib) resulted in sustained clinical improvement and normalization of ISG expression.
disease_name+syn: ['Autoinflammatory-pancytopenia syndrome', 'DNASE2', ' DNL', ' AIPCS']

disease_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and ischiopubic hypoplasia
disease_des/def: Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and ischiopubic hypoplasia (NEDFIH) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by these features and moderate to severe global developmental delay. Affected individuals show episodic regression during periods of stress, including seizures or infection, the latter of which may be associated with lymphopenia. Brain imaging shows diminished white matter volume, enlarged ventricles, and thin corpus callosum ({1:Muffels et al., 2023}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Muffels et al. (2023)} reported 3 unrelated patients ascertained through the GeneMatcher program who had a similar syndromic neurodevelopmental disorder associated with biallelic mutations in the NAE1 gene identified through exome sequencing. The patients, who were 12, 19, and 4 years of age, had moderate to severe developmental delay and mild growth delay with a variable disease course. At 1 year of age, patient 1 was admitted to the ICU for a lower respiratory infection that was followed by a loss of developmental milestones and profound drug-resistant epilepsy. Laboratory studies showed leukopenia, lymphopenia, and decreased Ig levels. At age 12 years, she could not sit without support and was nonverbal. Other features included congenital heart defects and craniofacial dysmorphism. Patient 2 had normal development until 14 months of age when he was admitted to the ICU with pneumonia and thereafter showed developmental regression; he acquired walking at age 2.5 years. Laboratory studies showed mild leukopenia and low Ig levels with lymphocytopenia during infections. Other features included craniofacial dysmorphism and cleft palate. He did not have seizures. At age 19 years, he could sit, walk, and communicate verbally. Patient 3 presented in infancy with plagiocephaly, sleeping difficulties, hyporeflexia, hypotonia, and epileptic spasms associated with developmental regression. He also had dysmorphic facial features. At 2.5 years of age, he could roll, sit with support, vocalize, and recognize his parents. The epilepsy was effectively treated. Common dysmorphic features include broad forehead, downslanting and almond-shaped palpebral fissures, telecanthus, round face with prominent cheeks, broad nasal tip, pointed chin, full lower lip, and asymmetric or cleft palate. All patients had skeletal abnormalities, most notably ischiopubic hypoplasia, decreased bone density, and hyperextensible joints with joint dislocation. Brain imaging in all patients showed diminished white matter volume, enlarged ventricles, and thin corpus callosum.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and ischiopubic hypoplasia', 'NAE1', ' APPBP1', ' NEDFIH']

disease_des/def:
Acromesomelic dysplasia-4 (AMD4) is characterized by disproportionate short stature due to mesomelic shortening of the limbs. Radiographic hallmarks include mild to moderate platyspondyly, moderate brachydactyly, iliac flaring, and metaphyseal alterations of the long bones that progressively increase with age ({1:Diaz-Gonzalez et al., 2022}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of acromesomelic dysplasia, see AMD1 ({602875}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Diaz-Gonzalez et al. (2022)} reported 2 unrelated girls with severe disproportionate short stature and mutation in the PRKG2 gene. Proband 1 was a 12-year-old Moroccan girl without dysmorphic facial features who had mesomelic shortening of the limbs and short stubby fingers. X-rays revealed mild flattening of thoracic vertebral bodies and mild thoracic scoliosis, lumbar hyperlordosis, and short lumbar pedicles. Lower limbs showed mild mesomelic shortening with mild flaring of metaphyses and mild genu valgum, with premature fusion of the growth plate at the knee. There was mild bowing of the radius and ulna with mild mesomelic shortening, as well as short and broad phalanges and metacarpals, all of which showed premature fusion, consistent with advanced bone age. She underwent both femoral and humeral limb lengthening. In addition, she had congenital complete atrioventricular block, and underwent pacemaker insertion at age 1 year. Proband 2 was an 11-year-old Indian girl with disproportionate short stature and dysmorphic features, including triangular face, broad nasal bridge, pointed chin, synophrys and generalized hirsutism, hypertelorism, low-set ears, prominent costochondral cartilages and sternum, wide wrists, short stubby fingers, genu varum, and sandal gap. Skeletal surveys showed moderate platyspondyly with anterior beaking, relatively large and wide epiphyses of the long bones with irregular metaphyses, prominent deltoid tuberosities of the humeri, short and broad phalanges, and metaphyseal irregularities of the metacarpals and metatarsals. Her bone age was normal. The authors designated the phenotype 'acromesomelic dysplasia, PRKG2 type (AMDP).'

{2:Pagnamenta et al. (2022)} reported a 9-year-old Iranian girl (family 2) with AMD and mutation in the PRKG2 gene. Radiographs showed generalized brachydactyly and mild disproportionate shortening of the radius and ulna relative to the humerus, consistent with mesomelic shortening. She also had mildly elongated femoral necks, and mild platyspondyly with small anterior vertebral body projections. She exhibited facial dysmorphisms similar to those previously reported in an Indian girl with AMD by {1:Diaz-Gonzalez et al. (2022)}, including thick eyebrows with synophrys, broad nasal bridge, and prominent chin.
disease_name+syn: ['Acromesomelic dysplasia 4', 'PRKG2', ' PRKGR2', ' AMD4', ' SMDP']

disease_name: Low density lipoprotein cholesterol level QTL6
disease_name+syn: ['Low density lipoprotein cholesterol level QTL6', 'SORT1', ' NT3', ' LDLCQ6']

disease_des/def:
Susceptibility to idiopathic generalized epilepsy-15 (EIG15) is an autosomal dominant seizure disorder characterized by onset of variable types of seizures in the first decade. Absence seizures are the most common manifestation, but most patients also develop other types, including clonic or generalized tonic-clonic seizures. EEG tends to show 3-Hz spike-wave discharges, whereas brain imaging is normal. The majority of patients also have developmental delay associated with impaired intellectual development apparent from infancy or early childhood (summary by {1:Rudolf et al., 2016}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of idiopathic generalized epilepsy, see EIG ({600669}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Rudolf et al. (2016)} reported a 4-generation French family in which 4 individuals (patients 4, 13, 14, and 20) had onset of absence seizures and rare generalized tonic-clonic seizures between 3 and 11 years of age. EEG showed generalized polyspikes followed by typical 3-Hz spike-and-wave absence seizures with loss of consciousness, ocular elevation, eyelid myoclonia, and neck and shoulder myoclonia of limited amplitude, mostly triggered by intermittent photic stimulation (IPS) at eye closure. The epilepsy was controlled by medication. Three patients were noted to have mild intellectual disability (IQ range from 62 to 73). There was evidence of possible incomplete penetrance and/or phenocopies within the family: the RORB variant was also found in patient 10, who had isolated photoparoxysmal response (PPR) during IPS, but whose seizure state could not be confirmed, and in patient 23, who reportedly had 1 absence seizure at age 9 years, but refused EEG investigations. In addition, there were 3 family members (11, 15, and 21) who had isolated PPR during IPS, but they did not carry the variant; these 3 patients did not have seizures.

{1:Rudolf et al. (2016)} subsequently identified 4 unrelated patients with early-onset seizures and impaired intellectual development. Patient AG1 was an 18-year-old woman who developed febrile seizures at age 3 years that progressed to febrile and nonfebrile generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Initially refractory, the seizures eventually were controlled with medication, and she became seizure-free off medication during her teenage years. She had developmental delay since age 15 months, abnormal behaviors such as stereotypies, compulsive behaviors, and aggression, autism spectrum disorder, significant sleep disturbances, and moderate to severe cognitive deficits (IQ of 40). Patient RO1 was a 4-year-old boy who developed clonic seizures at age 4 months, followed by clonic-atonic and atypical absence seizures. The seizures were refractory to medication, and EEG showed background slowing and frequent multifocal spikes. He had developmental delay beginning around 10 months of age, and later showed severe intellectual impairment with a developmental quotient of 50%. The remaining 2 patients had onset of absence and/or generalized seizures between 2 and 4 years of age. A 10-year-old girl (patient GE0705) had refractory seizures, eyelid myoclonia triggered by IPS, and global developmental delay with learning difficulties, speech impairment, and IQ less than 50. She also had strabismus and hypermetropia. A 28-year-old man (patient EC-CAE300) had variable seizure types that were partially responsive to treatment, learning difficulties, dyslexia, and behavioral problems with aggressive features. Brain imaging was normal in all 4 patients.
disease_name+syn: ['Epilepsy, idiopathic generalized, susceptibility to, 15', 'RORB', ' RZRB', ' EIG15']
['Obesity, susceptibility to', 'FFAR4', ' O3FAR1', ' GPR120', ' PGR4', ' BMIQ10']

disease_des/def: The Kondo-Fu type of spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia (SEDKF) is characterized by severely retarded growth and skeletal anomalies, including spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia with associated kyphosis and reduced bone mineral density. Elevated levels of blood lysosomal enzymes have also been observed ({1:Kondo et al., 2018}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Kondo et al. (2018)} studied an 11.5-year-old girl who showed severely retarded growth with skeletal anomalies, including a bone mineral density that was approximately 60% of that of healthy controls. She was small for gestational age at birth, with lengths and weights initially in the 5th centile, and after 6 months of age, growth in weight and height slowed down. At 2 years of age, bilateral cataracts were extracted, and at age 3.5 years, she underwent bilateral inguinal hernia repair. Although gross motor milestones were delayed, speech and cognitive development were normal. She showed limited response to growth hormone (GH1; {139250}) replacement therapy, which was discontinued after 1 year. Evaluation at age 6 years for back pain showed short stature, pectus carinatum, kyphosis, and waddling gait; x-rays revealed spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia.
