After recovery, he had residual fatigue, learning difficulties, and memory and attention deficits. He had 2 asymptomatic sisters with the same homozygous SQOR mutation.
disease_name+syn: ['Sulfide:quinone oxidoreductase deficiency', 'SQOR', ' SQRDL']

disease_des/def: Autosomal recessive deafness-121 (DFNB121) is characterized by congenital or prelingual moderate sensorineural hearing loss ({2:Ramzan et al., 2023}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Greene et al. (2023)} reported 7 patients from 3 unrelated families with deafness and mutation in the GPR156 gene. All affected individuals had congenital nonsyndromic bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

{2:Ramzan et al. (2023)} reported 5 patients from 2 unrelated Turkish families with deafness and mutation in the GPR156 gene. In family 2254, 3 brothers were affected, and in family 2986, 2 sisters were affected. All had nonsyndromic congenital or prelingual-onset moderate sensorineural hearing loss. Temporal bone MRI or CT scans were normal in all, and all exhibited normal vestibular function.
disease_name+syn: ['Deafness, autosomal recessive 121', 'GPR156', ' GABABL', ' DFNB121']

disease_name: Intellectual developmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{2:Gregor et al. (2018)} reported 18 unrelated patients, ranging in age from 1 to 29 years, with a syndromic intellectual developmental disorder associated with de novo heterozygous mutations in the FBXO11 gene. The patients were identified through collaborative efforts of research groups with exome sequencing data from patients with developmental delay. The severity and additional manifestations varied among the patients. All patients had delayed psychomotor development; intellectual disability ranged from mild to moderate in most patients, with only 4 patients being classified as having severe to profound deficits. Similarly, speech was usually delayed, and a few patients were nonverbal. Patients were able to attend either special or mainstream schools with additional support. Most patients had mildly delayed walking by 2 years, although a few did not achieve independent ambulation until age 5 or 6 years. Only 5 patients had seizures, and the severity ranged from epileptic encephalopathy to a single seizure. Additional common features included short stature, strabismus, hypermetropia, hypotonia, sleeping difficulties, and distal mild skeletal anomalies, such as small hands and feet, tapering fingers, clinodactyly, sandal gap, and flat feet. Most patients had a variety of behavioral abnormalities, such as poor social interaction, autistic features, stereotypic movements, hyperactivity, short attention span, and aggressive outbursts. Dysmorphic features were common, but there was not a distinctive gestalt. Some of these features included small head circumference, downslanting palpebral fissures, strabismus, deep-set eyes, hypertelorism, low-set ears, long philtrum, long eyelashes, narrow mouth, everted lower lip, and long face.

{1:Fritzen et al. (2018)} reported 2 unrelated boys with IDDFBA. One patient was a 14-year-old boy with global developmental delay apparent during his first years of life. He started walking at the age of 20 months and spoke his first sentences at age 4. He had hyperactivity, impatience, difficulties in focusing his attention, and a hyperkinetic disorder. Dysmorphic features included small head circumference, upslanting palpebral fissures, small and posteriorly rotated ears, and small hands with short fingers and toes. The other patient was a 3-year-old boy with intrauterine growth retardation, hypotonia, delayed psychomotor development, strabismus, short stature, and restless behavior. He also had plagiocephaly, a high forehead, a high frontal hairline, deep-set eyes, a broad tip of the nose with small alae, long philtrum, tented upper lip vermilion, downturned corners of the mouth, and full lips. He had hypospadias and his toenails were small and deep-set.

{3:Jansen et al. (2019)} reported 24 individuals with borderline to severely impaired intellectual development, 16 of whom also had behavioral problems, including autism spectrum disorder, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, anxiety, and aggression. More than half of the patients had hypotonia and a few had epilepsy. Brain imaging was performed in 17 patients and enlarged ventricles were seen in 6 of them. Three patients had additional brain anomalies, including hypoplasia of the anterior pituitary, bilateral hippocampal malformations and borderline large cerebellum, Chiari 2 malformation, and syringomyelia. Obesity was observed in 7 individuals. The most consistent facial features were a high broad forehead, long palpebral fissures, and a thin upper lip with broad space between the paramedian peaks. Minor hand abnormalities (e.g., brachydactyly or tapering fingers) were seen in half of the patients, and 8 patients had hyperlaxity of the joints. Gastrointestinal problems such as vomiting and feeding difficulties were reported in 11 patients and vision problems were reported in 9 patients.
disease_name+syn: ['Intellectual developmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities', 'FBXO11', ' FBX11', ' VIT1', ' PRMT9', ' IDDFBA']

disease_name: Leukoencephalopathy, motor delay, spasticity, and dysarthria syndrome
disease_des/def: Leukoencephalopathy, motor delay, spasticity, and dysarthria syndrome (LEMSPAD) is characterized by a motor-predominant phenotype including motor developmental delay, speech articulation disorder, progressive spastic hemiplegia with hyperreflexia, and age-appropriate cognition ({1:Mao et al., 2020}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Mao et al. (2020)} reported a 6-year-old girl (patient 1) of Irish/German descent who presented in infancy with delayed development manifest mainly as delayed walking (at 21 months) with an abnormal spastic gait and toe-walking. She also had speech delay and dysarthria with poor articulation. Features included hypertonia, progressive spasticity, hyperreflexia, and bradykinesia; she did not have dystonia or seizures. She reportedly had normal cognition and attended a mainstream school with accommodations, but she had anxiety and attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder. Brain imaging at age 3 years showed nonspecific T2-weighted hyperintensities at the posterior lateral ventricles and periventricular gliosis.
disease_name+syn: ['Leukoencephalopathy, motor delay, spasticity, and dysarthria syndrome', 'EIF2AK1', ' HRI', ' LEMSPAD']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {9:Schuelke et al. (2004)} described a child, offspring of a healthy woman who was a former professional athlete, who developed stimulus-induced myoclonus several hours after birth. He appeared extraordinarily muscular, with protruding muscles in his thighs and upper arms. Muscle hypertrophy was verified by ultrasonography when the infant was 6 days of age. The stimulus-induced myoclonus gradually subsided after 2 months. The child's motor and mental development were normal. At age 4.5 years, he continued to have increased muscle bulk and strength, and he was able to hold two 3-kg dumbbells in horizontal suspension with his arms extended. Several members in 4 generations of the family were exceptionally strong, according to information in their clinical history.
disease_name+syn: ['Muscle hypertrophy', 'MSTN', ' GDF8', ' MSLHP']

disease_des/def:
Asthma-related traits include clinical symptoms of asthma, such as coughing, wheezing, and dyspnea; bronchial hyperresponsiveness (BHR) as assessed by methacholine challenge test; serum IgE levels; atopy; and atopic dermatitis ({3:Laitinen et al., 2001}; {2:Illig and Wjst, 2002}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of asthma, see {600807}.
disease_name+syn: ['Asthma, susceptibility to, 2', 'NPSR1', ' GPR154', ' GPRA', ' VRR1', ' PGR14', ' ASRT2']

disease_des/def: Immunodeficiency-82 with systemic inflammation (IMD82) is a complex autosomal dominant immunologic disorder characterized by recurrent infections with various organisms, as well as noninfectious inflammation manifest as lymphocytic organ infiltration with gastritis, colitis, and lung, liver, CNS, or skin disease. One of the more common features is inflammation of the stomach and bowel. Most patients develop symptoms in infancy or early childhood; the severity is variable. There may be accompanying fever, elevated white blood cell count, decreased B cells, hypogammaglobulinemia, increased C-reactive protein (CRP; {123260}), and a generalized hyperinflammatory state. Immunologic workup shows variable B- and T-cell abnormalities such as skewed subgroups. Patients have a propensity for the development of lymphoma, usually in adulthood. At the molecular level, the disorder results from a gain-of-function mutation that leads to constitutive and enhanced activation of the intracellular inflammatory signaling pathway. Treatment with SYK inhibitors rescued human cell abnormalities and resulted in clinical improvement in mice ({1:Wang et al., 2021}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Wang et al. (2021)} reported 6 patients from 5 unrelated families with a similar immunologic disorder. The first 3 patients, including a girl with sporadic disease and a father and daughter, all presented in the first weeks of life with chronic intestinal inflammation and colitis manifest as diarrhea, fever, rash, and poor overall growth. Other features included arthritis with joint pain and swelling of the hands or ankles and lymphocytic vasculitis (patient 2), all consistent with a systemic hyperinflammatory disorder. They also had recurrent infections, indicating immune deficiency or dysfunction. Patients 5 and 6, who were 34 and 44 years of age, respectively, had histories of systemic inflammation, including intestinal, skin, joint, and lung, lymphadenopathy, as well as recurrent infections associated with hypogammaglobulinemia. Patient 5 had central nervous system inflammation with granulomatous lesions of the spinal cord that responded to high-dose steroids, but recurred approximately annually, and patient 6 developed degenerative arthritis and granulomatous hepatitis. Both patients developed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) as adults. Infections, when documented, included bronchitis, pneumonia, otitis media, skin abscesses, osteomyelitis, salmonellosis, H. pylori, and herpes zoster. Laboratory studies overall showed hypogammaglobulinemia, increased white blood cell counts, and often increased C-reactive protein (CRP; {123260}) levels. T, B, and NK cell levels were normal or decreased in different patients. Some patients had skewing of the B- or T-cell subsets, such as increased memory CD4+ T cells, indicating memory expansion and immune activation.
disease_name+syn: ['Immunodeficiency 82 with systemic inflammation', 'SYK', ' IMD82']
['Leprosy, susceptibility to, 4', 'LTA', ' TNFB']

disease_des/def: Immunodeficiency-106 (IMD106) is an autosomal recessive immunologic disorder characterized by increased susceptibility to viral infections beginning in infancy or early childhood. Some patients present with recurrent respiratory infections or other viral infections. In many cases, the susceptibility to viral infections due to IMD106 only becomes apparent after initial vaccination with live attenuated viral (LAV) vaccines, most notably MMR and yellow fever. A subset of IMD106 patients who demonstrate adverse reactions to MMR or other LAV vaccinations develop a severe acute hyperinflammatory response reminiscent of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) and may show encephalopathy, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and multiorgan failure. However, some patients with IMD106 tolerate MMR vaccination without sequelae. IFNAR1 deficiency may also predispose to severe respiratory infection with SARS-CoV-2 and to herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV1) encephalitis (HSE). The disorder results from an impaired type I interferon signaling response ({2:Bastard et al., 2022}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{5:Hernandez et al. (2019)} reported 2 unrelated children who presented with a hyperinflammatory response soon after vaccination with live attenuated vaccines for MMR and yellow fever, respectively. Neither showed features of immunodeficiency before vaccination. P1 was a 9-year-old boy born of consanguineous Iranian parents who presented at about 12 months of age with disseminated vaccine-strain measles after vaccination with MMR. He had fever, neurologic symptoms consistent with encephalitis, and leukocytosis in the CSF. He had previously received hepatitis B virus, BCG, and influenza vaccines without adverse effect. Antibodies against measles and mumps were at the low limits of normal, whereas responses to pneumococcal and hepatitis B were normal. He had frequent upper respiratory infections, but had normal development and was in good health at 9 years of age. A sister had died in infancy of meningoencephalitis after receiving MMR vaccine. P2 was a 14-year-old girl, born of unrelated Brazilian parents, who presented at age 12 years with fever, encephalitis, acute renal and hepatic failure, and leukocytosis following vaccination for yellow fever. She made a full recovery and was healthy at age 14. She had previously received 2 MMR vaccines and oral live poliovirus and BCG in early childhood without incident. {6:Khanmohammadi et al. (2022)} reported follow-up of P1, who presented with a severe COVID-19 respiratory infection requiring hospitalization at age 13 years. In addition to MMR-associated meningitis in infancy, he had a history of recurrent hospitalizations due to infection with influenza virus. Treatment with gamma-interferon (IFNG; {147570}) resulted in clinical improvement, and he was eventually discharged. These findings indicated that patients with INFAR1 deficiency may be predisposed to severe COVID-19 infections.

{4:Gothe et al. (2022)} reported a previously healthy 15-month-old boy, born of consanguineous parents, who developed a severe fatal hyperinflammatory response to MMR vaccination. He met the diagnostic criteria for HLH and died 6 months later. Analysis of serum and CSF did not showed vaccine-strain viral replication, but low-level EBV was detected.

{3:Bastard et al. (2021)} reported a girl, born of consanguineous Palestinian parents, who had recurrent viral infections in infancy and developed HSV encephalitis (HSE), resulting in death around 20 months of age. Prior to this, she had developed a fever following MMR vaccination, but it resolved spontaneously. A first cousin of the patient (P3) died at age 12 months following a severe adverse reaction to MMR vaccination. P2, who was the sib of P3, had episodes of aseptic meningitis in infancy that may have been related to HSV. At age 14 years, P2 developed parotiditis followed by bilateral hearing loss. This episode was strongly suspected to be due to mumps infection; he had not received MMR vaccination per the family's request. Serum analysis of P2 showed the presence of antibodies to various viruses, including HSV1, VZV, CMV, EBV, measles, and mumps.

{2:Bastard et al. (2022)} reported 7 patients from 5 unrelated families of western Polynesian origin who presented in the first months or year of life with severe life-threatening viral infections. Six of the 7 patients developed an acute adverse systemic hyperinflammatory reaction within days to weeks after vaccination with live attenuated MMR vaccine. Features included fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, encephalopathy, and acute respiratory distress syndrome. Most of these patients also developed thrombocytopenia, anemia, hyperferritinemia, dyslipidemia, coagulopathy, and increased levels of soluble CD25 (IL2RA; {147730}) with evidence of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). Vaccine-strain measles and mumps were detected in tissue from some of the patients. Three patients (P1-P3) died in infancy of multiorgan failure soon after the MMR vaccination, whereas a fourth patient (P4) initially recovered, but died of RSV infection several months later. P5, the brother of P4, was a 7-year-old boy who developed aseptic meningoencephalitis and features of hyperinflammation initially diagnosed as Kawasaki disease ({611775}) 17 days after his first MMR vaccine at age 16 months. He recovered and tolerated the second MMR dose without complications. P5 had no neurocognitive deficits, but demonstrated unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, possibly a sequela of mumps infection. P6 had recurrent viral pneumonia in the first year of life and showed an acute inflammatory reaction to MMR with viral encephalitis at age 14 months. He subsequently had multiple viral respiratory infections, including RSV and parainfluenza virus, necessitating extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO); thereafter he demonstrated bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, global developmental delay, and autism spectrum disorder. Four of the 6 patients with a severe reaction to MMR were noted to have viral infections prior to the first MMR vaccine, including respiratory infections with bronchiolitis (P4 and P5), recurrent viral pneumonia (P6), and enteroviral meningoencephalitis (P3). However, 2 sibs from family A (P1 and P2) were healthy before MMR vaccination at age 12 months and tolerated live attenuated vaccination with BCG and oral polio. P7 presented at 10 months of age with hemophilus influenza type B (Hib) bacteremia and meningitis complicated by seizures, and later developed RSV-associated respiratory insufficiency and multiorgan failure requiring ECMO. P7 received MMR vaccine at ages 4 and 4.5 years without complications; she was the only patient of the cohort who tolerated MMR vaccination. She also had developmental delay that may have been unrelated to the IMD phenotype.

{1:Abolhassani et al. (2022)} reported a 3-year-old girl, born of consanguineous Iranian parents, who presented around 8 months of age with chronic sinusitis and oral thrush and later developed severe mucormycosis of the nose and paranasal sinuses. She had no adverse reaction to vaccination with LAV, including BCG, oral polio, and MMR. At age 3 years, she presented with a severe SARS-CoV-2 infection complicated by pneumonia and multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C). Features included fever, respiratory insufficiency, hypotension, lymphadenopathy, anemia, leukocytosis, elevated transaminases, metabolic acidosis, and evidence of myocardial injury. Despite intensive care, she died of cardiorespiratory failure. This patient was also reported by {7:Zhang et al. (2022)} as patient P12 in a study of an international cohort of 112 children less than 16 years of age who were hospitalized for COVID-19 pneumonia.
disease_name+syn: ['Immunodeficiency 106, susceptibility to viral infections', 'IFNAR1', ' IMD106']

disease_des/def:
Familial hypercholesterolemia is characterized by elevation of serum cholesterol bound to low density lipoprotein (LDL), which promotes deposition of cholesterol in the skin (xanthelasma), tendons (xanthomas), and coronary arteries (atherosclerosis). The disorder occurs in 2 clinical forms: homozygous and heterozygous ({68:Hobbs et al., 1992}).

The FHCL1 phenotype can be modified by mutation in other genes. For example, in individuals with the LDLR mutation IVS14+1G-A ({606945.0063}), the phenotype can be altered by a SNP in the APOA2 gene ({107670.0002}), a SNP in the EPHX2 gene ({132811.0001}), or a SNP in the GHR gene ({600946.0028}).

<Subhead> Genetic Heterogeneity of Familial Hypercholesterolemia

Other forms of monogenic familial hypercholesterolemia include FHCL2 ({144010}), caused by mutation in the APOB gene ({107730}); FHCL3 ({603776}), caused by mutation in the PCSK9 gene ({607786}); and FHCL4 ({603813}), caused by mutation in the LDLRAP1 gene ({605747}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
Individuals with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia develop tendinous xanthomas, corneal arcus, and coronary artery disease; the last usually becomes evident in the fourth or fifth decade. Homozygous individuals have a more severe clinical picture with earlier presentation, usually in the first 2 decades of life ({68:Hobbs et al., 1992}).

The ranges of serum cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol are, in mg per dl, 250-450 and 200-400 in heterozygotes, greater than 500 and greater than 450 in homozygous affecteds, and 150-250 and 75-175 in homozygous unaffecteds, with some positive correlation with age ({84:Khachadurian, 1964}; {94:Kwiterovich et al., 1974}).

In homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia, the aortic root is prone to develop atherosclerotic plaque at an early age. Such plaques can accumulate in unusual sites, such as the ascending aorta and around the coronary ostia. {131:Summers et al. (1998)} evaluated the aortic root using MRI imaging in a blinded, prospective study of 17 homozygous FH patients and 12 healthy controls. When patient age and body mass index were taken into account, 53% of patients with homozygous FH had increased aortic wall thickness compared to controls; this was thought to result from a combination of medial hyperplasia and plaque formation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis was seen in 41% of patients.

{77:Houlston et al. (1988)} studied the relationship of lipoprotein(a) ({152200}) levels and coronary heart disease in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia. Individuals with coronary artery disease had a significantly higher mean lipoprotein(a) concentration than those without coronary heart disease, suggesting that lipoprotein(a) measurements may help predict the risk of coronary heart disease in individuals with familial hypercholesterolemia.

{34:Deramo et al. (2003)} investigated the relationship between nonarteritic ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION; {258660}) and serum lipid levels in 37 consecutive patients diagnosed with NAION at or below age 50 years and 74 age- and gender-matched controls. They found that hypercholesterolemia was a risk factor in these patients and suggested that NAION might be the first manifestation of a previously unrecognized lipid disorder. The patients had experienced a focal, microvascular central nervous system ischemic event at a relatively young age. {34:Deramo et al. (2003)} suggested that aggressive treatment of lipid abnormalities might be warranted in these patients.
disease_name+syn: ['Hypercholesterolemia, familial, 1', 'LDLR', ' FHCL1', ' FHC', ' FH', ' LDLCQ2']

disease_des/def:
Combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency-45 (COXPD45) is an autosomal recessive multisystem disorder characterized by poor overall growth apparent from infancy, global developmental delay, seizures, and acute progressive neurologic deterioration with loss of skills. Other features may include dysmorphic facies and lesions on brain imaging. Laboratory studies show increased serum lactate and COXPD in patient tissues, consistent with a mitochondrial defect (summary by {1:Serre et al., 2013}).

For discussion of genetic heterogeneity of combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency, see COXPD1 ({609060}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Serre et al. (2013)} reported a boy, born of consanguineous Roma Gypsy parents, with COXPD45. He presented at birth with severe hypotrophy and later showed failure to thrive with poor overall growth. He had mild muscle weakness, but started walking with aid at 12 months. Increased plasma lactate prompted analysis of mitochondrial respiratory chain enzyme activity, which demonstrated a combined OXPHOS deficiency in muscle, liver, and skin fibroblasts. Complexes I and IV were particularly affected. At age 2, he developed seizures and had rapid neurologic deterioration associated with an acute infection and fever. He then showed psychomotor retardation, severe trunk hypotonia, inability to sit or stand unaided, no speech, intermittent horizontal nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, and tremor. Brain imaging showed white matter abnormalities and lesions in the basal ganglia. His condition continued to deteriorate and he died after cardiac arrest. Mild facial dysmorphisms were noted, including round face, epicanthic folds, arched palate, short neck, low-set ears, and median palmar crease. During the next pregnancy, the mother expected dizygotic twins, but prenatal diagnosis based on assessment of respiratory chain enzyme activities showed a severe complex IV deficiency in fetal cells, leading to termination of the pregnancy.
disease_name+syn: ['Combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency 45', 'MRPL12', ' RPML12']

disease_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with or without variable movement or behavioral abnormalities
disease_des/def: Neurodevelopmental disorder with or without variable movement or behavioral abnormalities (NEDMAB) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by mildly to severely impaired intellectual development and, in some patients, movement abnormalities consisting of tremors, cerebellar ataxia, or extrapyramidal symptoms. Movement abnormalities have onset in childhood or adolescence. Other variable features include autism spectrum disorder or autistic features and epilepsy.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {2:Mochel et al. (2020)} described 10 unrelated patients with impaired intellectual development (IID), 6 of whom had early-onset movement abnormalities. The IID was mild in 4 patients, moderate in 3, and severe in 2; 1 patient, aged 2 years, had motor and language delays. The movement abnormalities included tremors (5 patients), cerebellar ataxia (4 patients), and extrapyramidal symptoms (4 patients), including myoclonus dystonia, bradykinesia with cogwheel rigidity, and dyskinesia with parkinsonism and choreic movements. The 4 patients without movement abnormalities were under the age of 16 years at the time of study. Autism spectrum disorder was seen in 2 patients, and autistic features were seen in 4. The 2 oldest patients, aged 30 and 60 years, had psychotic episodes in adulthood, suggesting that psychiatric findings might be a feature of the disorder. Epilepsy was seen in 2 patients. Brain MRI data were available for 6 patients, 3 of which showed white matter abnormalities. In 1 patient, her mother had similar findings (mild intellectual disability, a dyskinetic movement disorder with dystonia, and an unspecified psychiatric disorder) and the mother's brother had similar symptoms but was unavailable for genetic testing. The other 9 patients were the first in their family to be affected. The first patient studied was recruited from a series of individuals with leukoencephalopathies of unknown origin and the other patients were found through GeneMatcher.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodevelopmental disorder with or without variable movement or behavioral abnormalities', 'KCNN2', ' SK2', ' DYT34', ' NEDMAB']

disease_des/def:
Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy-69 (DEE69) is an autosomal dominant severe neurodevelopmental encephalopathic disorder characterized by early-onset refractory seizures, hypotonia, and profoundly impaired development often associated with macrocephaly, hyperkinetic movements, and contractures. The disorder can sometimes result in early death. Some patients may have a favorable seizure response to topiramate medication (summary by {1:Helbig et al., 2018}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of DEE, see {308350}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Helbig et al. (2018)} reported 30 unrelated patients with a similar neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by early-onset intractable seizures, severe hypotonia, and severe or profound global developmental delay with absent or very poor speech and inability to sit or walk. Most of the patients were children in the first decade, although there were several teenagers and 1 patient who died at age 25 years. Six further patients died in the first years of life. Most patients presented with various types of seizures in the first months of life, although 2 patients had onset of seizures at 3 years of age and 2 had not had seizures by age 4 years. EEG in those with seizures showed multifocal discharges, polyspike slow-wave discharges, and sometimes hypsarrhythmia or burst-suppression patterns. Some patients showed developmental regression after onset of seizures. Additional common features included spastic quadriplegia, hyperreflexia, hyperkinetic movements, dystonia, myoclonus, clonus, poor or absent eye contact, nystagmus, cortical visual impairment, and loss of head control. Thirteen patients had congenital contractures and 13 had macrocephaly. Brain imaging was normal in many and showed nonspecific white matter volume loss, atrophy of the corpus callosum, or cortical atrophy in a few patients. Three patients (27, 28, and 29) had a slightly milder phenotype, including 2 who had not developed seizures by age 4 years and 1 who had been seizure-free and was off medication at age 6. These 3 patients were able to achieve walking and a few words.

<Subhead> Clinical Variability

{2:Royer-Bertrand et al. (2021)} described 7 patients, aged 18 months to 31 years, with de novo mutations in the CACNA1E gene, only one of whom (patient 4) had seizures (infantile spasms), which began at 6.5 months of age and responded to topiramate. Of 3 other patients tested, 2 had an abnormal EEG and 1 was normal. All 7 patients had global developmental delay and/or intellectual disability. Four patients showed developmental regression and 3 showed motor stereotypies. Symptom onset/parental concern was shortly after birth to 24 months of age.
disease_name+syn: ['Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 69', 'CACNA1E', ' CACNL1A6', ' DEE69']

disease_des/def:
About 2 to 3% of human males are infertile because of defects in sperm function, primarily due to oligozoospermia (defined as less than 10-15 million sperm per mL of semen) or azoospermia ({20:Hull et al., 1985}).

<Subhead> Heterogeneity of Spermatogenic Failure

For a discussion of Y-linked spermatogenic failure due to Sertoli cell-only syndrome, see {400042}.

For a discussion of phenotypic and genetic heterogeneity of spermatogenic failure, see SPGF1 ({258150}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{47:Tiepolo and Zuffardi (1976)} observed the involvement of Yq deletions in male infertility when they were analyzing cells from idiopathic infertile males. Molecular studies ({38:Reijo et al., 1995}; {50:Vogt et al., 1996}; {37:Pryor et al., 1997}, {15:Foresta et al., 2001}) have since shown that microdeletions at Yq11 may represent the etiologic factor in as many as 10 to 20% of cases with idiopathic azoospermia or severe oligozoospermia. Most of the deletions occur de novo and fall in 3 nonoverlapping regions, designated AZFa, AZFb, and AZFc (see {50:Vogt et al., 1996}), of which the distally located AZFc is most frequently deleted ({51:Yen, 1998}).

{15:Foresta et al. (2001)} reviewed published data on more than 4,800 infertile men who had been screened for Y-chromosome microdeletions and found that patients with Y-chromosome deletions frequently have sperm either in the ejaculate or within the testis and are therefore suitable candidates for assisted reproduction techniques. However, the authors noted that while the use of spermatozoa carrying Y-chromosome deletions may produce pregnancies, in such cases the genetic anomaly will invariably be passed on to male offspring.
disease_name+syn: ['Spermatogenic failure, Y-linked, 2', 'USP9Y', ' DFFRY', ' SPGFY2']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{5:Lockey et al. (1973)} observed 2 families. In 1 family, consanguinity suggested recessive inheritance. The late onset and discordance in a pair of identical twins suggested that environmental factors may be important also. {6:Miller (1971)} reported affected sisters. {10:Von Maur et al. (1974)} described a family in which autosomal dominant inheritance of aspirin asthma was suggested. In addition to mode of inheritance, differences from prior reports included an earlier age of onset, lack of nasal polyps and sinusitis, and milder asthma.

{9:Spector et al. (1979)} found that oral challenge with aspirin caused bronchoconstriction in 19% of consecutive adult asthma patients, and other studies involving challenge with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) in both adults and children with asthma confirm a prevalence of 10 to 20%. Aspirin causes bronchoconstriction in aspirin-intolerant asthma (AIA) patients by triggering cysteinyl-leukotriene production, probably by removing PGE(2)-dependent inhibition. To investigate why aspirin does not cause bronchoconstriction in all individuals, {3:Cowburn et al. (1998)} immunostained enzymes of the leukotriene and prostanoid pathways in bronchial biopsies from AIA patients, aspirin-tolerant asthma (ATA) patients, and normal (N) subjects. Counts of cells expressing the terminal enzyme for cysteinyl-leukotriene synthesis, LTC4 synthase ({246530}), were 5-fold higher in AIA biopsies than in ATA biopsies and 18-fold higher than in N biopsies. Aspirin may remove PGE(2)-dependent suppression in all subjects, but only in AIA patients does increased bronchial expression of LTC4 synthase allow marked overproduction of cysteinyl-leukotriene leading to bronchoconstriction. {3:Cowburn et al. (1998)} speculated that a polymorphism directed to the regulation of LTC4 synthase expression could be a predisposing factor for the AIA group.

{2:Arm and Austen (2002)} stated that between 3% and 10% of asthma patients have acute, severe asthma accompanied by rhinorrhea and sometimes associated with hives, flushing, or abdominal pain after the injection of aspirin or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). The common feature of drugs that provoke asthma attacks in aspirin-intolerant persons is that they inhibit cyclooxygenase-1 (COX1; {176805}); selective inhibition of cyclooxygenase-2 (COX2; {600262}) appears not to provoke such a response. Cautious, incremental administration of oral doses of aspirin can lead to a state in which persons with aspirin-sensitive asthma can ingest aspirin without untoward reactions, but daily administration must be continued to maintain this state.

Patients with asthma and aspirin sensitivity have greater cysteinyl leukotriene production and greater airway hyperresponsiveness to the effects of inhaled cysteinyl leukotrienes than their aspirin-tolerant counterparts. {8:Sousa et al. (2002)} hypothesized that the latter effect reflects elevated expression of the cysteinyl leukotriene receptor CYSLT1 ({300201}) on inflammatory cells in the target organ and that its expression is downregulated by aspirin desensitization. They found elevated numbers of nasal inflammatory leukocytes expressing the CYSLT1 receptor in aspirin-sensitive patients with chronic rhinosinusitis as compared with their non-aspirin-sensitive counterparts and the downregulation of receptor expression after desensitization to aspirin.
disease_name+syn: ['Asthma and nasal polyps', 'TBX21', ' TBET', ' IMD88']

disease_des/def: The primary antigens of the Lewis blood group system, Le(a) and Le(b), are not synthesized by red cells but are introduced into the red cell membrane from plasma. The terminology Le(a) and Le(b) is misleading, as these antigens are not allelic. The Le gene, FUT3, encodes an alpha-1,4-L-fucosyltransferase that catalyzes the addition of a fucose residue to the H antigen to produce Le(b) or to the precursor of H to produce Le(a). The presence of H antigen in secretions is governed by the FUT2 gene ({182100}). Thus, red cells of most H secretors, who have a functional FUT2 enzyme, are Le(a-b+), and those of H nonsecretors (see {182100.0001}), who have a nonfunctional FUT2 enzyme, are Le(a+b-). FUT3 can also convert A antigen to ALe(b) and B antigen to BLe(b) (see {110300}). About 6% of white people and 25% of black people are homozygous for loss-of-function FUT2 mutations (e.g., {111100.0001}) and therefore have Le(a-b-) red cells and lack Lewis substances in their secretions. In Asia, the red cell phenotype Le(a+b+) is common and results from a weak secretor allele in FUT2 ({182100.0002}). The Le(c) and Le(d) antigens represent precursors of the Le antigens and are present in increased quantities in plasma of Le(a-b-) individuals. The Le(x) and Le(y) antigens are isomers of Le(a) and Le(b), respectively, and are not present in substantial quantities on red cells. Although Le antibodies are relatively common, hemolytic transfusion reactions are rare, and Le antibodies do not cause serious hemolytic disease of the newborn (summary by {2:Daniels, 2002}).
disease_name+syn: ['Blood group, Lewis', 'FUT3', ' LE']

disease_des/def:
Bartter syndrome refers to a group of disorders that are unified by autosomal recessive transmission of impaired salt reabsorption in the thick ascending loop of Henle with pronounced salt wasting, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and hypercalciuria. Clinical disease results from defective renal reabsorption of sodium chloride in the thick ascending limb (TAL) of the Henle loop, where 30% of filtered salt is normally reabsorbed ({13:Simon et al., 1997}).

Patients with antenatal forms of Bartter syndrome typically present with premature birth associated with polyhydramnios and low birth weight and may develop life-threatening dehydration in the neonatal period. Patients with classic Bartter syndrome (see BARTS3, {607364}) present later in life and may be sporadically asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic (summary by {14:Simon et al., 1996} and {2:Fremont and Chan, 2012}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of Bartter syndrome, see {607364}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
The antenatal form of Bartter syndrome is a life-threatening disorder in which both renal tubular hypokalemic alkalosis and profound systemic symptoms are manifest ({12:Seyberth et al., 1985}; {1:Deschenes et al., 1993}; and {10:Proesmans et al., 1985}). The abnormalities begin in utero with marked fetal polyuria that leads to polyhydramnios between 24 and 30 weeks of gestation and, typically, premature delivery ({9:Ohlsson et al., 1984}). The amniotic fluid contains high chloride levels but normal concentrations of sodium, potassium, calcium, and prostaglandin E2. Affected neonates have severe salt wasting and hyposthenuria, moderate hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hyperprostaglandinuria, and failure to thrive. The {4:International Collaborative Study Group for Bartter-like Syndromes (1997)} noted that an essential manifestation of the antenatal variant is marked hypercalciuria, and as a secondary consequence, affected infants develop nephrocalcinosis and osteopenia. Fever, vomiting, and occasional diarrhea associated with the disorder have been attributed to the stimulation of renal and systemic prostaglandin E2 activity in affected infants; these symptoms are effectively treated with inhibitors of prostaglandin synthesis. Based on these clinical features, the antenatal form of Bartter syndrome has been referred to as the hyperprostaglandin E syndrome ({11:Seyberth et al., 1987}).

<Subhead> Clinical Variability

{5:Kurtz et al. (1997)} studied a cohort of 20 Costa Rican patients, previously described by {7:Madrigal et al. (1997)}, who had a congenital syndrome that bore strong similarities to antenatal Bartter syndrome type 1 but also had several distinct features. In all patients, pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios, and 7 of the 9 patients were born prematurely. Six of 9 patients studied in detail were presented for evaluation within the first year of life. One was not diagnosed until the age of 10 years and another was 4.5 years old at the time of diagnosis. All affected children had experienced recurrent episodes of vomiting and dehydration, dating from the first few weeks of life. The phenotype was remarkable for a peculiar facies in 7 of 9 children, characterized by a triangularly shaped face, protruding ears, and drooping mouth; in addition, 5 of 9 had strabismus, and there was evidence of sensorineural hearing loss by audiogram testing in 2 of 9. All had hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hyposthenuria, and failure to thrive, with growth parameters less than the 3rd centile for age. Hypercalciuria with associated sonographic evidence of nephrocalcinosis was demonstrated in 7 children. The other 2 children had evidence of nephrocalcinosis but normal urine calcium excretion. Renal function was well preserved in all but 1 patient, who developed renal insufficiency and progressed to end-stage renal disease by 16 years of age. Although the development of tubulointerstitial disease leading to a progressive decline in renal function had been described both in patients treated with long-term indomethacin and in patients with classic Bartter syndrome, this patient was not treated with indomethacin, and the etiology of her end-stage renal disease remained unexplained. {5:Kurtz et al. (1997)} noted that the Costa Rican patients had a milder clinical course than other antenatal Bartter syndrome patients with NKCC2 (SLC12A1) mutations.

{3:Gross et al. (2015)} reported a 5-month-old boy, born of consanguineous Arab Muslim parents with an unusual presentation of BARTS1. The delivery was complicated by polyhydramnios, and he was diagnosed with nephrocalcinosis in the neonatal period. After treatment with antibiotics for a febrile illness at age 3 months, he developed severe diarrhea with weight loss. Laboratory studies at age 5 months showed increased serum calcium, hypercalciuria, and hyperparathyroidism, but other electrolytes were normal. Specifically, he did not have hypokalemia or metabolic alkalosis. Head and neck ultrasound did not show a parathyroid adenoma. Treatment with potassium citrate was effective for the biochemical abnormalities, but he showed significant developmental delay with hypotonia at age 10 months. {3:Gross et al. (2015)} suggested that the abnormality in renal calcium homeostasis may have triggered changes in parathyroid hormone (PTH; {168450}) secretion. Whole-exome sequencing identified a homozygous frameshift mutation in the SLC12A1 gene, confirming the diagnosis.

{6:Li et al. (2016)} reported 2 African American brothers with BARTS1 associated with hyperparathyroidism, hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, and nephrocalcinosis. Both pregnancies were complicated by polyhydramnios and premature delivery. The proband's brother died of multiorgan failure at 9 weeks, and postmortem examination showed multigland parathyroid hyperplasia. The 12-year-old proband continued to have persistent hypercalciuria and increased PTH levels with normal bone density. Other electrolytes were only mildly disturbed: he had mildly low sodium, potassium, chloride, and magnesium, and mildly increased bicarbonate. Plasma renin, vasopressin, and urinary prostaglandin E2 were increased. He was treated with cinacalcet and potassium citrate. Neck ultrasound did not reveal a parathyroid adenoma.

{15:Wongsaengsak et al. (2017)} reported 4 patients from 3 unrelated families of Hispanic descent with genetically confirmed BARTS1 associated with hyperparathyroidism, hypercalcemia, nephrocalcinosis, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. All had classic features of the disorder, including polyhydramnios and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and most had increased renin activity. Additional features included poor overall growth, failure to thrive, respiratory insufficiency, and gastroesophageal reflux. One patient was noted to have dysmorphic facial features with triangular facies and prominent forehead, and 2 were noted to have developmental delay. Treatment strategies included indomethacin, cinacalcet, potassium supplementation, and chlorothiazide, with variable responses.
disease_name+syn: ['Bartter syndrome, type 1', 'SLC12A1', ' NKCC2']

disease_des/def: Systemic autoinflammatory disease with vasculitis (SAIDV) is an autosomal dominant disorder that manifests soon after birth with features such as purpuric skin rash, fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP; {123260}). Laboratory studies may show leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and autoantibodies. A subset of patients develop progressive liver involvement that may result in fibrosis. Other systemic features, such as periorbital edema, conjunctivitis, infections, abdominal pain, and arthralgia are usually observed. Mutations occur de novo. {1:De Jesus et al. (2023)} referred to this disorder as LAVLI (LYN kinase-associated vasculopathy and liver fibrosis).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{2:De Jesus et al. (2016)} reported a 3-year-old Caucasian boy born at 31 weeks' gestation with hydrops fetalis requiring intrauterine blood transfusion. After birth, he developed a purpuric skin rash, periorbital erythema, testicular swelling, and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies showed increased C-reactive protein, anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, leukocytosis, and circulating autoantibodies. Splenectomy was performed at 9 months of age, but anemia and thrombocytopenia persisted. Liver biopsy showed periportal lymphocytic infiltration and vanishing bile duct disease; skin biopsy showed vasculitis. After a mutation in the LYN gene was identified, he was treated with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (dasatinib), which resulted in clinical improvement.

{1:De Jesus et al. (2023)} reported 3 unrelated boys (P1, P2, and P3) who presented soon after birth with a systemic autoinflammatory disorder. Patient 1 had previously been reported by {2:de Jesus et al. (2016)}. Common features included diffuse purpuric skin lesions, fever, increased C-reactive protein, mild leukocytosis, and transient positivity for autoantibodies. P1 and P3, both of whom carried a nonsense mutation in the LYN gene, developed liver fibrosis, whereas P2, who had a missense mutation, did not have liver involvement. Liver biopsy of P1 had clusters of macrophages and scattered neutrophils within hepatic sinuses and portal areas, as well as fibrosis. Skin biopsy showed neutrophilic vasculitis. Additional more variable features included poor overall growth, abdominal pain, periorbital edema and erythema, conjunctivitis, epididymitis, headaches, arthralgias, oral ulcers, fatigue, and colitis that was reminiscent of graft-versus-host disease.

{3:Louvrier et al. (2023)} reported a 4-year-old girl who was born prematurely at 26 weeks and 2 days' gestation due to HELLP syndrome with the findings of intrauterine growth retardation, cardiomegaly, hepatomegaly with persistent Arantius duct, and liver microcalcifications. At birth, she showed cholestasis, hepatosplenomegaly, hyaline membrane disease with respiratory insufficiency requiring intubation and noninvasive ventilation, and abdominal bloating suggestive of enteropathy. Other features included elevated C-reactive protein and episodic systemic inflammation with leukocytosis, fever, urticarial lesions, atopic dermatitis, arthritis, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and acute asthma. She also had growth retardation, global developmental delay, and dysmorphic features, including frontal bossing and hypertelorism. At age 2 years, immunophenotyping showed B and T cell lymphocytosis with increased levels of proinflammatory cytokines. Anti-IL1 (see {147760}) therapy was effective for the clinical symptoms and partly improved the growth defects.
disease_name+syn: ['Autoinflammatory disease, systemic, with vasculitis', 'LYN', ' SAIDV']

disease_name: Cortical dysplasia, complex, with other brain malformations 5
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Cushion et al. (2014)} reported 2 unrelated children with a severe neurodevelopmental disorder. A male child presented with infantile spasms at age 5 months, and was found to have hypsarrhythmia on EEG. Brain MRI showed a diffuse simplified gyral pattern with reduced volume of white matter, globular basal ganglia and thalami, enlarged ventricles, thin and dysmorphic corpus callosum, mild brainstem hypoplasia with a flattened pons, mild cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and a mildly enlarged posterior fossa. At age 8 months, he had continued seizures and global developmental delay. The second child had a less severe phenotype. She presented with hypotonia at age 4 months. EEG showed multifocal epileptiform discharges, but clinically the seizures consisted only of subtle vertical eye movements. The seizures resolved, and she was weaned off medication at age 2 years. Brain MRI showed a dysmorphic corpus callosum but normal basal ganglia, thalami, and gyral pattern. At age 3 years, she was nonverbal and nonambulatory with generalized hypotonia.

{2:Rodan et al. (2017)} reported a boy who had hypertonia and exaggerated startle in the neonatal period. He had global developmental delay since birth, and at age 4 years he was able to ambulate with ankle orthoses. He did not have any words, and he could follow one-step commands. He had cortical visual impairment but an otherwise normal ophthalmologic examination. His head circumference was at the 77th percentile, whereas his height was at the 2.8th percentile and weight below the first percentile. Brain MRI showed focal pachygyria, thinning of the body and splenium of the corpus callosum, and mildly decreased cerebral white matter.

{3:Schmidt et al. (2021)} reported 3 unrelated patients with impaired intellectual development, hypotonia, global developmental delay, cortical dysplasia, and dysmorphic corpus callosum. Patient 1 was a 17-year-old boy who was diagnosed with cortical visual impairment at 4 months of age. At age 3 years he had global developmental delay and was diagnosed with a neuronal migration disorder. He developed seizures at age 8, and a brain MRI at age 12 showed thinning of the corpus callosum, pachygyria, signal abnormality in the periaqueductal gray matter, and hypoplasia of the right caudate nucleus body. Patient 2 was a 14-year-old girl with congenital microcephaly, hypotonia, autism spectrum disorder, global developmental delay, and impaired intellectual development. Brain MRI at age 3 years showed cortical thickening of the frontal region suggestive of pachygyria, and brain MRI at age 6 showed periventricular leukomalacia. Patient 3 was a 13-year-old girl with a history of hypotonia, seizure disorder, mildly impaired intellectual development, sleep disturbances, central hypothyroidism, hyperactivity, and self-injurious behaviors. Brain MRI at age 4 showed shallow sulcation, broad gyri, and cortical thickening suggestive of pachygyria, among other findings.
disease_name+syn: ['Cortical dysplasia, complex, with other brain malformations 5', 'TUBB2A', ' CDCBM5']

disease_name: Facial palsy, congenital, with ptosis and velopharyngeal dysfunction
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Fazeli et al. (2017)} reported a 5-generation family with congenital nonprogressive bilateral facial palsy and velopharyngeal dysfunction. Features included varying degrees of hypomimia, rhinophonia, impaired gag reflex, and bilateral ptosis. The proband was a 4-year-old girl who showed bilateral ptosis and facial palsy since infancy. Physical examination as a child showed reduced motility of the levator palpebrae muscles with compensatory chin up posture and velopharyngeal dysfunction with a wide uvula, absent gag reflex, and severe rhinophonia aperta with speech articulation defects. She had no additional neurologic, skeletal, muscular, or cognitive abnormalities. Family history revealed a similar phenotype on the paternal side of the family. The severity of the disorder was highly variable: some patients had a mild hypomotile upper lip or reduced gag reflex only, whereas others had varying degrees of rhinophonia aperta, impaired facial movement, and ptosis. Some of the patients required surgical intervention for nasal regurgitation or ptosis. None of the affected individuals had limitation of ocular abduction or limb abnormalities as described for Moebius syndrome (MBS; {157900}). Cognition was normal in all patients. The phenotype was nonprogressive, and some patients reported improved symptoms with age or speech therapy. Brain imaging in 3 affected individuals showed no abnormalities.
disease_name+syn: ['Facial palsy, congenital, with ptosis and velopharyngeal dysfunction', 'TUBB6', ' FPVEPD']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
According to the DSM-IV-TR ({1:American Psychiatric Association, 2000}), major depressive disorder is characterized by one or more major depressive episodes without a history of manic, mixed, or hypomanic episodes. A major depressive episode is characterized by at least 2 weeks during which there is a new onset or clear worsening of either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure in nearly all activities. Four additional symptoms must also be present including changes in appetite, weight, sleep, and psychomotor activity; decreased energy; feelings of worthlessness or guilt; difficulty thinking, concentrating, or making decisions; or recurrent thoughts of death or suicidal ideation, plans, or attempts. The episode must be accompanied by distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Major depressive disorder is commonly recurrent and can be lethal. Up to 15% of individuals with severe major depressive disorder die by suicide. There is a 4-fold increase in death rate of individuals with major depressive disorder over 55 years of age ({1:American Psychiatric Association, 2000}).
disease_name+syn: ['Major depressive disorder 1', 'MDD1']

disease_des/def:
Congenital myopathy-15 (CMYP15) is a skeletal muscle disorder characterized by symptom onset soon after birth. Affected infants are hypotonic and have severe respiratory insufficiency and feeding problems, sometimes requiring mechanical ventilation or tube feeding. The disorder is unique in that there is gradual improvement of the severe muscle weakness with time, although forced vital capacity remains decreased. Additional features include facial weakness, scoliosis, joint contractures, and persistent ptosis or external ophthalmoplegia ({1:van de Locht et al., 2021}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of congenital myopathy, see CMYP1A ({117000}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Van de Locht et al. (2021)} reported 4 patients from 2 unrelated families with a similar type of congenital myopathy. In family 1, 3 patients spanning 3 generations were affected; the proband in family 2 had no family history of the disorder. The patients, who ranged from 19 to 76 years of age, all presented in the neonatal period with hypotonia, stridor, vocal cord paralysis, and respiratory insufficiency; 2 patients required tracheostomy. Two of the pregnancies were complicated by polyhydramnios, and fetal movements were noted to be decreased in 1 case. Two patients had swallowing difficulties necessitating tube-feeding. All had delayed motor development with mildly delayed walking, an unsteady waddling gait, difficulty keeping up with peers, and inability to run. The severe respiratory insufficiency in the neonatal period improved with time, although all had decreased forced vital capacity at last examination. None had cardiac involvement. There was an overall improvement in muscle weakness with time, but the older patients reported a more recent gradual decline in muscle strength. Other features included facial weakness, often with ptosis or external ophthalmoplegia, jaw or distal joint contractures, scoliosis, and osteopenia. Skeletal muscle biopsy, performed in 2 patients, showed mild variation in fiber size without structural abnormalities, necrosis, or fibrosis. There was mild atrophy of fast-twitch type 2 fibers and some hypertrophy of slow-twitch type 1 fibers, which may have represented a compensatory effect. MRI of the lower limbs showed mild focal fatty infiltration. Two patients in family 1 had mild learning difficulties, but both graduated from high school.
disease_name+syn: ['Congenital myopathy 15', 'TNNC2', ' CMYP15']

disease_des/def:
Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis-3 (CRMO3) is an autosomal dominant autoinflammatory bone disease characterized by early childhood onset of bone pain and arthritis caused by sterile osteomyelitis. The disorder results from constitutive activation of the IL1-mediated inflammatory pathway due to loss of IL1 receptor sensitivity to its antagonist IL1RN ({147679}). {6:Wang et al. (2023)} suggested the term 'Loss of IL1R1 Sensitivity to IL1RA (IL1RN)' or 'LIRSA' as a designation for this disorder.

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of CRMO, see {609628}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{4:Giedion et al. (1972)} described a syndrome termed chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis (CRMO). The inflammation had both subacute and chronic features, with lesions located predominantly in the metaphyses of the long bones. No pathogens were isolated from affected areas.

{6:Wang et al. (2023)} reported a 13-year-old girl with CRMO3 who carried a mutation in the IL1R1 gene. She presented at 15 months of age with left knee-joint swelling and arthralgia. During childhood, she developed arthritis of the shoulders, elbows, wrists, hips, knees, and ankles. She had chronic pain, gait disturbance, and poor overall growth. Skin rash and recurrent fever were not observed. Radiographs showed heterotopic ossification, osteolytic lesions, and multifocal metaphyseal lesions. Laboratory studies showed increased serum amyloid A (see {104750}), C-reactive protein (CRP; {123260}), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), suggesting an inflammatory process. Serum concentration of inflammatory cytokines, including IL1B ({147720}), IL6 ({147620}), and IL8 ({146930}), were elevated. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) was positive (1:100) and IgA was elevated. Treatment with TNF inhibitors did not result in significant clinical improvement, but treatment with a monoclonal antibody against IL1B (canakinumab) resulted in rapid and significant clinical improvement and reduced levels of inflammatory markers.
disease_name+syn: ['Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis 3', 'IL1R1', ' IL1RA', ' CRMO3']

disease_des/def: Hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) is characterized by severe nausea and vomiting in pregnancy. It occurs in up to 2% of pregnancies and results in significant weight loss, dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and ketonuria. It is associated with both maternal and fetal morbidity ({2:Fejzo et al., 2019}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
In a prospective observational study, {2:Fejzo et al. (2019)} analyzed serum concentrations of the hormones GDF15, IGFBP7 ({602867}), and hCG (see {118860}) at 12 and 24 weeks' gestation in 40 pregnant women, including 11 women hospitalized for hyperemesis gravidarum (HG), compared to 9 women with normal nausea and vomiting of pregnancy and 20 women with no nausea and vomiting of pregnancy. Serum levels of GDF15 and IGFBP7 were significantly increased in the women with HG, but hCG levels were not significantly different between cases and controls. At 24 weeks' gestation, when symptoms had largely resolved, there was no difference in GDF15 and IGFBP7 levels between cases and controls. Noting that the combined levels of both proteins resulted in a highly significant predictor for HG, the authors suggested that measuring levels of both proteins might be effective for disease prediction and diagnosis.

{1:Fejzo et al. (2024)} confirmed in 2 independent cohorts that levels of GDF15 in the maternal circulation in the late first trimester or second trimester were significantly higher in women with HG than in those without severe nausea and vomiting (p = 4.3 x 10(-5) and 3.3 x 10(-5), respectively).
disease_name+syn: ['Hyperemesis gravidarum, susceptibility to', 'GDF15', ' PLAB', ' PDF', ' MIC1', ' HG']

disease_des/def: Suleiman-El-Hattab syndrome (SULEHS) is an autosomal recessive multisystem developmental disorder characterized by hypotonia and feeding difficulties soon after birth, global developmental delay with impaired intellectual development and poor expressive speech, and a general happy demeanor. There is a distinctive facial appearance with microcephaly, thick arched eyebrows with synophrys, hypertelorism, epicanthal folds, low-set ears, broad nasal bridge, and thin upper lip. Additional more variable features include recurrent respiratory infections, cardiovascular malformations, cryptorchidism, seizures, and distal anomalies of the hands and feet (summary by {2:Suleiman et al., 2019}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {2:Suleiman et al. (2019)} reported 4 unrelated children, ranging from 1 to 4 years of age, with a similar syndromic developmental disorder. Patient 2 had previously been reported by {1:Suleiman et al. (2018)}. All patients were placed in the NICU soon after birth, due to hypotonia, respiratory insufficiency, and/or poor feeding with failure to thrive. They had significant global developmental delay with poor expressive speech. The 3 older patients achieved walking by age 3, often with difficulties, had poor motor skills, and were essentially nonverbal. The patients had limited ability to follow commands, indicating cognitive impairment, although visual tracking and attempts at communication were observed in some; a happy demeanor was noted. Other features included respiratory infections, cardiovascular malformations, mainly septal defects, cryptorchidism, and single palmar crease. Distinctive facial features included microcephaly (down to -5 SD), excessive forehead hair, arched and thick eyebrows with synophrys, epicanthus, hypertelorism, thick eyelids with periorbital fullness, broad nasal bridge, long smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, and low-set prominent ears with overfolded helices. Less common features included hirsutism, preauricular skin tag, webbed neck, microretrognathia, wide mouth, and downslanted palpebral fissures. Two patients had drooling, 2 had seizures, and 1 each had short stature, brachycephaly, polydactyly, clinodactyly, hydronephrosis, hearing impairment, and eye anomalies, including hyperopia, strabismus, amblyopia, and pale optic discs.
disease_name+syn: ['Suleiman-El-Hattab syndrome', 'TASP1', ' C20orf13', ' SULEHS']

disease_des/def: Neurocardiofaciodigital syndrome (NCFD) is characterized by severe developmental delay, variable brain anomalies, congenital heart defects, dysmorphic facial features, and a distinctive type of synpolydactyly with a supernumerary hypoplastic digit between the fourth and fifth digits of the hands and/or feet. Other features include eye abnormalities, hearing impairment, and electroencephalogram anomalies (summary by {1:Horn et al., 2021}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Horn et al. (2021)} reported 2 Egyptian sisters, aged 9 years and 2.5 years (patients 1 and 2), and an unrelated 19-month-old Turkish boy (patient 3) with severe developmental delay, facial and cardiac anomalies, and synpolydactyly with mutation in the MAPKAPK5 gene. Psychomotor development was severely delayed in all 3 children, with no ability to walk, and limited or no speech. All 3 exhibited electroencephalogram abnormalities; patient 1 developed syncopal episodes at age 9 years and was begun on antiepileptic treatment, and patient 2 had seizures that were controlled by phenobarbital. Variable brain anomalies included dilated fourth ventricle, small cerebellar hemispheres, and hypoplastic corpus callosum. Eye anomalies included optic disc pallor and tigroid retina, nystagmus, cataracts, and sclerocornea. Patients 1 and 3 also had hearing impairment. All 3 patients had congenital heart defects, including tetralogy of Fallot in patient 1, atrial septal defect and patent ductus arteriosus in patient 2, and double-inlet left ventricle, malposition of the great arteries, total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage, tubular hypoplasia of the aortic arch, and absence of the interatrial septum in patient 3. In addition, variable degrees of postaxial synpolydactyly of hands and feet were present in patients 1 and 3. A supernumerary hypoplastic digit was consistently located between the fourth and fifth digits and was always connected by cutaneous syndactyly to the fifth digit. The 3 children also exhibited common facial dysmorphisms, including prominent forehead, narrow palpebral fissures, thin lips, and retrognathia. Intrauterine growth retardation was observed in patient 1, and patients 1 and 2 had short stature and failure to thrive. Patients 2 and 3 developed postnatal microcephaly. The authors suggested that the type of synpolydactyly observed in these patients was very specific, and could be helpful in clinical diagnosis of the syndrome.

{3:Vecchio et al. (2022)} reported a 19-month-old boy with NCFD. Although at birth his weight and head circumference were normal, he had failure to thrive (weight -2.47 SD) and microcephaly when examined at age 19 months. He had severe global developmental delay. An EEG showed slow posterior activity and poor representation for the non-REM sleep graph-elements, but he reportedly had not had seizures. An echocardiogram showed a bicuspid aortic valve, slight ascending aorta dilation, hypertrabecular left ventricle, and a dysmorphic aortic arch. On brain MRI at age 14 months, he had hypoplasia of the corpus callosum, dilated fourth ventricle communicating with the cisterna magna, mild vermian and ventral pons hypoplasia, absence of olfactory bulbs, and reduced thickness of the cerebral white matter. At age 19 months he had brachyturricephaly, sparse hair and eyebrows, narrow and slightly downslanting palpebral fissures, hypoplastic nasal root, bulbous overhanging nasal tip, a small mouth with thin lips, a high-arched palate, and glossoptosis. He had mild strabismus, left kidney hypoplasia, right cryptorchidism, penoscrotal transposition, and coronal hypospadias. His fingers were short, and he had wide first toes and marked hypoplasia and dysplasia of the toenails.

{2:Maroofian et al. (2023)} reported 3 unrelated patients from consanguineous families with NCFD. All had severe global developmental delay, impaired intellectual development, characteristic facies, brachycephaly, digital anomalies, hair and nail defects, and abnormalities on brain imaging, including cerebellar hypoplasia and hypomyelination. Other features included failure to thrive, hypotonia, microcephaly, and genitourinary anomalies. Variable eye findings were seen in all 3 patients, and 2 of the patients had confirmed or suspected hearing loss. None of the 3 patients were reported as having congenital heart defects. When the authors reviewed their patients and the 4 previously reported patients, they noted failure to thrive (5/7), microcephaly (5/7), hearing impairment (5/7), congenital urogenital anomalies (5/6, but in 3/3 males), and congenital heart defects (4/7). None of the patients had a history of seizures.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurocardiofaciodigital syndrome', 'MAPKAPK5', ' PRAK', ' NCFD']

disease_des/def: Immunodeficiency-96 (IMD96) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by onset of recurrent, usually viral, respiratory infections in infancy or early childhood. Other infections, including gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections, may also occur. Laboratory studies show hypogammaglobulinemia, lymphopenia with increased gamma/delta T cells, and erythrocyte macrocytosis. The disorder results from defective cellular DNA repair (summary by {4:Maffucci et al., 2018}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{6:Webster et al. (1982)} reported a girl with a complex immunodeficiency and increased cellular sensitivity to DNA-damaging agents. {5:Webster et al. (1992)} provided follow-up of the patient, who presented in early childhood with poor overall growth and recurrent middle ear and chest infections that led to poor hearing and bronchiectasis. She had mildly delayed early developmental milestones (walking at age 3), but normal cognition. Other features included sun sensitivity, an 'elf-like' appearance, lack of secondary sexual characteristics during adolescence, and delayed bone age. At the age of 17, patches of venous dilatation appeared on her skin, mainly on the limbs. There was also some telangiectasia on the bulbar conjunctivae. Laboratory studies showed persistent red cell macrocytosis, low serum IgA and IgG, progressive lymphopenia with absent proliferative T-cell responses in vitro, increasing neutropenia, and hepatosplenomegaly with possible lymphoma. After a severe cutaneous herpes zoster infection, her condition deteriorated and she died of pneumonia at age 19.

{4:Maffucci et al. (2018)} reported 5 patients from 3 unrelated families with IMD96. Four patients were between 3 and 6 years of age, and 1 was 19. They had onset of variable recurrent infections in infancy or early childhood associated with hypogammaglobulinemia. The infections were mainly respiratory, although diarrhea was also reported, and the infectious agents tended to be viral, including adenovirus, rhinovirus, RSV, rotavirus, and herpes zoster. Patient 3 had oral candidiasis and urinary tract infections. Two sibs (P3 and P4), born of consanguineous Sudanese parents (kindred C), had severe anemia requiring blood transfusions and multicystic dysplastic kidneys. Laboratory studies showed hypogammaglobulinemia, low numbers of B cells, erythrocyte macrocytosis, and reduced absolute CD3+ T cells with increased gamma-delta T-cells. P1 and P2 were diagnosed with common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) and P3 and P4 were diagnosed with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). P3 and P4 underwent hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; other patients were treated with Ig replacement. Overall growth and development were normal.
disease_name+syn: ['Immunodeficiency 96', 'LIG1', ' IMD96']

disease_des/def: Hiatt-Neu-Cooper neurodevelopmental syndrome (HINCONS) is characterized by global developmental delay with delayed walking or inability to walk and impaired intellectual development with poor or absent speech. Affected individuals have axial hypotonia and dysmorphic facies. Additional more variable features may include seizures, autistic or behavioral abnormalities, and brain abnormalities, such as dysplastic corpus callosum or polymicrogyria (summary by {1:Hiatt et al., 2018}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Hiatt et al. (2018)} reported 11 patients, including a pair of monozygotic twins, with a similar neurodevelopmental disorder associated with de novo heterozygous mutations in the RALA gene who were ascertained through the GeneMatcher program. The patients, who ranged from 16 months to 16 years of age, presented in early infancy with global developmental delay, hypotonia, delayed walking or inability to walk, and moderately to severely impaired intellectual development with poor or absent speech and poor eye contact. They tended to have feeding difficulties with poor overall growth, sometimes with short stature. Several patients were wheelchair-bound, and 2 required feeding tubes. Six patients had various types of seizures, including absence, tonic, and myoclonic, 3 had autism spectrum disorder, and others had variable behavioral abnormalities. Brain imaging was normal in some patients, but showed variable abnormalities in others, including thin or dysplastic corpus callosum, periventricular gliosis, incomplete myelination, and polymicrogyria. Most patients had dysmorphic facial features, including relative macrocephaly or microcephaly, broad prominent forehead, bitemporal narrowing, flat midface, horizontal eyebrows, epicanthal folds, mild ptosis, slanted palpebral fissures, depressed or wide nasal bridge with anteverted nares, short philtrum, thin upper lip, pointed chin, drooling, and low-set or posteriorly rotated ears. Other features included distal skeletal anomalies, such as long thin fingers, fifth finger or toe clinodactyly, and hyperextensible joints.

{2:Okamoto et al. (2019)} reported a 9-year-old Japanese girl with global developmental delay, hypotonia, and severely impaired intellectual development; developmental quotient was 30. She had poor eye contact, esotropia, astigmatism, and myopia. Dysmorphic features included relative macrocephaly, frontal bossing, epicanthal folds, wide nasal bridge, thin upper lip, pointed chin, and low-set, posteriorly rotated ears. She also had aggressive behavior including self-mutilation and restlessness. Brain imaging was normal.
disease_name+syn: ['Hiatt-Neu-Cooper neurodevelopmental syndrome', 'RALA', ' HINCONS']

disease_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies, sleep disturbance, and brain abnormalities
disease_des/def: Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies, sleep disturbance, and brain abnormalities (NEDFASB) is a syndromic disorder with multisystemic involvement. Affected individuals have severe global developmental delay with severely impaired intellectual development, poor or absent language, behavioral abnormalities, seizures, and sleep disturbances. Craniofacial dysmorphisms, while variable, include round face, prognathism, depressed nasal bridge, and cleft or high-arched palate. Brain imaging shows dysgenesis of the corpus callosum and progressive cerebellar atrophy. Additional features may include genitourinary tract anomalies, hearing loss, and mild distal skeletal defects (summary by {1:Humbert et al., 2020}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Humbert et al. (2020)} reported 3 unrelated patients with a similar syndromic disorder identified through GeneMatcher after exome sequencing identified de novo heterozygous missense mutations in the KAT5 gene. The patients were 30 years, 13 years, and 2 years of age; none were born of consanguineous parents. Common features included severe global developmental delay with impaired intellectual development, poor or absent speech, behavioral abnormalities, and sleep disturbances. IQ, measured in 2 patients, ranged from 20 to 40. Behavioral features included perseverative language, disruptive behavior, attention deficit, hyperactivity, and stereotypies. The patients also had severe sleep anomalies, including early offset, nighttime awakenings, and daytime sleepiness. All patients developed seizures, although age at onset and seizure type varied. Two patients had mild hearing loss and 1 had hyperacusis. Craniofacial features, while variable, showed some overlap. The patients tended to have a small head with round face, flat facial profile, prognathism, almond-shaped eyes, strabismus, epicanthal folds, depressed nasal bridge, bulbous or upturned nose, low-set ears, downslanting corners of the mouth, and thick lower lip. One had a cleft lip and palate, and another had a high-arched palate. There were variable genitourinary anomalies, including recurrent urinary tract infections (patient 1), cryptorchidism, horseshoe kidney, and vesicoureteral reflux (patient 2), and hypospadias and cryptorchidism (patient 3). Additional variable features included myopia, hyperacusis, brachydactyly, single palmar crease, fifth finger clinodactyly, and feeding difficulties with dysphagia, gastroesophageal reflux, and constipation. Brain imaging showed nonspecific abnormalities: patient 1 had thin corpus callosum, patient 2 had progressive cerebellar atrophy, dysgenesis of the corpus callosum, and small anterior pituitary gland associated with growth hormone deficiency, and patient 3 had cerebellar atrophy and polymicrogyria of the right sylvian fissure.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies, sleep disturbance, and brain abnormalities', 'KAT5', ' HTATIP', ' TIP60', ' ESA1', ' PLIP', ' NEDFASB']

disease_des/def:
Moyamoya disease-7 (MYMY7) is a cerebrovascular disease that leads to strokes and neurologic deficits. The age at symptom onset is highly variable, ranging from childhood to adulthood. Brain imaging shows progressive occlusion and stenosis of the distal internal carotid arteries with collateral vessel formation. Intracranial aneurysms and involvement of the posterior circulation, including the basilar artery, may also be observed ({1:Pinard et al., 2023}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of moyamoya disease, see MYMY1 ({252350}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Pinard et al. (2023)} identified 11 patients from 7 unrelated families diagnosed with MYMY associated with heterozygous (6 families) or homozygous (1 family) variants in the ANO1 gene found through exome sequencing. Five patients came from 2 distantly related families (MM137 and MM001), and the remaining 6 were probands from unrelated families. The age at symptom onset was highly variable, ranging from 9 months to 50 years. Three individuals from family MM137/MM001 presented between 9 and 14 years of age with variable neurologic symptoms, including hemiparesis, poor school performance, obsessive-compulsive behavior, choreiform movements, migraine headaches, and transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). Brain imaging showed bilateral stenoocclusive lesions in the terminal internal carotid arteries, consistent with MYMY. The proband of family MM001, who had onset at age 9 and was in her late thirties at the time of the report, continued to have additional ischemic infarcts with progressive occlusion of the basilar artery and robust collateral vessel formation in the posterior circulation. Her mother presented at age 50 with a TIA and an occlusive lesion in the internal carotid artery; she also had a basilar artery aneurysm. In family 137, the proband and her affected brother presented with neurologic symptoms and intracerebral vascular anomalies on brain imaging at 9 and 14 years of age, respectively. Of note, their 39-year-old mother, who carried the mutation, had no symptoms or occlusive lesions, but showed multiple intracranial aneurysms on brain imaging. The maternal great-aunt of the proband in this family had onset of strokes at age 50; imaging showed diffuse stenosis of the internal carotid arteries and a basilar tip aneurysm that was coiled. Her father and sister reportedly died of intracranial aneurysms in their fifties. The patients from other families similarly had strokes and were confirmed to have MYMY on brain imaging. The proband in family Baylor 2 was diagnosed with MYMY at 6.5 years of age. He had a history of premature birth and intrauterine growth retardation. Other features included cutis marmorata, conductive hearing loss, nearsightedness, dysmorphic features, short stature, and microcephaly. Three other probands (MM035, MM117, and MM184) presented with strokes in their thirties or forties and were confirmed to have MMD on brain imaging. Proband MM153 was diagnosed with MYMY at 9 months of age; no further clinical details were available, but MM153 inherited the variant from her unaffected mother. Two sibs in family Baylor 1, born of consanguineous parents, presented in childhood with MMD; both also had obesity and acanthosis nigricans. The proband carried a homozygous ANO1 mutation; his similarly affected sister and unaffected parents did not have genetic testing.
disease_name+syn: ['Moyamoya disease 7', 'ANO1', ' TMEM16A', ' FLJ10261', ' INDMS', ' MYMY7']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{3:Martin et al. (2018)} reported 9 patients, 4 to 48 years of age, with intellectual developmental disorder from 7 nonconsanguineous families of European ancestry. All were homozygous for the same mutation in EIF3F (see MOLECULAR GENETICS). All patients were born at term with average growth parameters, and all had normal growth. There were no specific facial dysmorphic features and no structural brain abnormalities on MRI. Impaired intellectual development ranged from specific learning disability to severe ID. Six had seizures, one of these with infantile spasms. Three had sensorineural hearing loss. One of these patients also had bilateral cleft lip and palate.
