One other patient had anal stenosis, cryptorchidism, and small hands and feet. One patient had wasting of thenar and hypothenar eminences, which was noted because EIF3F had been shown to play a role in regulating skeletal muscle size via interaction with the mTOR ({601231}) pathway ({1:Csibi et al., 2010}).

Through GeneMatcher and internal communications, {2:Huffmeier et al. (2021)} collected 21 previously unreported patients from 16 families with MRT67 and mutation in the EIF3F gene. Global developmental delay was present in all patients. Hearing loss was found in 57% of patients, behavioral problems in 57%, muscular hypo- or hypertonia in 48%, short stature in 40%, microcephaly at the last physical examination in 32%, ophthalmologic findings in 38%, sleep issues in 24%, and epilepsy in 15%. Developmental regression was observed in 3 of 21 individuals at the age of 2.5 years (P11.1), 21 years (P4.1), and in adulthood (P14). Dysmorphic features were subtle and nonspecific.
disease_name+syn: ['Intellectual developmental disorder, autosomal recessive 67', 'EIF3F', ' EIF3S5', ' MRT67']

disease_des/def:
Mutation in the HCN2 gene can cause a spectrum of seizure disorders beginning in childhood or adolescence. Affected individuals may have simple febrile seizures or more complex afebrile seizures, including tonic-clonic, myoclonic, and photosensitive. Rare patients may have mild intellectual disability or behavioral problems (summary by {5:Li et al., 2018}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of idiopathic generalized epilepsy, see EIG ({600669}).

For a phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of familial febrile seizures, see FEB1 ({121210}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of GEFS+, see {604233}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{3:DiFrancesco et al. (2011)} reported a 28-year-old man who had onset of generalized epilepsy with absence and tonic-clonic seizures at age 12. There was no history of febrile seizures. EEG showed generalized sharp-wave complexes; brain imaging was normal. He had initial response to lamotrigine, but developed side effects. There was no family history of a seizure disorder.

{6:Nakamura et al. (2013)} reported 2 unrelated Japanese children with febrile seizures. One of the children had a similarly affected mother who had febrile seizures in childhood, consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance. Clinical details were limited.

{5:Li et al. (2018)} reported 7 patients from 3 unrelated families with various types of seizure disorders associated with mutations in the HCN2 gene. In 1 family, a woman and her daughter both had idiopathic photosensitive occipital lobe epilepsy, whereas the woman's son had febrile seizures. In a second family, 2 Italian brothers had early-onset absence seizures. One brother had onset of absence seizures at age 3 years, followed by generalized tonic-clonic seizures and spike-wave discharges on EEG in adolescence, whereas the other had absence seizures associated with photosensitivity. Three affected individuals in a third family were diagnosed with idiopathic photosensitive occipital lobe epilepsy, photosensitive generalized epilepsy, and an unclassified epilepsy, respectively. These patients had onset of myoclonic or focal seizures between 6 years and adolescence. EEG showed spike-wave discharges and centrotemporal spikes. One patient also had mild intellectual disability, and her affected sib had behavioral problems, mainly ADHD.
disease_name+syn: ['Febrile seizures, familial, 2', 'HCN2', ' BCNG2', ' GEFSP11', ' FEB2', ' EIG17']

disease_name: Immunodeficiency 71 with inflammatory disease and congenital thrombocytopenia
disease_des/def: Immunodeficiency-71 with inflammatory disease and congenital thrombocytopenia (IMD71) is an autosomal recessive immunologic disorder characterized by the onset of recurrent infections and inflammatory features such as vasculitis and eczema in infancy or early childhood. Infectious agents include bacteria and viruses. Laboratory findings are variable, but usually show thrombocytopenia, sometimes with abnormal platelet morphology, increased serum IgE, IgA, or IgM, leukocytosis, decreased or increased T lymphocytes, and increased eosinophils. Detailed studies show impaired neutrophil and T-cell chemotaxis, as well as impaired T-cell activation due to defects in F-actin (see {102610}) polymerization (summary by {1:Brigida et al., 2018}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{2:Kahr et al. (2017)} reported 3 patients from 2 unrelated families with a multisystem disorder characterized by platelet abnormalities, vasculitis, eosinophilia, and predisposition to inflammatory diseases. Patient 1, born of consanguineous parents of South Asian descent, had a more severe disorder, with recurrent infections beginning in early infancy, immunodeficiency, microthrombocytopenia, and a severe cutaneous papular nodular rash consistent with vasculitis and associated with deposition of IgG, IgM, and C3. Other features included inflammatory bowel disease with eosinophilic infiltration, cervical lymphadenopathy, and joint limitations progressing to bony erosions. He did not have opportunistic infections. Laboratory studies showed autoantibodies (positive antinuclear antibodies, ANA and ANCA), and bone marrow biopsy showed adequate megakaryocytes and increased eosinophils. At age 9 years, he was maintained on IV Ig infusions, immunosuppression, and prophylactic antibiotics; biochemical markers indicated increased inflammation. Patients 2 and 3, who were sibs, had a skin rash and normal platelet counts, but small platelets. One sib had leukocytoclastic vasculitis with deposition of IgM and C3 and was ANA and ANCA positive. He was treated with IV Ig and immunosuppression. His brother had an intermittent eczematous-like rash, 1 episode of pneumonia at 1 to 2 years of age, and asthma. He had persistently increased C-reactive protein and was positive for ANCA. Immunologic workup of all 3 patients showed eosinophilia, lymphocytosis, and increased numbers of circulating B cells with increased IgA and IgE; T-cell number and function appeared normal in all patients. Other findings included increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, suggestive of enhanced inflammation. All patients had failure to thrive early in life. Platelets derived from all 3 patients were small and dysmorphic compared to controls; dysmorphic features included odd shapes, collapse or loss of circumferential microtubule coils, and decreased dense granules. The findings were similar to those observed in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS; {301000}).

{3:Kuijpers et al. (2017)} reported a 7-year-old boy, born of consanguineous Moroccan parents, with IMD71. He presented at 2 months of age with gastric bleeding during a febrile period of gastroenteritis. Laboratory studies showed mild thrombocytopenia with normal platelet volume, normochromic anemia, and leukocytosis. He later developed recurrent infections, including staphylococcal auricular infection, gastrointestinal infection with Salmonella, and pneumonias resulting in mild bronchiectasis. The patient also had recurrent vasculitis with purpuric lesions on the arms, legs, and scrotum, poor wound healing, eczema, and nut allergy. Skin biopsy showed leukocytoclastic vasculitis with multiple microthrombi in the vascular lesions. Laboratory studies showed increased IgG, IgA, and eosinophilia that responded to treatment with corticosteroids. An autoantibody screen was negative.

{4:Somech et al. (2017)} reported 2 brothers, born of consanguineous Jewish parents, with a complex immunologic disorder. The patients presented in the first months of life with colitis, eczematous rash, and thrombocytopenia. Both patients developed recurrent infections, including abscesses, chest infections, pneumonitis, otitis media, and sepsis. Both died in childhood. Immunologic workup showed increased B lymphocytes, high IgG and IgE, reduced T cells, particularly CD8+ T cells, impaired T-cell response to anti-CD3 mitogen, and reduced thymic output with decreased TRECs.

{1:Brigida et al. (2018)} reported 6 unrelated patients, ranging from 3 to 24 years of age, with IMD71. Patient 3 had previously been reported by {6:Yan et al. (2005)}; he died at 24 years of age. The families were of various ethnic origins, including Italian, Canadian, Colombian, Moroccan, and Turkish; 4 families were consanguineous. The patients presented in the first months or years of life with severe eczema and recurrent bacterial and viral infections, including pneumonia, enterocolitis, panniculitis, meningitis, sepsis, oral thrush, and cutaneous warts. Organisms included Salmonella, Pseudomonas, rare Staphylococcus, Actinomyces, HPV, and CMV. Most patients also had evidence of autoinflammation, including leukocytoclastic vasculitis, recurrent fevers, inflammatory colitis with gastrointestinal bleeding, hematochezia, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The patients had poor overall growth. Laboratory findings were somewhat variable, but commonly included thrombocytopenia, chronic anemia, T-cell lymphopenia, and eosinophilia. Some platelets had abnormal morphology, but aggregation and spreading were normal. Two patients underwent successful hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

{5:Thaventhiran et al. (2020)} reported a 27-year-old woman with IMD71 who presented with HPV-associated cervical and vulval intraepithelial dysplasia grade 3. She had a history of atopic dermatitis with recurrent staphylococcal skin infections, bacterial pneumonia, and hepatic abscesses. Laboratory studies showed increased IgE and thrombocytopenia. She developed an anaplastic large cell lymphoma and died from complications following chemotherapy. The patient had 2 older sibs who died in infancy of unknown causes.
disease_name+syn: ['Immunodeficiency 71 with inflammatory disease and congenital thrombocytopenia', 'ARPC1B', ' ARC41', ' IMD71']

disease_name: Progressive external ophthalmoplegia with mitochondrial DNA deletions, autosomal recessive 6
disease_des/def:
Autosomal recessive progressive external ophthalmoplegia-6 (PEOB6) is characterized by ptosis and ophthalmoplegia as well as other clinical manifestations and multiple mtDNA deletions in muscle ({1:Shintaku et al., 2022}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of autosomal recessive PEO, see PEOB1 ({258450}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Shintaku et al. (2022)} described clinical features in 4 patients from 3 families with autosomal recessive progressive external ophthalmoplegia and mutation in the RRM1 gene. Age of onset of symptoms ranged from 7 to 61 years. In the patient with the youngest age of onset, the first symptom was nausea and vomiting. The first symptoms in the other patients included difficulty swallowing, double vision, or ptosis. All 4 patients developed ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and myopathy. Gastrointestinal symptoms included dysphagia in 2 patients, nausea and vomiting in 2 patients, intestinal dysmotility in 2 patients, and gastroparesis in 1 patient. Three patients had difficulty with ambulation, 2 patients had facial weakness, 3 patients had limb weakness, and 2 patients had cachexia. None of the patients had cognitive dysfunction, and 1 patient had absent reflexes and a sensorimotor neuropathy. Laboratory abnormalities included elevated AST and ALT in 1 patient and elevated creatine kinase in 1 patient.
disease_name+syn: ['Progressive external ophthalmoplegia with mitochondrial DNA deletions, autosomal recessive 6', 'RRM1', ' PEOB6']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Mayatepek and Flock (1998)} described the inability to synthesize LTC4, thought to be due to a primary deficiency of LTC4 synthase (LTC4S; {246530}), in an infant with a fatal developmental syndrome. The infant presented with muscular hypotonia, psychomotor retardation, failure to thrive, and microcephaly. The course of the disease was rapidly progressive and the infant died at the age of 6 months. The patient was the daughter of consanguineous Turkish parents.

{2:Mayatepek et al. (2000)} reported another patient with LTC4S deficiency, a girl born at 33 weeks' gestation to consanguineous Italian parents. She had generalized muscular hypotonia with lack of facial expression from the first day of life. After the first week of life, she developed symmetric extension in the lower extremities, including stretching of the trunk musculature. During the course of the disease, severe muscular hypotonia and failure to thrive with tendency to microcephaly became rapidly progressive. There were no pyramidal tract signs, and deep tendon reflexes were not present. She had no psychomotor development and there was no visual contact at any time. It was impossible to extubate the patient, and the infant died at 6 months of age.
disease_name+syn: ['Leukotriene C4 synthase deficiency', 'LTC4S']

disease_des/def:
Lissencephaly-7 with cerebellar hypoplasia (LIS7) is a severe neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by lack of psychomotor development, facial dysmorphism, arthrogryposis, and early-onset intractable seizures resulting in death in infancy ({2:Magen et al., 2015}).

For a general description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of lissencephaly, see LIS1 ({607432}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {2:Magen et al. (2015)} reported a large, highly consanguineous kindred of Israeli Muslim descent in which 10 infants had a lethal form of lissencephaly. Patients presented at birth with abnormal features, including small head size, short forehead, low hairline, full cheeks, downslanting corners of the mouth, micrognathia, hirsutism, lymphedema, arthrogryposis multiplex, and clenched hands. Affected newborns had shallow breathing, head lag, absent reflexes, reduced responses to pain, and intractable seizures associated with burst-suppression pattern on EEG. All died from respiratory failure between 2 days and 3 months of age. Brain imaging showed extreme lissencephaly with complete agyria, cerebellar hypoplasia, and agenesis of the corpus callosum. Skeletal muscle biopsies of 2 patients showed nonspecific myopathic changes, such as small round skeletal muscle fibers with centralized nuclei. Neuropathologic examination of 1 patient showed smooth brain surface and severely disordered cortical lamination.
disease_name+syn: ['Lissencephaly 7 with cerebellar hypoplasia', 'CDK5', ' LIS7']

disease_name: Hypermetabolism due to uncoupled mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation 2
disease_des/def:
Hypermetabolism due to uncoupled mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation-2 (HUMOP2) is characterized by failure to thrive apparent in infancy despite adequate caloric intake. Affected individuals show normal thyroid function, hyperphagia, tachypnea, increased basal temperature, and increased sweating. Biochemical studies demonstrate increased mitochondrial oxygen consumption with inefficient production of ATP in the final steps of oxidative phosphorylation due to an uncoupling defect ({1:Ganetzky et al., 2022}).

<Subhead> Genetic Heterogeneity of Hypermetabolism due to Uncoupled Mitochondrial Oxidative Phosphorylation

See also HUMOP1 ({238800}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Ganetzky et al. (2022)} reported a pair of 22-month-old monozygotic twin boys, born of unrelated parents of Ashkenazi Jewish descent, who presented around 2 months of age with a euthyroid hypermetabolic state. They had intrauterine growth retardation and were born at 34 weeks' gestation. As infants, they demonstrated failure to thrive despite caloric intake in excess of the calculated need. They showed hyperphagia without proper weight gain, persistent tachypnea, and recurrent episodes of hyperthermia with persistent diaphoresis and tactile warmth. Laboratory studies showed elevated branched-chain amino acids, mild hyperammonemia and uremia, and elevated triglyceride levels, which were interpreted to reflect high protein catabolism rates and mobilization of fatty acids for catabolism. Both twins showed mild global developmental delay with poor fine and gross motor skills and speech delay.
disease_name+syn: ['Hypermetabolism due to uncoupled mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation 2', 'ATP5B', ' ATPSB', ' HUMOP2']

disease_des/def:
Spermatogenic failure-21 (SPGF21) is characterized by acephalic spermatozoa causing male infertility ({1:Li et al., 2017}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of spermatogenic failure, see SPGF1 ({258150}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Li et al. (2017)} studied a Chinese man with infertility who had 99.5% acephalic spermatozoa, with reduced sperm density (7.6 million/mL) and motility (0.5%). The acephalic spermatozoa did not contain any mitochondria by electron microscopy. Hormone levels were normal. The proband's parents were first cousins, and he had an older brother who was married with 1 child.
disease_name+syn: ['Spermatogenic failure 21', 'BRDT', ' SPGF21']

disease_des/def: Immunodeficiency-109 with EBV-induced lymphoproliferation (IMD109) is an autosomal recessive primary immune disorder characterized by onset of recurrent sinopulmonary infections in childhood. Affected individuals are susceptible to infection with EBV and develop EBV viremia and EBV-associated lymphoproliferative disease or B-cell lymphoma. Immunologic work-up shows normal levels of T, B, and NK cells, with defective CD8+ T cell function after stimulation. Some patients may have hypogammaglobulinemia and poor antibody response to stimulation ({1:Alosaimi et al., 2019}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Alosaimi et al. (2019)} reported 2 unrelated children, both born of consanguineous Saudi parents, with immunodeficiency and EBV-induced lymphoproliferation. The patients presented in the first years of life with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, generalized lymphadenopathy, and EBV viremia. Patient 1 was a 5-year-old girl with normal T, B, and NK cells, hypogammaglobulinemia, and poor antibody responses to vaccination. Treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin (IV Ig) reduced the frequency of infections. She developed hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) and was treated with anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies, resulting in resolution of her viremia. After this treatment, immunologic work-up showed increased effector memory T cells, undetectable B cells, decreased T-cell proliferative responses, and decreased gamma-IFN ({147570}) secretion. She was undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation from an HLA-matched sister at the time of the report. Patient 2 was a 6-year-old boy with increased serum IgG and IgA and low IgM who was diagnosed with EBV-positive Hodgkin disease and successfully treated with chemotherapy. Subsequently, he was found to have decreased numbers of T cells with increased effector memory T cells, undetectable B cells, and reduced T-cell proliferation and IFN-gamma secretion when stimulated compared to normal controls. He relapsed with recurrence of a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma that was positive for EBV.
disease_name+syn: ['Immunodeficiency 109 with lymphoproliferation', 'TNFRSF9', ' ILA', ' CD137', ' IMD109']

disease_des/def: Hypotaurinemic retinal degeneration and cardiomyopathy (HTRDC) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by low plasma taurine, childhood-onset progressive retinal degeneration, and cardiomyopathy ({1:Ansar et al., 2020}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Ansar et al. (2020)} described a brother and sister, aged 15 and 6 years, respectively, with retinal dystrophy and cardiomyopathy. The brother had advanced macular atrophy with peripheral atrophy and pseudoosteoblast formation. There was no retinal response on an electroretinogram (ERG), and optical coherence tomography (OCT) showed extensive loss of photoreceptors. His sister had foveal-sparing macular atrophy and salt-and-pepper fundus pigmentation. OCT showed atrophy of photoreceptors, and global ERG showed no response. Echocardiograms in both sibs showed mild hypokinetic cardiomyopathy with systolic dysfunction. Plasma amino acids showed very low levels of taurine.

{4:Preising et al. (2019)} described 2 brothers, aged 4 and 11 years, with early-onset retinal degeneration with progressive loss of rod and cone photoreceptor cells. Both sibs had low serum taurine, normal urine taurine, and increased urine excretion of 8-oxo-7,8-dihydroguanosine, reflective of oxidative stress. The older sib also had pendular nystagmus from birth and blue color vision reduction. The younger sib also had congenital nystagmus and hyposmia.
disease_name+syn: ['Hypotaurinemic retinal degeneration and cardiomyopathy', 'SLC6A6', ' TAUT', ' HTRDC']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Alkufri et al. (2016)} reported 4 sisters, born of consanguineous Palestinian parents, with a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by delayed psychomotor development apparent in infancy, poor speech, and onset of abnormal involuntary movements around 8 to 9 years of age. The movement initially appeared on the face around the oral area, but later spread to involve the hand, fingers, and thighs. Physical examination showed insuppressible choreiform movement. All patients had learning disabilities and moderate intellectual disability with dyscalculia (IQ of 40 in 1 patient). Brain imaging of the oldest patient at age 14 years showed no abnormalities.
disease_name+syn: ['Chorea, childhood-onset, with psychomotor retardation', 'GPR88', ' STRG', ' COCPMR']

disease_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with microcephaly, cataracts, and renal abnormalities
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Alazami et al. (2015)} described 3 unrelated children (08DG00485, 10DG0703, and 13DG1542), each born of consanguineous parents, with a complex and severe neurodevelopmental disorder. The patients had global developmental delay since infancy, microcephaly, poor or absent speech, and inability to walk or spasticity. Additional common features included congenital cataracts, gastroesophageal reflux disease, seizures with onset in infancy or childhood, hyporeflexia, and nonspecific white matter abnormalities on brain imaging, possibly reflecting disturbed myelination. All patients had variable renal involvement, including hydronephrosis, renal stones, nephrocalcinosis, small kidneys, tubulopathy, and secondary hypertension. All patients had a family history of relatives with a similar disorder, many of whom died in childhood.

{3:Patel et al. (2017)} reported 2 patients with global developmental delay and congenital cataract who had mutations in the GEMIN4 gene. Additional features in the first patient (11DG2480) included severe failure to thrive, microcephaly, strabismus, abnormal pupillary light reflex, mild epiphyseal dysplasia, central hypotonia with appendicular hypertonia, spasticity, brisk reflexes, seizures, and nephrocalcinosis. Dysmorphic features included synophrys, long nose, and overlapping toes. Brain imaging showed atrophy, hypomyelination, and callosal thinning. The second patient (14DG2265) was reported to have ataxia in addition to developmental delay and cataract.

{2:Maddirevula et al. (2019)} reported a 7-year-old girl (17-3434), born of consanguineous parents, who had global developmental delay, cataract, and hearing loss. She sat without support at 12 months of age, and walked at 2 years. Speech was significantly delayed and she spoke only with difficulty. She had a history of seizures that responded to medication. Brain MRI showed a small atrophic cerebellum, with prominence of the posterior fossa cerebrospinal fluid spaces. There were 2 similarly affected sibs, with variable severity.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodevelopmental disorder with microcephaly, cataracts, and renal abnormalities', 'GEMIN4', ' NEDMCR']

disease_des/def:
Diaphragmatic hernia-4 with cardiovascular defects (DIH4) is an autosomal recessive congenital anomaly syndrome characterized by the presence of diaphragmatic hernia or eventration apparent at birth. Affected infants have associated pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory insufficiency resulting in death in infancy. Most also have variable cardiovascular defects, including aortopulmonary window or conotruncal anomalies. Dysmorphic facial features and mild distal limb anomalies are sometimes observed ({1:Beecroft et al., 2021}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), see DIH1 ({142340}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Beecroft et al. (2021)} reported an Australian family (AUS1) in which 2 male infants died soon after birth due to severe respiratory distress associated with diaphragmatic eventration and pulmonary hypoplasia. Both pregnancies were complicated by polyhydramnios and the infants were born at 34 and 33 weeks' gestation, respectively. One infant had pulmonary hypertension, an aortopulmonary window, and dysmorphic features including large head, micrognathia, low-set ears, widely spaced nipples, syndactyly, and cryptorchidism; he died on day 19. The other infant had an aortopulmonary window, absent thymus, mild anomalies of the hands and feet (clinodactyly, syndactyly), large head, downslanting palpebral fissures, and micrognathia; he died 1.5 hours after birth. In this family, prenatal ultrasound of a subsequent pregnancy at 12 weeks' gestational age showed cystic hygroma, and the pregnancy was terminated. The fetus carried the pathogenic mutations identified in the other 2 infants with the disorder. A female infant from an unrelated Italian family (ITA1) with a similar disorder was identified through MatchMaker Exchange. She had congenital diaphragmatic hernia and complex cardiac defects, including hypoplasia of the pulmonary arteries, aortopulmonary collateral arteries, ventricular septal defect, and ectasia of the aortic root. Dysmorphic features included micrognathia, bulbous nose, and clubfeet. She died of respiratory failure at 3 months of age.
disease_name+syn: ['Diaphragmatic hernia 4, with cardiovascular defects', 'ALDH1A2', ' RALDH2', ' DIH4']

disease_des/def: Chilton-Okur-Chung neurodevelopmental syndrome (CHOCNS) is characterized mainly by global developmental delay with variably impaired intellectual development and occasional speech delay. Most patients have behavioral abnormalities, including autism spectrum disorder, ADHD, and aggression. About half of patients have dysmorphic facial features, and about half have nonspecific brain abnormalities, including thin corpus callosum. Rare involvement of other organ systems may be present. At least 1 child with normal development at age 2.5 years has been reported ({1:Chilton et al., 2020}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Chilton et al. (2020)} reported 14 unrelated patients, ranging in age from 2 to 29 years, who were ascertained through the GeneMatcher Program after exome sequencing identified de novo heterozygous mutations in the CDC42BPB gene. One patient (individual 4) was a male fetus with cystic hygroma and progressive ventriculomegaly found on prenatal ultrasound; the pregnancy was terminated at 27 weeks' gestation. All except 1 (individual 8) of the other 13 patients had global developmental delay, often with impaired intellectual development, speech delay, and behavioral abnormalities, including ADHD, aggressive behavior, anxiety, and repetitive or stereotypic movements. Eight were diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder, including a 14-year-old boy with Asperger syndrome (individual 2). Several patients had hypotonia or unsteady gait, 3 had seizures, and 1 had EEG abnormalities. One of the patients with seizures (individual 7) was unable to walk at age 12 years and had severe speech delay with only a few words. Four patients had ophthalmologic findings, including ptosis, strabismus, esotropia, amblyopia, refractory errors, and septooptic dysplasia with optic atrophy (1 patient). Brain imaging showed nonspecific abnormalities in 4 patients, including cerebellar hypoplasia, thin or absent corpus callosum, white matter loss, and enlarged ventricles. Brain imaging was normal in other patients tested. About half of individuals had dysmorphic facial features, including macrocephaly, abnormal head shape, broad or high forehead, sparse scalp hair, sparse eyebrows, low-set ears, up- or downslanting palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, high nasal root, flat nasal bridge, broad nasal tip, short philtrum, large mouth, thin upper lip, and widely spaced teeth. A few had distal skeletal anomalies of the hands and feet or pectus abnormalities. Less common features included cryptorchidism, constipation, recurrent otitis media, micropenis, kidney abnormalities, and joint hypermobility. Rare features observed in a single patient each included acquired microcephaly, congenital diaphragmatic hernia with intestinal malrotation, patent foramen ovale, patent ductus arteriosus, and scoliosis.
disease_name+syn: ['Chilton-Okur-Chung neurodevelopmental syndrome', 'CDC42BPB', ' MRCKB', ' CHOCNS']

disease_des/def: The plasma level of vitamin B12 is a modifiable quantitative trait associated with many diseases ({1:Hazra et al., 2008}). Vitamin B12 found in meat and milk products is composed of corrin and cobalt rings and is necessary for the formation of red blood cells, DNA synthesis during cell division, and maintenance of the myelin nerve sheath, among other functions. Deficiency in vitamin B12, clinically associated with pernicious anemia, cardiovascular disease, cancer, and neurodegenerative disorders, is often related to poor intestinal B12 absorption rather than direct dietary deficiency.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: In the Nurses' Health Study, {2:Kang et al. (2006)} observed that women in the lowest quartile of plasma vitamin B12 levels had marginally worse cognitive performance (based on a global score averaging 6 cognitive tests) than women in the highest quartile, and that combined folate and vitamin B12 deficiency was associated with the lowest cognitive performance.
disease_name+syn: ['Vitamin B12 plasma level QTL1', 'FUT2', ' SE', ' B12QTL1']

disease_des/def:
Oculomotor-abducens synkinesis (OCABSN) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a specific anomaly of extraocular muscle movements involving the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) and the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI). The superior branch of CN3 innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which raises the eyelid, and CN6 innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which controls lateral eye movement. Affected individuals show ptosis as well as elevation of the eyelid on ipsilateral abduction. The features indicate abnormal innervation of these muscles and suggest synkinesis of the oculomotor and abducens nerves. The disorder can be classified as a congenital cranial dysinnervation disorder (CCDD), and also shows features of congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles (CFEOM; see {135700}) (summary by {1:Khan et al., 2004} and {3:Whitman et al., 2019}).

See also oculomotor-levator synkinesis (OCLEVS; {151610}), a similar disorder.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Khan et al. (2004)} reported a large consanguineous Arab kindred in which 2 sibs had ptosis and abnormal synkinetic lid elevation associated with ipsilateral abduction. One was bilaterally affected and the other had unilateral findings. A third sib had isolated bilateral congenital ptosis. Another relative had unilateral classic Duane syndrome type 1 (see {126800}), which is aplasia of the abducens CN6 with aberrant innervation of the lateral rectus by CN3. The different phenotypes exhibited by affected members of the same family could be explained by developmental cranial nerve dysinnervation.

{3:Whitman et al. (2019)} provided follow-up of the family reported by {1:Khan et al. (2004)}, which included 3 affected sibs. One patient had bilateral congenital ptosis without apparent synkinesis, another had bilateral ptosis with elevation of the eyelid on ipsilateral abduction, and the third had left congenital ptosis, ipsilateral lid elevation on abduction, and slight limitation of adduction and globe retraction with adduction. A previously unreported cousin exhibited right congenital ptosis with ipsilateral lid elevation on abduction. The ptosis and synkinesis in these individuals was most consistent with failure of innervation of the levator palpebrae superioris by CN3 and its aberrant innervation by CN6. A half-sister of the 3 affected sibs had right-sided Duane syndrome with limitation of abduction, mild limitation of adduction, and globe retraction with upshoot of the right eye on attempted adduction. The authors noted that mouse models of Duane syndrome have revealed that this pattern of synkinesis results from absence of CN6 and aberrant innervation of the lateral rectus by axons of CN3 ({2:Park et al., 2016}).
disease_name+syn: ['Oculomotor-abducens synkinesis', 'ACKR3', ' CXCR7', ' CMKOR1', ' GPR159', ' RDC1']

disease_des/def: The Indian blood group comprises 2 antigens, In(a) and In(b). Most individuals express the In(b) antigen ({2:Giles, 1975}). The rare event of In(a) homozygosity is associated with production of alloantibody to In(b) after transfusion or pregnancy ({4:Telen et al., 1996}). The In(a+b-) phenotype is most common in Middle Eastern and South Asian populations ({1:Badakere et al., 1974}).
disease_name+syn: ['Blood group, Indian system', 'CD44', ' MDU2', ' MDU3', ' MIC4', ' IN']

disease_des/def: Ichthyosis with erythrokeratoderma (IEKD) is an autosomal dominant disorder of cornification characterized by abnormal desquamation in addition to erythematous hyperkeratotic plaques or patches. Lesions are present at birth or appear soon after ({1:Gong et al., 2023}; {2:Takeichi et al., 2023}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Gong et al. (2023)} reported 5 patients from a 3-generation Han Chinese family (Fam1) as well as 2 sporadic Han Chinese patients (individuals 2 and 3) with ichthyosiform erythroderma or erythrokeratoderma and mutation in the KLK11 gene. All affected individuals in Fam1 developed reddish, scaly plaques or erythroderma soon after birth, with marked variation in severity. An affected mother and son presented with ichthyosiform erythroderma, whereas lesions in the mother's 2 affected brothers were sparse and patchy. Individual 2 was a 4-year-old boy who presented with erythematous lesions 2 weeks after birth, who also had whitish polygonal scales on his face and extremities, with the knees, hands, and feet being the most prominently affected. Erythematous hyperkeratotic lesions coalesced into confluent plaques on his torso. Individual 3, a 23-year-old man, showed patchy erythrokeratoderma of the scalp and extremities at 3 months after birth. The lesions progressed with age, predominating on the upper back and extensor aspects of the limbs, with perifollicular keratosis on the extremities. All of the patients reported an exacerbation of the lesions during cold and dry weather with mild to moderate pruritus. None of them reported any history of collodion membrane at birth, atopic manifestations, or skin blistering, and no extracutaneous abnormalities were recorded. Histopathology of skin biopsies from the proband in Fam1 showed hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and marked acanthosis with mild perivascular infiltration of monocytes in the superficial dermis. Notably, a thickened, dense, and compact stratum corneum (SC) was observed. Ultrastructural analysis by transmission electron microscopy of skin specimens from the proband and his mother showed entombed lamellar bodies in the SC layer and bubble-like inclusions at the stratum granulosum (SG)-SC interface. Increased corneodesmosomes were also noted in the thickened upper SC of the patients, and expression of DSG1 ({125670}) was increased compared to that of control SC, indicating delayed degradation of corneodesmosomes and their constituent proteins in patient SC. The authors concluded that abnormal skin desquamation and disturbed secretion of lamellar bodies caused secondary epidermal hyperkeratosis and superficial dermal inflammation, manifesting as erythroderma or erythrokeratoderma in the patients.

{2:Takeichi et al. (2023)} reported a 7-year-old Japanese boy who was born with focal palmoplantar hyperkeratosis, and developed scaling and peeling by 1 month of age. On examination at age 7 years, he had whitish to light brown scales with mild erythema on his trunk and extremities. A large hyperkeratotic plaque with light brown pigmentation and distinct margins was present on his abdomen. There was mild diffuse palmoplantar keratoderma, and he had mild leukonychia and pitting of the toenails. Skin biopsy from the hyperkeratotic area of the abdomen showed a compact stratum corneum and preserved granular layer, without epidermolytic changes or parakeratosis. The authors noted elevated SCCA2 (SERPINB4; {600518}) and TARC (CCL17; {601520}) levels, indicating activated type 2 inflammation. The authors designated the phenotype in this patient to be ichthyosiform erythroderma.
disease_name+syn: ['Ichthyosis with erythrokeratoderma', 'KLK11', ' PRSS20', ' TLSP', ' IEKD']

disease_des/def:
Combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency-55 (COXPD55) is characterized by global developmental delay, hypotonia, short stature, and impaired intellectual development with speech disabilities in childhood. Indolent progressive external ophthalmoplegia phenotype has been described in 1 patient (summary by {2:Olahova et al., 2021}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency, see COXPD1 ({609060}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Bowden et al. (2013)} described a 10-year-old girl who presented at 1 year of age with genu valgum and laboratory findings of low serum phosphorus, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and elevated parathyroid hormone. She was treated with ergocalciferol without improvement. Laboratory testing at 3 years of age was consistent with a proximal tubulopathy or a renal Fanconi syndrome. On evaluation at age 5 years, she had mild developmental delay and hypotonia. Laboratory testing showed generalized aminoaciduria, elevated urine lactate, and elevated plasma alanine and proline. Respiratory chain analysis in muscle tissue demonstrated deficient activity of complexes I and III. Brain MRI showed thinning of the corpus callosum. Treatment with elemental phosphorus, calcitriol, and sodium citrate resulted in improvement of genu valgum and a normal growth rate.

{2:Olahova et al. (2021)} described clinical features in 8 patients, including 1 sib pair and the patient (patient 1) previously described by {1:Bowden et al. (2013)}. Five of the patients presented in infancy or childhood and 3 patients presented in adulthood. Five patients had developmental delay, 6 had hypotonia, 1 had seizures, and 4 had brain MRI abnormalities including thinning of the corpus callosum in 1, nonspecific FLAIR hyperintense lesions in the frontoparietal white matter in 1, ventriculomegaly in 1, and cavum septum pellucidum in 1. Eye findings included movement abnormalities in 4 patients, ptosis in 2, and vision problems in 3. Skeletal findings included short stature in 4 patients and hypophosphatemic rickets in 1. Muscle symptoms included facial muscle weakness/wasting in 2 patients, neck wasting/weakness in 1, and limb-girdle myopathy in 3.
disease_name+syn: ['Combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency 55', 'POLRMT', ' APOLMT', ' COXPD55']

disease_des/def:
Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy-82 (DEE82) is an autosomal recessive mitochondriopathy manifest as early-onset metabolic epileptic encephalopathy. Soon after birth, affected individuals exhibit hypotonia, feeding difficulties, and global developmental delay even before the onset of seizures in the first year of life. The severity is variable, but all patients have severely impaired intellectual development with absent speech and spastic tetraplegia. Other features include poor overall growth with microcephaly and recurrent infections. Brain imaging shows cerebral atrophy, thin corpus callosum, cerebellar hypoplasia, and white matter abnormalities. Laboratory studies show increased serum lactate and ammonia. Importantly, treatment with combined pyridoxine and serine can result in significant improvement in seizures as well as some mild developmental progress (summary by {1:van Karnebeek et al., 2019}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of DEE, see {308350}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Van Karnebeek et al. (2019)} reported 4 children, ranging in age from 4 to 10 years, from 3 unrelated families with DEE82. Two families were consanguineous and of Egyptian descent, and 1 family was Romanian. The patients presented soon after birth or in the first months of life with feeding difficulties, respiratory insufficiency, drooling, hypotonia, and developmental delay. Patient 1 had abdominal spasms and disturbed sleep. All developed severe and frequent seizures between 4 and 9 months of age. Seizure types included febrile, afebrile, myoclonic, tonic, and generalized tonic-clonic; the seizures were refractory in patients 1 and 4, but could be controlled with antiepileptic medication in patients 2 and 3, who were sisters. The patients had failure to thrive with poor overall growth and progressive microcephaly, and frequent infections. They had severely impaired psychomotor development with profoundly impaired intellectual development, absent speech, and spastic para- or quadriplegia with brisk reflexes. Only 1 patient could walk short distances with support; the other 3 patients were wheelchair-bound. More variable features included nystagmus and scoliosis, and the sisters had acrocyanosis and chilblains in winter. Laboratory investigations showed increased serum lactate and ammonia in all patients; patient 1 also had decreased serine and increased citrulline. Urinary organic acids and acylcarnitines were unremarkable. Brain imaging showed cerebral atrophy and white matter abnormalities in all patients; other findings were enlarged ventricles, thin corpus callosum, and cerebellar vermis atrophy. Patient 1 also had periventricular leukomalacia and multicystic encephalomalacia. Each family had another affected fetus or child who died of the disorder. Treatment with pyridoxine and serine resulted in clinical improvement and amelioration of the seizure frequency (see CLINICAL MANAGEMENT).
disease_name+syn: ['Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 82', 'GOT2', ' DEE82']

disease_des/def: Breast cancer (referring to mammary carcinoma, not mammary sarcoma) is histopathologically and almost certainly etiologically and genetically heterogeneous. Important genetic factors have been indicated by familial occurrence and bilateral involvement.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{21:Cady (1970)} described a family in which 3 sisters had bilateral breast cancer. Together with reports in the literature, this suggested to him the existence of families with a particular tendency to early-onset, bilateral breast cancer. The genetic basis might, of course, be multifactorial.

{5:Anderson (1974)} concluded that the sisters of women with breast cancer whose mothers also had breast cancer have a risk 47 to 51 times that in control women; a revised estimate was 39 times ({6:Anderson, 1976}). The disease in these women usually developed before menopause, was often bilateral, and seemed to be associated with ovarian function. About 30% of daughters with early-onset, bilateral breast cancer inherited the susceptibility. The risk of breast cancer to women with affected relatives is higher when the diagnosis is made at an early age and when the disease is bilateral. {108:Ottman et al. (1983)} provided tables that give the cumulative risk of breast cancer to mothers and sisters at various ages. The highest risk group is sisters of premenstrual probands with bilateral disease. Among the sisters of women with breast cancer, {3:Anderson and Badzioch (1985)} found the highest lifetime risks when the proband had bilateral disease, an affected mother (25 +/- 7.2%), or an affected sister (28 +/- 11%). The risks were reduced to 18 +/- 3.3% and 14 +/- 2.6%, respectively, with unilateral disease. An early example of familial breast cancer was provided by {17:Broca (1866)}. According to the pedigree drawn by {86:Lynch (1976)}, 10 women in 4 generations of the family of Broca's wife died of breast cancer. {39:Eisinger et al. (1998)} called attention to an even earlier report of hereditary breast cancer by {79:Le Dran (1757)}, who related the experience of a colleague in Avignon who had diagnosed a 19-year-old nun with cancer of the right breast. The patient refused a mastectomy not only because of the pain of surgery, but also because of a belief that the operation would be futile. Her grandmother and a grandmaternal uncle died with breast cancer, and she was convinced that this malady was hereditary and that 'her blood was corrupted by a cancerous ferment natural to her family.'

Two families with an extraordinary incidence of male breast cancer and father-to-son transmission of same was reported by {41:Everson et al. (1976)}. They found a suggestion of elevated urinary estrogen in 3 of the affected males. {138:Teasdale et al. (1976)} described breast cancer in 2 brothers and in a daughter of 1 brother. {74:Kozak et al. (1986)} reported breast cancer in 2 related males, an uncle and nephew. In this family and in several reported families with male breast cancer, {74:Kozak et al. (1986)} found women in the same family with breast cancer.

Soft tissue sarcomas are associated with breast cancer in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. {101:Mulvihill (1982)} used the term cancer family syndrome of Lynch ({120435}) for the association of colon and endometrial carcinoma and other neoplasms including breast cancer.

{127:Seltzer et al. (1990)} concluded that dermatoglyphics can help in the identification of women either with or at risk for breast cancer. They found that the presence of 6 or more whorls is associated in a statistically significant manner with breast cancer.

{90:Marger et al. (1975)} presented the cases of 2 brothers with breast cancer and reviewed the courses of 28 other previously unreported male patients. In one of the brothers, breast cancer was preceded by prostate cancer and estrogen administration, raising the possibility that the breast cancer was a metastatic deposit. The possibility of prostatic metastases was raised in 2 other patients. {36:Demeter et al. (1990)} reported breast cancer in a 64-year-old man who had had bilateral gynecomastia since childhood. His maternal grandfather had been found to have adenocarcinoma of the breast at the age of 65. His maternal grandmother had radical mastectomy for breast cancer at the age of 66 and 2 years later underwent radiation therapy for rib metastases. The proband's sister developed breast cancer at the age of 31 years and despite aggressive therapy died 1 year later with extensive metastases.

{56:Hauser et al. (1992)} reported a family in which 2 females and 2 males in 2 generations had breast cancer. Two females in the family had prophylactic bilateral mastectomy at a young age. One male developed a left breast mass and axillary node at age 59 and died of metastatic disease at age 62. His paternal uncle presented at age 57 years with bleeding from his right breast. Biopsy suggested Paget disease of the breast and he underwent mastectomy. He subsequently died at age 75 years of prostatic carcinoma. He had a daughter who developed breast cancer at age 27 years and died at age 30 with disseminated disease, and a son who developed infiltrating grade 4 adenocarcinoma of the breast at age 54.
disease_name+syn: ['Breast cancer, lobular, somatic', 'CDH1', ' UVO', ' LCAM', ' ECAD', ' BCDS1']

disease_des/def: Congenital pancreatic lipase deficiency is a rare, monoenzymatic form of exocrine pancreatic failure. All reported patients have presented with similar symptoms and clinical findings, including oily/greasy stools from infancy or early childhood and the absence of discernible pancreatic disease. Failure to thrive has not been observed. Analyses of duodenal contents consistently show a marked decrease of pancreatic lipolytic activity (summary by {4:Figarella et al., 1980}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{12:Sheldon (1964)} reported 4 children, a brother and sister and 2 brothers, from 2 unrelated nonconsanguineous families, who had congenital pancreatic lipase deficiency. From early infancy, all 4 were noted to have a greasy quality to their stools, with liquid oil separating from the stool and solidifying as the stool cooled. At an age when most children were gaining control of their bowel movements, these children were handicapped by soiling their clothes with liquid oil that they were unable to restrain. Analysis of duodenal fluid in the children showed total absence of pancreatic lipase in 1 boy and less than half the normal amount in the other 3 children. {12:Sheldon (1964)} stated that the disorder could be distinguished from other causes of steatorrhea such as fibrocystic disease of the pancreas and celiac disease due to satisfactory growth, lack of abdominal distention, and lack of respiratory infections leading to lung damage. The author also noted that despite greatly decreased production of pancreatic lipase, fat absorption in the 3 children in whom it was analyzed was approximately 70%, suggesting action of lipase derived from the stomach and intestine. Treatment with lipase given as pancreatin improved fat absorption, although not to normal levels, and brought the oily condition of the stools and soiling under control; dietary control of fat intake, however, remained necessary, with any excess intake leading to a return of oil in the stools and soiling.

{11:Rey et al. (1966)} reported a 10-year-old boy who at 3 years of age developed episodes of abundant, greasy diarrhea that coincided with asthmatic attacks. By 5 years of age, his stools were consistently greasy and voluminous, occurring once or twice a day with excessive oil that separated out, and despite being continent, his clothes were stained with oil seepage. A sweat chloride test was within normal limits, and analysis of duodenal fluid showed normal secretion of bicarbonates, slightly decreased trypsin (see {276000}) and amylase (see {104650}) activity, and virtually absent lipase activity. Absorption of sugars was normal, and a barium study of the small intestine and jejunal and pancreatic biopsies were all normal. The fat in his stools decreased by 50% when pancreatic extract was added to his diet, but increased immediately to previous levels when the treatment was stopped. {11:Rey et al. (1966)} noted that the delayed onset in this patient was suggestive of an acquired disorder, but the persistent absence of pancreatic lipase at 8 years of age showed similarity to the 4 patients described by {12:Sheldon (1964)}.

{1:Balzer (1967)} studied an 8-year-old girl who had abundant fatty stools from around 1 year of age, which did not improve with the use of charcoal. She had normal growth and development. Pancreatic function tests showed complete absence of lipase activity, with slightly reduced protease activity and normal amylase activity; lipase activity remained very low even after vagal stimulation. Follow-up for more than a decade showed continued symptoms, but good growth and development; she did well in school and participated in sports. Based on the history and findings, {1:Balzer (1967)} concluded that the patient had a congenital enzymopathy, most likely autosomal recessive in nature, since both parents were healthy and the patient had 2 healthy brothers.

{8:Larbre et al. (1969)} reported a 10-year-old girl with congenital lipase deficiency who developed chronic greasy diarrhea at 10 months of age when breastfeeding was discontinued and whole milk introduced into her diet. She was otherwise healthy and had normal growth and development; she had 2 younger brothers who were healthy. The coefficient of fat absorption in the patient was 62%, and analysis of enzyme activity in her duodenal fluid demonstrated an almost total lack of lipase activity. Symptomatic improvement was minimal with pancreatic extract alone, and it was discontinued by the family; the patient's mother stated that limiting her daughter's intake of fats to 40 to 50 g per day normalized her stools. {8:Larbre et al. (1969)} noted that similar to previous reports, there was a striking discrepancy between the voluminous steatorrhea and the patient's overall good state of health.

{14:Verger et al. (1971)} reported a 9-year-old boy who had severe steatorrhea from 2 years of age, in whom examination of duodenal fluid revealed decreased pancreatic lipase activity. In contrast to previous reports, replacing dietary animal fat with corn oil increased the patient's coefficient of fat absorption from 60% to 82%. Effective treatment measures included high doses of pancreatic extract and extreme reduction of dietary fat, to 20 g of corn oil per day.

In a 9-year-old girl who had large greasy stools from 3 months of age and complete lack of pancreatic lipase activity in duodenal fluid, {5:Figarella et al. (1972)} demonstrated that pancreatic colipase ({120105}) was present and unaffected.

{10:Muller et al. (1975)} reported a patient in whom, despite complete absence of pancreatic lipase, more than 50% of dietary fat was absorbed. Studies to elucidate the mechanism of fat absorption suggested that in the absence of pancreatic lipase, gastric lipase ({601980}) and pancreatic esterase ({114840}) may play an important compensatory role in the absorption of dietary fat.

Using immunologic and enzymatic techniques to study a 46-year-old man who had steatorrhea from at least age 20 years, {3:Figarella et al. (1979)} demonstrated a complete lack of pancreatic lipase, but normal levels of colipase. Duodenal fluid from the patient, in which no pancreatic lipase activity could be detected, was capable of reactivating pure pancreatic lipase inhibited by a high concentration of biliary salts, thus indicating the presence of colipase.

In a 5.5-year-old boy of German parentage who from infancy had greasy/oily stools, {4:Figarella et al. (1980)} found absence of pancreatic lipase in duodenal contents after stimulation with secretin/pancreozymin. Colipase, however, was present, consistent with independent synthesis of the 2 enzymes. Stool bulk and frequency decreased while on a fat-reduced diet. Addition of exogenous lipase to a diet with normal fat content did not appreciably change stool weight and frequency. Lard as a major source of dietary fat did not cause overtly greasy/oily stools, whereas such stools were again produced after ingestion of butterfat. At 11 years of age, the child was well within normal growth and development, and continued on a fat-reduced diet. {4:Figarella et al. (1980)} suggested that the poor clinical response to exogenous lipase might be due in part to denaturation in the acid milieu of the stomach, with the remaining activity inadequate to normalize fat digestion.

{2:Behar et al. (2014)} reported 15- and 19-year-old brothers, born to healthy first-cousin parents of Arab Muslim origin from central Israel, who had voluminous greasy stools from the first postnatal days of feeding. The brothers had no dysmorphic features or other abnormalities, and they had been treated with ADEK vitamin and pancreatic enzyme replacement since childhood, with partial compliance. Their body mass indices (BMIs) were in the 'underweight' range (22-23), despite very high caloric intake. Laboratory analysis in the affected brothers showed low lipase levels, low fecal elastase levels, and an abnormal pancreolauryl test. Biochemical analysis showed a marked decrease in PNLIP activity in the 2 brothers, with mildly reduced and low-normal levels in their father and mother, respectively. Vitamin A levels were in the normal range, but lower in the 2 affected brothers than in other family members, whereas vitamin D levels were 'insufficient' in the father as well as in 2 unaffected brothers, 'deficient' in the 2 affected brothers, and 'severely deficient' in their mother; vitamin E levels were low only in the 2 affected brothers.

<Subhead> Isolated Pancreatic Colipase Deficiency

{7:Hildebrand et al. (1982)} studied 2 Assyrian brothers, born of consanguineous parents, in whom loose stools developed at 5 and 6 years of age, respectively. Evaluation revealed steatorrhea, and analysis of exocrine pancreatic enzymes in the small intestine revealed isolated colipase deficiency, with normal levels of amylase, chymotrypsin ({601405}), and lipase. Intraduodenal infusion of purified colipase improved fat digestion measured by the triolein breath test, and the sibs' steatorrhea decreased on treatment with enteric-coated pancreatic enzymes. Both boys had gallstones, possibly related to malabsorption of bile salts associated with pancreatic insufficiency. The older brother also had megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency; the authors noted that defective absorption of vitamin B12 had been observed in patients with pancreatic insufficiency ({13:Toskes et al., 1971}), and suggested that colipase might be involved in its absorption. {7:Hildebrand et al. (1982)} stated that this was the first report of isolated colipase deficiency, and noted that either lipase or colipase deficiency results in the same pattern of decreased fat absorption.

<Subhead> Combined Congenital Pancreatic Lipase and Colipase Deficiency

{6:Ghishan et al. (1984)} reported a 5-year-old boy who had a history of passing foul-smelling oily/greasy stools from birth. The stools became less greasy when skim milk feedings were begun at 2 months of age, but began again upon introduction of solid foods. Pancreatic stimulation tests showed that both lipase and colipase activities were less than 2% of normal values. The patient's fat absorption coefficient went from 50% to 82% upon supplementation with pancreatic enzymes. {6:Ghishan et al. (1984)} stated that this was the first report of congenital combined lipase and colipase deficiency.

{9:Ligumsky et al. (1990)} described 2 brothers of Arab origin, born to nonconsanguineous parents, who had isolated congenital lipase and colipase deficiency. Both sibs, who were 15 years and 10 years old, had passed greasy stools from infancy but were otherwise healthy and normally developed. Both had voluminous steatorrhea and low serum carotene and vitamin E concentrations, although there were no clinical signs of any lipid-soluble vitamin deficiency. After exocrine pancreatic stimulation, lipase activity in duodenal fluid from both brothers was less than 1.5% of the control value and colipase activity was almost completely absent, whereas amylase, trypsin, bile salts, and pH values were normal. {9:Ligumsky et al. (1990)} noted that fat absorption in the sibs was 70% and 79%, respectively, suggesting that in these patients extrapancreatic sources of lipase, such as lingual and gastric lipase, may have an important compensating role in fat digestion.
disease_name+syn: ['Pancreatic lipase deficiency', 'PNLIP', ' PNLIPD']

disease_des/def:
Infection-induced acute encephalitis-12 (IIAE12) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by episodic acute encephalopathy associated with infections and febrile illness. Patients present with neurologic symptoms in the first months or years of life, usually after normal early development. Brain imaging in the acute episodes shows restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and T2-weighted abnormalities in the periventricular and subcortical regions, which progresses to cavitation of previously affected areas. The long-term outcome is highly variable, even within families, ranging from death to severe neurologic deficits to normal outcomes ({2:Shashi et al., 2023}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of susceptibility to acute infection-induced encephalopathy, see {610551}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Hedberg-Oldfors et al. (2023)} reported 2 sibs, born of consanguineous Somali parents, who presented soon after birth with congenital cataracts, hypotonia, and feeding difficulties. They had global developmental delay, poor head control, and clumsy movements. Both had recurrent viral upper respiratory infections with fever, breathing difficulties, and feeding problems beginning at age 4 months and 8 months, respectively. These episodes were associated with macrocytic anemia and increased CSF levels of NEFL ({162280}) and GFAP ({137780}), suggesting neuroaxonal and astroglial injury. At age 7 months, the boy developed seizures and respiratory insufficiency that required ventilator treatment. At 8 months, he had fever and vomiting followed by severe hypotonia, multifocal seizures, and apnea. He became comatose with no spontaneous respiration. Brain imaging showed supratentorial ischemia and cerebral herniation, and he died. From 8 to 17 months of age, his younger sister had similar recurrent viral infections associated with seizures, respiratory insufficiency, and neurologic deterioration with loss of developmental skills. Brain imaging at 8 months of age showed increased T2-weighted signals in the thalamus, globus pallidus, and other cortical/subcortical regions. She was able to walk with aid at age 17 months, but had neurologic stagnation, subtle evidence of a myopathy, and required tube-feeding. She was noted to have exophoria, tent-shaped mouth, and small chin.

{2:Shashi et al. (2023)} reported 8 patients from 4 unrelated families who presented between 3 months and 6 years of age with acute encephalopathy associated with febrile illness or infection, usually viral. All had normal early development before the onset of symptoms. Neurologic features of the acute episodes included seizures, hemiplegia, decreased consciousness, hypotonia, abnormal posturing, feeding problems, and respiratory insufficiency. Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP; {123260}) and cytokines were observed in some patients, consistent with inflammation, and some patients had anemia. One patient developed atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS) associated with thrombotic microangiopathy. Three patients died between 3 months and 4 years of age. Brain imaging during the acute episodes showed DWI restriction and T2-weighted abnormalities in the periventricular and deep white matter regions, including the thalami. Some patients had involvement of the brainstem and cerebellum. Later brain imaging showed parenchymal volume loss, ventriculomegaly, and extensive cavitation of previously affected areas. Of the 5 living patients, who ranged from 5 to 22 years of age, 2 had normal neurodevelopment (1 with emotional lability), whereas 3 had profound neurologic and intellectual disabilities. Two sibs in family 4, ages 16 and 22 years, were severely affected with little voluntary movement, diffuse spasticity, ankle clonus, contractures, scoliosis, absent speech, and chronic pigmentary retinopathy; both were tube-fed.
disease_name+syn: ['Encephalopathy, acute, infection-induced, susceptibility to, 12', 'RNH1', ' RNH', ' IIAE12']

disease_des/def:
Mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome-18 (MTDPS18) is an autosomal recessive neuromuscular disorder characterized by early-onset progressive weakness and atrophy of the distal limb muscles, resulting in loss of ambulation as well as atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles with clawed hands. Affected individuals may also develop scoliosis and have hypo- or hyperreflexia and decreased pulmonary vital capacity. Examination of skeletal muscle shows neurogenic atrophy and combined mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation deficiency associated with mtDNA depletion. The clinical phenotype is reminiscent of spinal muscular atrophy (see SMA, {253300}) and the metabolic profile is reminiscent of 2-aminoadipic 2-oxoadipic aciduria (AMOXAD; {204750}), which is caused by mutation in the DHTKD1 gene ({614984}) (summary by {1:Boczonadi et al., 2018}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of autosomal recessive mtDNA depletion syndromes, see MTDPS1 ({603041}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Boczonadi et al. (2018)} reported a 19-year-old woman, born of consanguineous Pakistani parents, with a progressive neurologic disorder. She achieved walking at 15 months of age, but showed progressive deterioration with frequent falls between 3 and 5 years. She developed distal muscle weakness and atrophy of the hands and feet with clenched hands and bilateral foot drop. The disorder was progressive, with the development of proximal weakness and intermittent relapses triggered by fever; she became wheelchair-bound at age 15. Other features included failure to thrive, scoliosis, hyporeflexia, brisk reflexes in the lower limbs with ankle clonus, and decreased forced vital capacity (56 to 65% normal values). Laboratory studies showed some lactic aciduria and urinary excretion of 3-hydroxyisovaleric and glutaric acid, with mildly increased lactate in the CSF. Brain and spinal cord imaging was normal. Neurophysiologic testing showed severe neurogenic changes consistent with an anterior horn cell process, and nerve biopsy showed an axonopathy with patchy loss of myelinated fibers. Skeletal muscle biopsy showed fiber type grouping suggesting neurogenic atrophy, as well as variably decreased activities and steady-state levels of mitochondrial complexes I, III, IV, and V, and significant mtDNA depletion (less than 10% of normal).
disease_name+syn: ['Mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome 18', 'SLC25A21', ' ODC', ' MTDPS18']

disease_name: Neuronopathy, distal hereditary motor, autosomal recessive 8
disease_des/def:
Autosomal recessive distal hereditary motor neuronopathy-8 (HMNR8), or sorbitol dehydrogenase deficiency with peripheral neuropathy (SORDD), is characterized by onset of distal muscle weakness mainly affecting the lower limbs and resulting in difficulty walking. Onset of symptoms is usually in the first or second decades of life, although later adult onset has been reported; the disorder is slowly progressive. Nerve conduction velocities are most consistent with an axonal process. More variable features include distal sensory impairment, upper limb tremor, and scoliosis. Laboratory studies show increased serum sorbitol (summary by {1:Cortese et al., 2020}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of autosomal recessive HMN, see HMNR1 ({604320}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Cortese et al. (2020)} reported 45 patients from 38 unrelated families with distal hereditary neuropathy mainly affecting the lower limbs. The patients were ascertained from 3 large cohorts totaling about 1,000 individuals with a peripheral neuropathy who underwent whole-exome or whole-genome sequencing. Most patients presented with difficulty walking in the first or second decade, although a few had later onset (up to age 40). Delayed motor milestones were uncommon, but many had foot deformities, including pes cavus, suggesting that the neuropathy may have started earlier. All had distal lower limb weakness, but only about half of patients had sensory impairment. Seven had tremor in the upper limb, 4 had mild scoliosis, and 2 had hearing loss. Nerve conduction studies typically showed an axonal neuropathy. Sural nerve biopsy reports were not provided. The disease severity tended to be mild, although some had moderate severity. The clinical diagnoses encompassed autosomal recessive axonal Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (see, e.g., CMT2A1; {118210}) in 51%, distal hereditary motor neuropathy (see, e.g., dHMN; {182960}) in 40%, and intermediate CMT (see, e.g., CMTRIA; {608340}) in 9%. None of the patients had cataracts or other organ involvement.

{2:Liu et al. (2021)} described 5 unrelated Chinese patients with HMNR8. All presented in childhood or adolescence with distal weakness and atrophy in the lower limbs. All of the patients retained the ability to walk, and disease progression was mild to modest. Two patients had numbness and pain in the distal lower extremities, and 2 patients had mild weakness in the upper limbs.
disease_name+syn: ['Neuronopathy, distal hereditary motor, autosomal recessive 8', 'SORD', ' SORD1', ' HMNR8']

disease_des/def: Squalene synthase deficiency (SQSD) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by profound developmental delay, brain abnormalities, 2/3 syndactyly of the toes, and facial dysmorphisms, as well as low total and LDL-cholesterol and abnormal urine organic acids ({1:Coman et al., 2018}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Coman et al. (2018)} reported 3 patients from 2 families with squalene synthase deficiency. The sibs from family 1 were the products of a nonconsanguineous union of European parents and had very similar features and course. They were both born at term with normal growth parameters and developed seizures in the neonatal period. Brain MRI showed hypoplasia of the corpus callosum and white matter loss. Both had profound global developmental delay at 10 and 7 years, with irritability and poor sleep initiation. Both children developed failure to thrive and required gastrostomy tube feeds. Optic nerve hypoplasia with cortical visual impairment was present, but neither had cataracts. Facial dysmorphisms included depressed nasal bridge, square nasal tip, epicanthal folds, mild micrognathia, and mild retrognathia. The 7-year-old brother had bilateral cryptorchidism, large ears, and dorsal foot fat pads. The 10-year-old sister had low-set, posteriorly rotated ears. Both had thin gracile bones, flexion deformities at the knees, and 2/3 toe syndactyly. Dry skin with photosensitivity was present, and lack of hair pigment was seen on light and electron microscopy. Total and low density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol were low in both, while high density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) was low for the sister, but normal for the brother. Very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) and triglycerides were normal. Plasma farnesol was more than 10 times normal in both. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy profiles in urine yielded a consistent and complex pattern of elevated methylsuccinic acid, mevalonate lactone, mesaconic acid, and 3-methyladipic acid. Saturated and unsaturated branched-chain dicarboxylic acids and glucuronides derived from farnesol were also observed. The boy from family 2 was also born of nonconsanguineous European parents. Findings were similar except that his brain MRI showed diffuse polymicrogyria as well as central white matter and cortical volume loss. He had hypospadias without cryptorchidism, bicuspid aortic valve, and flexion deformities of elbows rather than knees. Total cholesterol and LDL-C were low, with normal HDL-C and triglycerides. VLDL-C and farnesol were not measured.
disease_name+syn: ['Squalene synthase deficiency', 'FDFT1', ' DGPT', ' SQSD']

disease_name: Cerebellar dysfunction, impaired intellectual development, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
disease_des/def: Cerebellar dysfunction, impaired intellectual development, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (CDIDHH) is characterized by delayed motor development, ataxia, severe progressive scoliosis, moderate to severe intellectual disability, and delayed sexual development. Cerebellar hypoplasia has been observed in some patients ({1:Whittaker et al., 2021}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Whittaker et al. (2021)} reported a Maltese brother and sister (patients 1 and 2) and an unrelated Maltese man (patient 3) with cerebellar dysfunction, impaired intellectual development, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, and mutation in the PRDM13 gene. All 3 patients showed developmental delay in infancy, with generalized hypotonia and hyporeflexia, as well as wide-based ataxic gaits. The 2 sibs ambulated with walkers, whereas patient 3 was wheelchair-dependent by age 12 years. Brain imaging in patients 1 and 3 showed cerebellar hypoplasia, whereas imaging in patient 2 had been reported as normal. All 3 patients had progressive severe scoliosis requiring surgical fixation. In addition, delayed or absent puberty became apparent in adolescence, associated with low gonadotropin levels. Both male patients had a small penis and cryptorchidism, and underwent orchidopexy. The patients responded to testosterone or estrogen supplementation with development of secondary sexual characteristics. Neurologic evaluation in the second and third decades of life showed generalized hypotonia, markedly reduced power, symmetric hyporeflexia, intention tremor, dysdiadochokinesis, and past-pointing. Patient 3 also exhibited nystagmus. Intellectual deficits were present in all 3, which were reported as moderate in the 2 sibs and severe in patient 3.
disease_name+syn: ['Cerebellar dysfunction, impaired intellectual development, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism', 'PRDM13', ' CDIDHH', ' PCH17']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
In Japanese, {8:Matsunaga (1962)} described a dimorphism of ear wax, the 2 types being wet and dry. This variation has been studied extensively in Japan since at least 1934. Less attention has been given to this variation elsewhere, probably because Caucasians and blacks have only the wet type of cerumen. In 80 to 85% of Japanese, the cerumen is gray, dry, and brittle. It is referred to as 'rice-bran ear wax' in Japanese. In the other Japanese, the cerumen is brown, sticky, and wet. This is referred to as 'honey ear wax,' 'oily ear wax' or 'cat ear wax.' In all except about 0.5% of Japanese, classification is simple. Family studies indicate monofactorial inheritance, with the rarer phenotype, wet wax, being dominant. Wet cerumen is often associated with axillary odor, which, because of its rarity in Japan, is considered in the lay mind a pathologic state requiring medical attention.

{10:Petrakis et al. (1967)} found a high frequency of dry cerumen in pure-blooded American Indians. No qualitative differences in the chemical composition of the dry and wet types of cerumen were identified by {4:Kataura and Kataura (1967)}.

{11:Petrakis (1971)} noted a positive correlation between wet ear wax and breast cancer in several countries and suggested an association. In a study of Chinese women in Hong Kong, {3:Ing et al. (1973)} could not confirm the association.

{2:Ibraimov (1991)} presented data on the high frequency of dry cerumen in Mongoloid populations and low frequency among Europoids. Intermediate frequencies were found among peoples of subequatorial Africa.

{14:Tomita et al. (2002)} noted that the difference in nature of wet and dry cerumen is attributed to secretory products of ceruminous glands. Histologic studies have shown abundant lipid droplets and pigment granules in the cytoplasm of secretory cells in individuals with wet cerumen, whereas these cytoplasmic components are scarce in individuals with dry cerumen ({8:Matsunaga, 1962}). The ceruminous gland is an apocrine gland, as are axillary and breast glands. In individuals with dry cerumen, the axillary apocrine gland is usually much less developed than in those with wet cerumen, and therefore the dry type is associated with less axillary odor.

The wet cerumen phenotype is completely dominant to the dry type. {15:Yoshiura et al. (2006)} stated that the dry ear wax type is seen frequently (80 to 95%) among East Asians, but uncommonly (0 to 3%) in populations of European and African origins. Intermediate frequencies (30 to 50%) of the dry type are seen in populations of southern Asia, the Pacific Islands, central Asia, and Asia Minor, as well as among the native North American and Inuit of Asian ancestry. These figures show geographic gradient distributions.

Among 225 Japanese women, {9:Miura et al. (2007)} reported an association between ear wax type and apocrine colostrum secretion from the mammary gland on the first postpartum day. The absence of colostrum secretion was more common among women with dry ear wax (105 of 155, 67.7%) compared to women with wet ear wax (28 of 70, 40%). The authors noted that both colostrum and cerumen have a common origin in the secretory glands and suggested that the ABCC11 gene product may play a role in colostrum secretion independent of endocrine control.
disease_name+syn: ['Axillary odor, variation in', 'ABCC11', ' MRP8', ' EWWD', ' WW']
['Microvascular complications of diabetes 1', 'VEGF', ' MVCD1']

disease_des/def:
Primary ciliary dyskinesia-51 (CILD51) is characterized by male infertility due to multiple morphologic abnormalities of the sperm flagella (MMAF), resulting in severely reduced progressive motility. Some men also have a low sperm count. In addition, affected individuals experience chronic rhinosinusitis and bronchitis, and recurrent upper and lower respiratory infections, and some exhibit dextrocardia and/or situs inversus ({1:Guo et al., 2021}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of primary ciliary dyskinesia, see CILD1 ({244400}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Guo et al. (2021)} reported 3 unrelated Chinese men (F1, F2, and F3) with infertility due to MMAF as well as chronic respiratory illnesses, and mutation in the BRWD1 gene. Semen analysis in all 3 men revealed severely reduced progressive sperm motility, with increased percentages of abnormal flagella, including absent, short, and irregular-caliber flagella. Probands F2 and F3 also showed markedly reduced sperm counts. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of patient sperm (from F1 and F2) showed absence of the inner and outer dynein arms (IDAs and ODAs), and this was confirmed by immunostaining; however, the outer doublet microtubule (DMT) number and central pair complex were normal. All 3 men also had a history of chronic wet cough, nasal obstruction, and pneumonia early in life, which developed into chronic rhinosinusitis and bronchitis and recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections in adulthood. CT of the paranasal sinuses in F1 and F2 confirmed chronic rhinosinusitis with a narrowed sinus cavity. Chest CT revealed bronchiectasis and dextrocardia in both, and F1 also had situs inversus. Nasal nitric oxide testing in F1, who had relatively more severe respiratory symptoms than the other 2 probands, showed a level below the diagnostic cutoff for primary ciliary dyskinesia, whereas nasal nitric oxide in F2 was normal; F3 was not tested. TEM of respiratory cilia from patient F1 revealed defects in the IDAs and ODAs as well as a frequent absence of outer DMTs (ranging from 8+2 to 5+2). Staining for markers of the ODAs confirmed their absence in respiratory epithelial cells from F1. In addition, the overall number of cilia was decreased in F1, and cilia on the free surface of respiratory epithelial cells were notably shorter and fewer than those of healthy controls.
disease_name+syn: ['Ciliary dyskinesia, primary, 51', 'BRWD1', ' WRD9', ' C21orf107', ' CILD51']

disease_des/def:
Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy-57 (DEE57) is a neurologic disorder characterized by global developmental delay with hypotonia, variably impaired intellectual development, and poor or absent language. Affected individuals have onset of refractory multifocal seizures in the first days or months of life, and may show developmental regression. EEG patterns include hypsarrhythmia, suggesting a clinical diagnosis of West syndrome, background slowing, and epilepsy of infancy with migrating focal seizures (EIMFS). Some patients may have mild dysmorphic features (summary by {1:Ambrosino et al., 2018} and {4:Mao et al., 2020}).
