disease_name+syn: ['Nephrolithiasis, calcium oxalate, 2, with nephrocalcinosis', 'OXGR1', ' GPR80', ' CAON2']
['Microvascular complications of diabetes 6', 'SOD2', ' MNSOD', ' MVCD6']

disease_des/def:
Craniofacial microsomia-1 (CFM1) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by mandibular hypoplasia, microtia, facial and preauricular skin tags, epibulbar dermoids, and lateral oral clefts, in addition to skeletal and cardiac abnormalities. Inter- and intrafamilial variability has been observed ({63:Timberlake et al., 2021}).

Hemifacial microsomia is a common birth defect involving the first and second branchial arch derivatives. It typically affects the external ear, middle ear, mandible and temporomandibular joint, muscles of mastication and facial muscles, and other facial soft tissues on the affected side. In some cases, other facial structures, such as the orbit, eye, nose, cranium, or neck, may be involved. Involvement is usually limited to one side, but bilateral involvement is known. In addition to craniofacial anomalies, there may be cardiac, vertebral, and central nervous system defects. The phenotype is highly variable. Most cases are sporadic, but there are rare familial cases that exhibit autosomal dominant inheritance (summary by {41:Poole, 1989} and {21:Hennekam et al., 2010}).

<Subhead> Genetic Heterogeneity of Craniofacial Microsomia

CFM2 ({620444}) is caused by mutation in the FOXI3 gene ({612351}) on chromosome 2p11.

See also hemifacial microsomia with radial defects ({141400}) and oculoauriculofrontonasal dysplasia (OAFNS; {601452}), which may be part of the OAV spectrum.

Another disorder that overlaps clinically with CFM is Townes-Brocks syndrome (TBS; {107480}).

<Subhead> Reviews

{47:Ronde et al. (2023)} reviewed the international classification and clinical management strategies for craniofacial microsomia and microtia, and tabulated survey responses from 57 professionals involved in management of CFM patients. The authors noted that although the International Consortium for Health Outcomes Measurement (ICHOM) criteria for CFM exclude isolated microtia from the phenotypic spectrum of CFM, the question of whether isolated microtia can be considered the mildest form of CFM is debated in the literature. No consensus was reached in their survey, as a majority of respondents agreed with the ICHOM criteria but also considered isolated microtia to be a mild form of CFM. In addition, the authors noted that although vertebral, cardiac, and renal anomalies have been reported in CFM patients, there was no consensus on screening for such extracraniofacial anomalies.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
The features of hemifacial microsomia include unilateral deformity of the external ear and small ipsilateral half of the face with epibulbar dermoid and vertebral anomalies. Coloboma of the upper eyelid is frequent. The ear deformities range from preauricular tags of cartilaginous masses, to atresia of the external auditory canal, anomalies in the size and shape of the external auricle, and even to anotia. {20:Gorlin et al. (1963)} suggested the designation oculoauriculovertebral dysplasia for this disorder.

{49:Saraux et al. (1963)} described 2 sisters with Goldenhar syndrome, born of healthy, unrelated parents. The karyotype was normal. {42:Proto and Scullica (1966)} described the condition in a father and his son and daughter. The mother was a first cousin of the father. A patient who possibly had the same condition was observed by {15:Fraser (1967)} to have acroosteolysis of the terminal phalanges. {31:Krause (1970)} described affected brother and sister. The proband had a hemangioma of the scalp. {46:Rollnick and Kaye (1983)} studied the families of 97 probands. Of 433 first-degree relatives, 35 (8%) had the same or a similar anomaly. Of 176 sibs, 11 (6%) were 'affected.' The most frequent anomaly was a mild ear malformation such as preauricular nodule or tag. Multifactorial determination was proposed. {45:Rollnick et al. (1987)} reviewed phenotypic characteristics of 294 patients.

{36:Morrison et al. (1992)} reviewed the cardiovascular anomalies associated with OAV dysplasia.

{51:Singer et al. (1994)} described a large Australian family in which 9 members over 2 generations had hemifacial microsomia. The affected individuals exhibited marked variation in their clinical manifestation of HFM and associated anomalies, with some having such mild involvement that they were previously undiagnosed. Features ranged from isolated microtia, which was the most consistent finding, to severe HFM characterized by microtia, preauricular skin tags, macrostomia, and ipsilateral ramus and condylar hypoplasia with associated soft tissue deficiency. Most patients had unilateral involvement, with the right side more commonly affected that the left, but 2 had bilateral lesions. The authors noted that the extreme phenotypic variability displayed in this family was in keeping with previous reports in the literature. Epibulbar dermoid was present in 1 patient, consistent with an earlier suggestion that HFM and Goldenhar syndrome are part of a spectrum rather than distinct clinical entities.

{59:Sutphen et al. (1995)} found that 3 of 60 patients with the oculoauriculovertebral spectrum (OAVS) had tracheoesophageal fistula, with or without esophageal atresia.

{55:Stoll et al. (1998)} described a mother and 2 of her children who had the oculoauriculovertebral spectrum. The mother had only auricular anomalies for which she had had plastic and reconstructive surgery. Her first child, a girl, had a bilateral cleft lip and palate, a coloboma of the upper eyelid, facial asymmetry, and posteriorly angulated ears. This child also had bilateral vesicoureteral reflux. During the second pregnancy, her fetal ultrasonographic examination performed at 18 weeks' gestation showed a cleft lip and palate. At 31 weeks' gestation, clubfeet, hypoplasia of the left ear, hypoplasia of the left maxillary and mandibular arches, and left microphthalmia were evident. Examination of the male fetus after termination of the pregnancy confirmed the findings of ultrasonography and demonstrated vertebral anomalies.

{65:Van Meter and Weaver (1996)} reported 2 infants (a male and a female) with significant overlap of symptoms of oculoauriculovertebral spectrum and CHARGE association ({214800}). In addition, both infants had plagiocephaly and torticollis, and the boy had cleft lip, heminostril, and tracheoesophageal fistula. The authors suggested that deficiency in migration of neural crest cells, deficiency of mesodermal formation, or defective interaction between neural crest cells and mesoderm may explain the pathogenesis of these defects of blastogenesis.

{39:Nijhawan et al. (2002)} reported 7 children with Goldenhar syndrome who were found to have dysplastic, ectopic, or bilobed caruncles, a small body at the medial angle of the eye that contains modified sebaceous and sweat glands. Four of the children had a nasal sinus or tag and 1 had a nasal-ocular cleft, suggesting an abnormality in the developmental process that is common to the nose and caruncle.

By study of a series of 30 cases (26 previously reported) and by analysis of a congenital birth defects registry in Spain, {66:Wang et al. (2002)} found that infants of diabetic mothers were at increased risk for a diagnosis of OAVS. Analysis of the registry data gave an odds ratio of OAVS of 2.28 (95% CI, 1.03-4.82; p = 0.03) and 1.50 (95% CI, 0.08-9.99; p = 0.49) in maternal gestational diabetes and preconceptually diagnosed type I or II maternal diabetes, respectively. {66:Wang et al. (2002)} hypothesized that poorly controlled maternal diabetes interferes with neural crest cell migration.

{11:Derbent et al. (2003)} described a child with del22q11 who had a phenotypic appearance similar to that seen in OAVS. He had left microtia with atresia of the external meatus, left mandibular hypoplasia, and peripheral facial nerve paralysis. Growth parameters were below the 5th percentile, but intelligence and ophthalmologic examination were normal. Cardiac findings included situs inversus dextrocardia, double outlet right ventricle, pulmonic stenosis, and ventricular septal defect. Radiographs showed platybasia, complete fusion of the C2-C3, and posterior fusion of the T1-T2 vertebrae.

{3:Beck et al. (2005)} described 2 unrelated girls with OAVS and ocular colobomas. One girl had bilateral iris colobomas extending into the retina and a small left optic nerve coloboma; her mother had features consistent with OAVS and a segmental area of heterochromia of her right iris. The second girl had a large left inferior chorioretinal coloboma involving her optic nerve and macula as well as a left colobomatous cyst; her sister and father had features consistent with OAVS, although neither had ocular colobomas.

{64:Touliatou et al. (2006)} reported detailed clinical features of 17 Greek patients with Goldenhar syndrome, including a pair of affected monozygotic twins. The most consistent findings were auricular defects (94%), followed by facial anomalies (76%), ocular anomalies (65%), and conductive hearing loss (76%). Most features were unilateral (70%); mandibular hypoplasia was ipsilateral to the dysplastic ear in 9 of 10 patients. Facial nerve paralysis and mental retardation were also observed.

{56:Stromland et al. (2007)} performed a multidisciplinary study of 18 Swedish patients with Goldenhar syndrome and found that the most frequent systemic malformations involved the ears (100%), eyes (72%), vertebrae (76%), cerebrum (50%), and heart (33%). Functional defects consisted of hearing impairment (83%; including conductive loss, sensorineural, or combined), visual impairment (28%), both visual and hearing impairment (28%), difficulties in feeding/eating (50%), speech impairment (53%), and mental retardation (39%). Two of 17 patients evaluated for autistic spectrum disorder had severe autistic symptoms (11%).

{70:Yusufoglu et al. (2008)} reported an 8-year-old boy with facial, auricular, and vertebral anomalies consistent with Goldenhar syndrome, who had a parachute mitral valve and was also found to have growth hormone deficiency. The authors noted that 1 other patient with Goldenhar syndrome had been reported with growth hormone deficiency ({37:Nakagawa et al., 1993}), but stated that it was not clear whether this was an association by chance or a rare finding in the syndrome.

{2:Amalnath et al. (2008)} reported 3 brothers with OAVS manifest as bilateral lower facial palsies, bilateral microtia with aural atresia, and kyphoscoliosis. Radiographs showed fused cervical vertebrae and spina bifida occulta of multiple lumbar vertebrae in all 3 sibs. CT scan of the temporal bone revealed temporal bone dysplasia, absent styloid process, and intact ear ossicles. There were no cardiac or renal anomalies. One of the boys developed a B cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma at age 13 years. Inheritance was consistent with an autosomal recessive or X-linked pattern.

{13:Digilio et al. (2008)} analyzed the frequency and anatomic characteristics of congenital heart defects (CHDs) in a series of 87 patients with OAVS who were examined during a 17-year period at a single center. CHDs were diagnosed in 28 (32%) of the patients. The most common CHDs were membranous or muscular ventricular septal defect (6 patients) and tetralogy of Fallot, either classic or with pulmonary atresia (6 patients). Three patients had atrial septal defect. In addition, anomalous pulmonary venous return was diagnosed in 4 patients, which was partial in 3 and total in 1. Although there is a greater frequency of male patients with OAVS, there was no sex preponderance among OAVS patients with CHDs.

{52:Slavotinek and Vargervik (2011)} reported a 10-year-old Hispanic boy who had features of OAVS, including facial asymmetry, lipodermoids, smaller right ear with preauricular tags and a cheek tag, small jaw with defective oral commissure, and vertebral anomalies, but who also displayed several atypical findings, including an imperforate anus, rib fusions, and scoliosis requiring a brace. He was born of a twin pregnancy with dichorionic, diamniotic membranes; his twin brother had developmental delay, unilateral mild to moderate conductive hearing loss, mild hypotonia, and bilateral fifth finger clinodactyly. Chromosome microarray showed no diagnostic cytogenetic aberrations, and screening of the SALL1 gene was negative in the proband.

{63:Timberlake et al. (2021)} studied 20 patients from 7 kindreds with craniofacial microsomia and mutation in the SF3B2 gene, including the large Australian family originally described by {51:Singer et al. (1994)}. Features included mandibular hypoplasia, microtia, facial and preauricular tags, epibulbar dermoids, and lateral oral clefts. Widely variable phenotypes were observed within single kindreds, supporting the notion that microtia and CFM are part of a single phenotypic spectrum. Cervical ribs were detected in 3 patients; the authors stated that cervical imaging was not available for the other patients, and thus the exact frequency in the cohort was unknown. Noting that consistent features included mandibular hypoplasia and external ear malformations involving the tragus, the authors suggested that the SF3B2 variants predominantly affect development of pharyngeal arch I.

<Subhead> Reviews

{4:Beleza-Meireles et al. (2014)} reviewed 158 published cases of OAVS, noting the lack of consensus regarding the minimum diagnostic criteria due to variable expressivity, with a phenotypic spectrum ranging from subtle facial asymmetry with a small skin tag in front of an otherwise normal-appearing ear to a complex phenotype involving multiple congenital anomalies. Nearly all OAVS patients exhibit some degree of hemifacial microsomia, resulting from maxillary and/or mandibular hypoplasia. External ear anomalies are also very common, and most affected individuals have some degree of hearing loss. In addition, a variety of ocular anomalies may be observed, and congenital heart defects are not uncommon.
disease_name+syn: ['Craniofacial microsomia', 'SF3B2', ' SF3B145', ' SAP145', ' CFM']

disease_des/def:
AMED syndrome (AMEDS) is an autosomal recessive digenic multisystem disorder characterized by global developmental delay with impaired intellectual development, onset of bone marrow failure and myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) in childhood, and poor overall growth with short stature (summary by {1:Oka et al., 2020}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of bone marrow failure syndrome (BMFS), see BMFS1 ({614675}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Oka et al. (2020)} reported 10 patients from 8 unrelated Japanese families with a syndromic disorder comprising bone marrow failure, poor growth, and global developmental delay. Three patients died between 2 and 9 years of age, whereas 7 were alive well into the second decade. Detailed clinical features were available for 7 patients from families 4 through 8. Most presented in the first months or years of life with failure to thrive, short stature, developmental delay, and bone marrow failure manifest as pancytopenia or anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia. Bone marrow examination showed various types of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with trilineage dysplasia; 1 patient was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. Four patients received a bone marrow transplant. The patients had poor weight gain and impaired growth, manifest as short stature (down to -4.5 SD) and microcephaly (down to -5.8). All had global developmental delay with impaired motor skills, intellectual disability, learning disabilities, and speech delay; some had behavioral problems, including ADHD and autistic features. A few patients had variable additional features, such as skin hyperpigmentation, hypohidrosis, long thumbs, displaced toes, mild dysmorphic facial features, hypothyroidism, leukoencephalopathy, and frontal lobe atrophy. None had episodes of sunburn. The phenotype was similar to other bone marrow failure disorders caused by defective DNA repair. Before genetic analysis, some of the patients were diagnosed clinically with disorders such as Fanconi anemia (see, e.g., FANCA; {227650}) or Bloom syndrome (BLM; {210900}).
disease_name+syn: ['AMED syndrome, digenic', 'ADH5', ' FDH', ' AMEDS', ' BMFS7']

disease_des/def: Hepatocellular carcinoma is the major histologic type of malignant primary liver neoplasm. It is the fifth most common cancer and the third most common cause of death from cancer worldwide. The major risk factors for HCC are chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, prolonged dietary aflatoxin exposure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and cirrhosis due to other causes. Hepatoblastomas comprise 1 to 2% of all malignant neoplasms of childhood, most often occurring in children under 3 years of age. Hepatoblastomas are thought to be derived from undifferentiated hepatocytes ({38:Taniguchi et al., 2002}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
Primary cancer of the liver in 3 brothers was described by {19:Kaplan and Cole (1965)} and by {10:Hagstrom and Baker (1968)}. In these patients there was no recognized preexisting liver disease. {7:Denison et al. (1971)} described 2 adult brothers who died of primary hepatocellular carcinoma. Both had micronodular cirrhosis with features of subacute progressive viral hepatitis. Australia antigen was demonstrated in the brother in whom it was sought. Their father had died much earlier of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Hepatoblastoma has been described in sibs ({9:Fraumeni et al., 1969}; {27:Napoli and Campbell, 1977}; {16:Ito et al., 1987}).

See {231100} for description of liver cancer as a complication of giant cell hepatitis of infancy. Familial liver cell carcinoma might also have its explanation in alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency ({613490}), hemochromatosis ({235200}), and tyrosinemia ({276700}).

{18:Jiang et al. (2019)} used proteomic and phosphoproteomic profiling to characterize 110 paired tumor and nontumor tissues of clinical early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma related to hepatitis B virus infection. The quantitative proteomic data highlight heterogeneity in early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma. The cohort was stratified into subtypes S-I, S-II, and S-III, each of which has a different clinical outcome. S-III, which is characterized by disrupted cholesterol homeostasis, is associated with the lowest overall rate of survival and the greatest risk of a poor prognosis after first-line surgery.
disease_name+syn: ['Hepatoblastoma, somatic', 'APC', ' GS', ' FPC', ' BTPS2', ' DESMD']

disease_des/def: Prieto syndrome (PRS) is an X-linked intellectual developmental disorder characterized by mildly to severely impaired intellectual development, developmental delay, autism spectrum disorder, or neuropsychiatric symptoms, variably accompanied by speech delay, epilepsy, microcephaly, structural brain defects, and minor facial anomalies (summary by {1:Kury et al., 2022}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{2:Prieto et al. (1987)} described 8 males in 3 sibships who had a growth syndrome characterized by impaired intellectual development (ID), facial dysmorphism, abnormal dental growth, skin dimple at the lower back, clinodactyly, patella luxation, and subcortical cerebral atrophy.

{1:Kury et al. (2022)} described 14 males with impaired intellectual development from 6 unrelated families, including the large multigenerational family originally reported by {2:Prieto et al. (1987)}. The patients were identified after molecular testing revealed mutations in the WNK3 gene. The 6 probands were referred for genetic testing for impaired intellectual development, developmental delay (DD), autism spectrum disorder, or neuropsychiatric symptoms. In all families, tested mothers were asymptomatic heterozygotes. The most frequently reported features were ID and DD (14/14). Ten of 13 patients (77%) had minor dysmorphic features, but no unifying facial gestalt was evident. Five of 13 patients (38%) had behavioral or neuropsychiatric symptoms, including attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD; 2 patients), autistic features (1 patient), and self-aggression (1 patient). Six of 13 patients (46%) exhibited mild microcephaly with head circumference between -2 SD and -2.4 SD. Five of 13 patients (38%) had epilepsy. Variable structural brain abnormalities were noted in 7/10 patients who had undergone MRI imaging, including 2 brothers from family 2 with polymicrogyria.
disease_name+syn: ['Prieto syndrome', 'WNK3', ' PRKWNK3', ' KIAA1566', ' PRS']

disease_des/def: Autosomal recessive spinocerebellar ataxia-31 (SCAR31) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by global developmental delay with hypotonia and variably impaired intellectual and language development. Affected individuals have an ataxic gait, tremor, and dysarthria; more severely affected patients also have spasticity with inability to walk. Most have optic atrophy. Brain imaging shows cerebellar hypoplasia, enlarged ventricles, and atrophy of the posterior corpus callosum. Additional features may include retinitis pigmentosa, sensorineural deafness, dysmorphic facial features, and possibly endocrine dysfunction (summary by {1:Collier et al., 2021}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Collier et al. (2021)} reported 12 patients from 5 unrelated families with a complex neurodevelopmental disorder. The patients were ascertained internationally through the GeneMatcher Program after undergoing exome sequencing. The patients ranged from 21 months to 71 years of age. From early infancy, they showed axial hypotonia, variably impaired intellectual development with poor or absent speech, and delayed walking (up to 7 years of age) or inability to walk. All patients had ataxia, often with tremor or dyskinesia, as well as dysarthria associated with cerebellar hypoplasia on brain imaging. Other brain imaging findings included cerebral atrophy, enlarged ventricles, and atrophy of the posterior part of the corpus callosum. Most patients had optic atrophy, and some had ptosis, chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia, retinopathy, and strabismus; 1 had early-onset cataracts. More severely affected patients had spastic paraplegia and inability to walk. Some patients had dysmorphic facial features, such as long face, smooth philtrum, retrognathia, high-arched palate, and gum hypertrophy. One patient (P3) had seizures, another (P5) had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, and gynecomastia, and 2 sisters (family 2) had late-onset or absent puberty, suggesting possible endocrine dysfunction. Two sibs (family 4), 71 and 68 years of age, had additional neurodegenerative features, including dementia, schizophrenic psychosis, aggression, self-mutilation behavior, dysphagia, and choreatic hyperkinesia.
disease_name+syn: ['Spinocerebellar ataxia, autosomal recessive 31', 'ATG7', ' APG7L', ' GSA7', ' SCAR31']

disease_des/def:
Erythropoietic porphyria-2 is an autosomal dominant metabolic disorder of heme biosynthesis, resulting in abnormal accumulation of the heme biosynthesis intermediate protoporphyrin IX (PPIX). Affected individuals may have photosensitivity (summary by {1:Yien et al., 2017})

For discussion of genetic heterogeneity of EPP, see EPP1 ({177000}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Yien et al. (2017)} reported an 18-year-old French girl with congenital porphyria. She had onset of acute photosensitivity at age 9 months. Features included painful phototoxic reactions and elevated levels of free and zinc-chelated erythroid PPIX, a heme biosynthesis intermediate. At the time of diagnosis, she also had microcytic iron deficiency anemia, which may or may not have been related to the EPP. Her father and paternal uncle had mild photosensitivity and accumulation of PPIX, but without the complete clinical syndrome of EPP.
disease_name+syn: ['Protoporphyria, erythropoietic, 2', 'CLPX', ' EPP2']

disease_des/def: Autosomal recessive spinocerebellar ataxia-30 (SCAR30) is a progressive neurologic disorder characterized by childhood-onset global developmental delay with variably impaired intellectual development, motor dysfunction, and cerebellar ataxia. Affected individuals may also have psychiatric abnormalities, such as obsessive behavior, psychotic episodes, or hallucinations. Brain imaging usually shows cerebellar atrophy, although this may be an age-dependent feature (summary by {3:Langer et al., 2018}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Brunetti et al. (2016)} reported 2 sibs from a Norwegian family with SCAR30. The proband was a 68-year-old woman with mild intellectual disability since childhood, spinocerebellar ataxia, and obsessional behavior with psychotic episodes and hallucinations. CSF analysis showed low beta-amyloid(1-42) (see {104760}). Her brother had mild intellectual disability, early-onset ataxia, obsessional behavior, and psychotic episodes. Brain imaging in both patients showed marked cerebellar atrophy. Skeletal muscle biopsy from 1 patient showed some evidence of mitochondrial dysfunction.

{3:Langer et al. (2018)} reported 2 brothers, born of consanguineous Palestinian parents (family A), with SCAR30. The patients, who were 15 and 18 years of age, had global developmental delay with delayed walking and impaired intellectual development. The more severely affected brother walked at age 11 years, had expressive aphasia, dysmetria, psychotic episodes, and anger attacks. Laboratory studies showed increased serum creatine kinase and increased lactate. He also had mild distal sensory impairment. His brother, who walked at 5 years, had severe ataxia and psychotic episodes. Brain imaging in both patients showed severe cerebellar atrophy. Two sibs from a second consanguineous Palestinian family (family B) had a similar disorder with motor, cognitive, and speech delay apparent from early childhood, although the phenotype was not as severe as in the first family. One patient had unsteady gait and dysmetria. Brain imaging was normal in both patients from family B at ages 12 and 4 years, respectively. None of the patients had seizures.
disease_name+syn: ['Spinocerebellar ataxia, autosomal recessive 30', 'PITRM1', ' MP1', ' PREP', ' SCAR30']

disease_des/def:
Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy-96 (DEE96) is characterized by onset of seizures in the first days or weeks of life. Affected infants have tonic or myoclonic seizures associated with burst-suppression pattern on EEG. They also have hypotonia with respiratory insufficiency that may result in premature death. Those that survive have profound developmental delay and persistent seizures (summary by {2:Suzuki et al., 2019}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of DEE, see {308350}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {2:Suzuki et al. (2019)} reported 2 unrelated Japanese infant girls with early infantile epileptic encephalopathy (EIEE). The first patient presented after birth with continuous vomiting and tonic seizures associated with a continuous burst-suppression pattern on EEG. She died of respiratory failure on day 36 of life. The second patient was born prematurely at 33 weeks' gestation; prenatally she had exhibited hydrops, anemia, and failure to thrive. At birth, head circumference was -3.4 SD and she had no spontaneous respiration, requiring mechanical ventilation. She had frequent myoclonic seizures associated with continuous burst-suppression patterns on EEG. At age 3 years, she had profound intellectual disability, severe motor developmental delay, and no spontaneous respiration. The patient continued to have frequent myoclonic seizures and epileptic spasms.
disease_name+syn: ['Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 96', 'NSF', ' DEE96']

disease_name: Visual impairment and progressive phthisis bulbi
disease_des/def: Visual impairment and progressive phthisis bulbi is characterized by poor vision at birth, with development of bilateral phthisis by adulthood ({1:Ansar et al., 2018}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Ansar et al. (2018)} reported a consanguineous Pakistani family (family F105) in which 3 sibs had poor vision at birth. The 2 older affected sibs (V:2 and V:3), who were 30 and 18 years old, developed eye phthisis by adulthood. MRI showed small deformed eye globes bilaterally, with loss of the normal structural differentiation between the anterior and posterior chambers, including the aqueous and vitreous humors. Ultrasonography in patient V:3 showed a thickened posterior wall, vitreous opacity, and small interior-posterior chamber with a 14-mm axial diameter (normal diameter, 24 mm); no posterior eye wall was detected in patient V:2. Their 15-year-old affected sister (V:5) had ptosis with reduced visual acuity and hazy corneas, and examination revealed cornea plana and hypermetropia. Funduscopy was unremarkable.
disease_name+syn: ['Visual impairment and progressive phthisis bulbi', 'MARK3', ' VIPB']

disease_des/def: DFNB109 is characterized by bilateral congenital severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. In addition, affected individuals exhibit vestibular dysplasia on CT scan, although they do not manifest problems with balance or movement ({1:Rohacek et al., 2017}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Rohacek et al. (2017)} studied a family in which an 8-year-old girl and her 14-year-old brother had bilateral congenital severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. Temporal bone CT scan revealed no abnormalities in cochlear morphology; however, both sibs showed an unusual vestibular dysplasia, consisting of a rudimentary lateral semicircular canal deficient in its central bony island, which had a cystic appearance. Despite the abnormal vestibular findings, neither child exhibited a balance or movement disorder. There were 4 healthy sibs, including the affected girl's twin brother, who had normal hearing.
disease_name+syn: ['Deafness, autosomal recessive 109', 'ESRP1', ' RMB35A', ' DFNB109']

disease_des/def:
Spermatogenic failure-87 (SPGF87) is characterized by male infertility, with total fertilization failure due to inability of mutant sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida. Infertility can be rescued by intracytoplasmic sperm injection without assisted oocyte activation ({1:Hua et al., 2023}).

For a general phenotypic description and discussion of genetic heterogeneity of spermatogenic failure, see SPGF1 ({258150}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Hua et al. (2023)} reported 2 Chinese brothers (P1 and P2) from a consanguineous family with infertility and mutation in the ACR gene. Semen analysis parameters were normal, and both wives had pregnancies with previous partners and no abnormalities of the reproductive system on routine examination. Sperm morphology appeared normal under light microscopy and scanning electron microscopy. However, transmission electron microscopy of patient sperm showed that approximately 75% of acrosomes were detached from the nuclear envelope and exhibited a ruffled morphology, with folding and shedding, as well as irregular thickening of the loosened perinuclear theca. Both couples experienced total fertilization failure with initial in vitro fertilization (IVF). IVF experiments demonstrated that the ACR-deficient sperm could not penetrate the oocyte zona pellucida (ZP), even after successful adherence to the surface of the ZP using oocytes without cumulus cells. When patient sperm were injected into the perivitelline space of metaphase II oocytes (subzonal insemination, SUZI), the mutant sperm fused successfully with the oocytes and eventually fertilized them without requiring assisted oocyte activation (AOA). The couples were able to achieve oocyte fertilization with intracytoplasmic sperm injection without AOA, resulting in clinical pregnancy after implantation.
disease_name+syn: ['Spermatogenic failure 87', 'ACR', ' SPGF87']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Vetro et al. (2017)} studied a 4.75-year-old Italian boy who exhibited intrauterine and postnatal growth restriction, as well as dysmorphic features including microstomia, thick lips, micrognathia, and bilateral low-set small ears. He also had bilateral cryptorchidism, and abdominal ultrasound revealed hypoplasia and ptosis of the left kidney. Psychomotor development and brain NMR were normal. Growth hormone levels were normal, and immunologic evaluation showed normal populations of T and NK cells. Bilateral absence of the ossification centers of the patella was noted at age 20 months, at which time a clinical diagnosis of Meier-Gorlin syndrome was made. At 4.75 years of age, his height and weight were -2.7 SD and -2.5 SD, respectively, and his head circumference was 51 cm (0.3 SD).
disease_name+syn: ['Meier-Gorlin syndrome 8', 'MCM5', ' CDC46', ' MGORS8']

disease_des/def: Deficiency of maleylacetoacetate isomerase (MAAID) is characterized by mild elevations in succinylacetone in blood and urine, usually identified by newborn screening. Liver function and coagulation are normal. MAAID is differentiated from hepatorenal tyrosinemia (TYRSN1; {276700}), which is also identified by hypersuccinylacetonemia on newborn screening but is a severe disorder with hepatic failure, renal tubulopathy, rickets, and porphyria-like neurologic crises. MAAID and TYRSN1 are caused by mutations in genes encoding the penultimate and ultimate enzymes, respectively, in the phenylalanine and tyrosine degradation pathway (summary by {1:Yang et al., 2017}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Yang et al. (2017)} reported 3 boys and 3 girls with MAAID, identified by newborn screening with mildly elevated succinylacetone (SA) by mass spectrometry on dried blood spot. Initial plasma SA level ranged from 233-1282 nmol/L (median 358 nmol/L) with an assay reference range of less than 24 nmol/L. This compares with hepatorenal tyrosinemia (TYRSN1) patients whose initial plasma SA levels ranges from 16,944 to 74,377 nmol/L (median 39,454). In urine, the SA level in benign hypersuccinylacetonemia subjects ranged from 73-4,103 micromol/mol creatinine (median 522) versus less than 34 micromol/mol creatine in controls. In TYRSN1 HT1 patients the urine SA ranged from 59,921-1,195,273 micromol/L (median 290,391). There was no overlap in laboratory values between the TYRSN1 group and the MAAID group. All individuals with benign hypersuccinylacetonemia had normal prothrombin ({176930}) time and international normalized ratio (PT/INR). Initial serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP; {104150}) was normal and remained within age-appropriate reference range for all 6 subjects for up to 13 years of follow-up. Plasma amino acids showed no elevation of tyrosine. There was no liver or kidney dysfunction or disease detected by imaging.
disease_name+syn: ['Maleylacetoacetate isomerase deficiency', 'GSTZ1', ' MAAI', ' MAAID']

disease_name: Megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts 4, remitting
disease_des/def:
Remitting megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts-4 (MLC4) is an autosomal recessive neurologic disorder characterized by macrocephaly in infancy associated with developmental delay, delayed walking, variable cognitive decline, behavioral abnormalities, and early-onset seizures. The severity of neurologic dysfunction is variable, even within a family, but tends to show improvement with time. Brain imaging shows swelling of the cerebral white matter and subcortical cysts in the anterior temporal region, consistent with MLC. Brain imaging abnormalities also tend to improve with time, indicating a remitting disease course ({1:Passchier et al., 2023}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts, see MLC1 ({604004}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Passchier et al. (2023)} reported a brother (P4) and a sister (P5), born of consanguineous parents, who developed macrocephaly in the first 6 months of life; head circumference normalized in the boy and remained just above 2 SD in the girl. Both showed developmental delay and hypotonia, although P4 was more severely affected. He walked at 4-5 years, whereas his sister walked at age 2. Both had seizures from 1 year of age. P4 had frequent status epilepticus, which eventually was controlled, and P5 had epilepsy that was well-controlled. At 16 years of age, P4 had marked cognitive decline with limited language ability. He could walk with difficulty and had limited hand function. Additional features in P4 included truncal and limb ataxia, dystonia, rigidity, and dysarthria. At age 13, P5 had close to normal motor function with mild clumsiness and mild cognitive deficit. Both patients demonstrated behavioral problems in early childhood, including agitation, impulsivity, and hyperactivity, which later improved (P4) or normalized (P5). Brain imaging of P4 at 8 months of age showed diffuse signal abnormalities, mild swelling of the cerebral white matter, and subcortical cysts in the anterior temporal region. Follow-up at age 4 showed normalization of the cerebral white matter, but persistence of small temporal cysts. Brain imaging of P5 showed similar findings, but milder. The brain imaging findings were consistent with remitting MLC.
disease_name+syn: ['Megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts 4, remitting', 'AQP4', ' MIWC', ' MLC4']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Merico et al. (2015)} and {2:Sharfe et al. (2015)} reported a consanguineous family of Irish descent in which 3 boys had a primary immunodeficiency apparent from early infancy. All had recurrent upper and lower respiratory infections; 1 had ecthyma gangrenosum and developed a polyarticular arthritis with joint swelling, and another had a urinary tract infection. Immunologic workup showed normal to increased numbers of circulating lymphocytes, with an increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio compared to controls. In vitro studies showed impaired T-cell proliferative responses to multiple antigens, as well as impaired ability to produce specific immunoglobulins, indicating an effect on humoral immunity as well. The findings were consistent with a primary T-cell defect. Total serum immunoglobulin levels were normal, and patients did not show susceptibility to atypical mycobacterial infections. However, the disorder was severe enough to warrant treatment with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. {2:Sharfe et al. (2015)} found that a thymus biopsy from 1 of the patients showed decreased levels of new emigrant T cells from the thymus and decreased T-cell receptor excision circles (TREC), consistent with deficient new T-cell production. Circulating cells from all patients showed low numbers of naive T cells and increased numbers of central memory T cells.
disease_name+syn: ['Immunodeficiency 53', 'RELB', ' IREL', ' IMD53']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {2:Valentine et al. (1970)} described a family in which homozygotes and heterozygotes for deficiency of glyoxalase II (hydroxyacyl-glutathione hydrolase; HAGH; {138760}) were demonstrated in 3 generations. Homozygotes had no clinical or hematologic abnormality, and elliptocytosis (which was segregating independently in the family) was not worsened by the presence of the enzyme defect.
disease_name+syn: ['Glyoxalase II deficiency', 'HAGH', ' GLO2']

disease_name: Cortical dysplasia, complex, with other brain malformations 2
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{2:Poirier et al. (2013)} reported 4 brothers with severe malformations of cortical development. The proband showed intrauterine growth retardation, severe arthrogryposis, and microcephaly (-4 SD) at birth, and developed clonic seizures in the first months of life. Brain MRI showed frontal and perisylvian polymicrogyria and a thin corpus callosum with a normal brainstem and cerebellar vermis. The infant was bedridden with spastic tetraplegia. The unaffected mother subsequently had 3 medical abortions of similarly affected male fetuses who showed fetal akinesia associated with polymicrogyria, gyral simplification, delayed development of the cerebellum and brainstem, and abnormal positioning of the corticospinal tracts.

{1:De Ligt et al. (2012)} and {3:Willemsen et al. (2014)} reported a 15-year-old girl with severe intellectual disability. She developed seizures at age 6 months, never acquired speech, and had walked only with support since about 9 to 10 years of age. Other features included secondary microcephaly (-2.5 SD), small hands and feet, slight hypertonia, stereotypic hand movements, and severe automutilation. Brain MRI showed signs of cortical malformation mainly affecting the frontal cortex, including a decreased number of gyri, coarse gyri, and shallow sulci. There was no evident facial dysmorphism.
disease_name+syn: ['Cortical dysplasia, complex, with other brain malformations 2', 'KIF5C', ' NKHC2', ' CDCBM2']

disease_name: Aspartate aminotransferase, serum level of, QTL1
disease_name+syn: ['Aspartate aminotransferase, serum level of, QTL1', 'GOT1', ' ASTQTL1']

disease_des/def:
Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation-8 (NBIA8) is characterized by iron accumulation in the basal ganglia and manifests as a progressive extrapyramidal syndrome with dystonia, rigidity, and choreoathetosis ({1:Drecourt et al., 2018}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of NBIA, see NBIA1 ({234200}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Drecourt et al. (2018)} reported a girl (patient 3), born of consanguineous Turkish parents, with a neurodegenerative disorder. She walked at 14 months, but showed speech delay. At age 3 years, she was noted to have progressive cerebellar ataxia and unbalanced gait. She developed tremor, dysmetria, hypotonia, hyperreflexia, and a sensory neuropathy, and gradually lost the ability to stand, walk, and write. Brain imaging showed cerebellar atrophy and hyperintensities in the basal ganglia, globus pallidi, and substantia nigra, consistent with brain iron accumulation.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation 8', 'CRAT', ' CAT1', ' NBIA8']

disease_name: Cerebellar hypoplasia/atrophy, epilepsy, and global developmental delay
disease_des/def: Cerebellar hypoplasia/atrophy, epilepsy, and global developmental delay is an autosomal recessive neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by infantile onset of hypotonia and developmental delay with subsequent impaired intellectual development and severe speech delay. In childhood, affected individuals show delayed walking and develop epilepsy that is usually controlled by medication. Brain imaging shows cerebellar hypoplasia/atrophy (summary by {8:Wang et al., 2019}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {8:Wang et al. (2019)} reported 5 patients from 3 unrelated families with CHEGDD. One patient was 20 years of age, whereas the others ranged from 12 to 15 years; 1 had died at 11 years due to chronic lung disease associated with recurrent aspiration pneumonia. The patients presented in early childhood with hypotonia, global developmental delay, delayed walking at about age 3 years, and severely impaired intellectual development with profound speech delay or even absent language. All also developed epilepsy between 7 and 10 years of age, but the seizures were controlled by medication in most. Subtle nonspecific dysmorphic features seen in some patients included poor overall growth, large forehead, tall face, mild hypertelorism, joint hyperlaxity, and long fingers and toes. Brain imaging in all 5 patients showed cerebellar atrophy and dysplasia. Families 2 and 3 were consanguineous; family history revealed 4 miscarriages in family 3. Additional cerebellar features, such as tremor, ataxia, and nystagmus, were not noted in these patients.
disease_name+syn: ['Cerebellar hypoplasia/atrophy, epilepsy, and global developmental delay', 'OXR1', ' CHEGDD']

disease_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities
disease_des/def: Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities (NEDFBA) is characterized by developmental delay with variably impaired intellectual development with speech delay, behavioral abnormalities, and nonrecurrent dysmorphic facial features. Additional features may include hypotonia, skeletal anomalies such as scoliosis or pectus defects, and visual problems such as strabismus and myopia ({1:Bogaert et al., 2023}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Bogaert et al. (2023)} reported 11 individuals from 10 unrelated families with a neurodevelopmental disorder. The patients, who ranged from 2 to 34 years of age, were ascertained through international collaborative efforts, including the GeneMatcher program, after exome sequencing identified de novo heterozygous mutations in the SRSF1 gene. All had global developmental delay with variably impaired intellectual development; 2 patients (P4 and P9) had learning difficulties and borderline intellectual disability. Most patients had speech delay (a few were nonverbal), hypotonia, and mildly delayed walking. More than half of the patients had autistic features and/or behavioral abnormalities, including poor social interaction, frustration, stereotypies, outbursts of anger, and hyperactivity. Many had visual problems such as myopia, strabismus, astigmatism, and hypermetropia. Seizures were observed in only 1 patient (P14) who had myoclonus associated with fever. Four patients had nonspecific findings on brain imaging, including enlarged ventricles, cortical and subcortical atrophy, thin corpus callosum, and delayed myelination. More variable features included cryptorchidism, hypospadias, congenital heart defects, scoliosis, and foot deformities. Three older males (P4, P14, and P15) had a marfanoid habitus with arachnodactyly and pectus excavatum or carinatum. Almost all had nonspecific and nonrecurrent dysmorphic facial features, including arched eyebrows, down- or upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthus, hypertelorism, deep-set eyes, triangular face, long smooth philtrum, depressed nasal bridge, wide nasal bridge, long nose, low-set ears, retrognathia, downturned corners of the mouth, thin upper lip, and high palate.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodevelopmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities', 'SRSF1', ' SFRS1', ' ASF', ' SF2', ' SRp30a', ' NEDFBA']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: Much of the genetic vulnerability to abuse of different legal and illegal addictive substances is shared, and many abusers use multiple addictive substances (summary by {5:Uhl et al., 2001}).
disease_name+syn: ['Drug addiction, susceptibility to', 'FAAH']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: Whereas most humans express an alpha-1,3-fucosyltransferase in plasma, 9% of individuals on the isle of Java (Indonesia) do not express this enzyme. The Lewis negative phenotype is found on red cells of 95% of these FUT-deficient individuals, suggesting strong linkage disequilibrium between these 2 traits ({1:Mollicone et al., 1994}).
disease_name+syn: ['Fucosyltransferase 6 deficiency', 'FUT6']

disease_des/def:
Infantile-onset multisystem autoimmune disease-3 (ADMIO3) is an autosomal recessive disorder of immune dysregulation characterized by the onset of various systemic autoimmune manifestations in the first months or years of life. Features may include hypothyroidism, type 1 diabetes mellitus, systemic inflammatory manifestations (fever, hepatomegaly), and autoimmune cytopenias. Laboratory studies show normal levels of T, B, and NK cells, but CD4+ (see {186940}) T cells demonstrate hyperproliferation when stimulated in vitro ({1:Janssen et al., 2022}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of ADMIO, see ADMIO1 ({615952}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Janssen et al. (2022)} reported 3 unrelated patients, ranging from 4 to 16 years of age, with onset of autoimmune features in infancy or in the first years of life. P1 was a 16-year-old girl, born of consanguineous Saudi parents, who developed hypothyroidism at 1 year of age followed by type 1 diabetes mellitus and vitiligo at age 6 and recurrent urticaria in the absence of atopy. She also had recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections associated with hypogammaglobulinemia, which responded to IV Ig treatment. Immunologic work-up showed normal T, B, and NK cell levels, but levels of IgG autoantibodies were increased. Her plasma strongly activated normal basophils, suggesting the presence of an activator in her serum. Accordingly, plasma levels of IL6 ({147620}), TNFA ({191160}), IL10 ({124092}), CXCL9 ({601704}), and CXCL10 ({147310}) were substantially elevated compared to controls. {1:Janssen et al. (2022)} suggested that the hypogammaglobulinemia and recurrent infections in P1 may have been due to additional variants in other genes. P2 was a 11-year-old boy, born of unrelated Saudi parents, who presented at 3 years of age with fever, lung infiltrates, hepatomegaly, and ascites responsive to medical treatment, including corticosteroids. He was later diagnosed with hypothyroidism and type 1 diabetes. At age 7, he again developed fevers and arthralgias, and bone marrow aspiration showed hemophagocytosis. Immunologic work-up showed normal T, B, and NK cells with increased IgG autoantibodies and elevated plasma cytokines, similar to that observed in P1. P3 was a 4-year-old boy, born of consanguineous Omani parents, who developed autoimmune hemolytic anemia at 6 months of age, followed by idiopathic thrombocytopenia purpura (ITP) at age 1. T and B cell numbers were normal, and serum cytokines were increased. Testing for autoantibodies was not performed due to lack of sample.
disease_name+syn: ['Autoimmune disease, multisystem, infantile-onset, 3', 'CBLB', ' ADMIO3']

disease_name: High density lipoprotein cholesterol level QTL6
disease_name+syn: ['High density lipoprotein cholesterol level QTL6', 'SCARB1', ' CD36L1', ' CLA1', ' HDLQTL6']

disease_des/def:
Congenital myopathy-20 (CMYP20) is an autosomal recessive neuromuscular disorder that shows wide phenotypic variability. Some patients present in early childhood with proximal muscle weakness affecting the lower and upper limbs resulting in difficulties running and climbing, whereas others present soon after birth with congenital limb or distal contractures. Additional features may include dysmorphic facial features and global developmental delay. Skeletal muscle biopsy may show nemaline rods ({1:Nilipour et al., 2018}; {2:Pehlivan et al., 2019}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of congenital myopathy, see CMYP1A ({117000}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Nilipour et al. (2018)} reported a 22-year-old woman with congenital myopathy. After normal early development, the patient developed muscle weakness manifest as difficulty running and climbing stairs around 5 years of age. She had a positive Gowers sign and mild weakness of the arms. At age 22, she had mild proximal muscle weakness in all 4 limbs and mild scapular winging, but no scoliosis. She also had a long narrow face, high-arched palate, facial weakness, and micrognathia, but no ophthalmoplegia or ptosis. Forced vital capacity was 75%. Serum creatine kinase was normal and EMG showed a myopathic pattern. Skeletal muscle biopsy showed wide variation in fiber size with type 1 fiber predominance and atrophy, hypertrophic type 2 fibers, increased internal nuclei, and abundant nemaline bodies in the perinuclear and subsarcolemmal areas, as well as in the cytoplasm. There were some core-like regions as well. Mutations in known nemaline myopathy-associated genes were excluded, and genetic analysis identified compound heterozygous missense variants in the RYR3 gene (M2070V, {180903.0001} and R2980L, {180903.0002}) that segregated with the disorder in the family.

<Subhead> Clinical Variability

{2:Pehlivan et al. (2019)} reported 2 unrelated girls diagnosed clinically with arthrogryposis associated with biallelic mutations in the RYR3 gene who were ascertained from a cohort of 89 families with arthrogryposis who underwent exome sequencing. Patient BAB8988, born of consanguineous parents (family HOU3274), was a 15-year-old girl born with contractures of the upper limbs and left hip dislocation. She had a prominent forehead, blue sclerae, high-arched palate, ulnar deviation in the hands, contractures of the elbows, fingers, and toes, and scoliosis. Exome sequencing identified a homozygous missense mutation in the RYR3 gene (R2980L; {180903.0002}); this mutation had been found in compound heterozygous state in the patient reported by {1:Nilipour et al. (2018)}. Patient PAED187, identified through the GeneMatcher program, was a girl who showed club feet and an echogenic intracardiac focus on prenatal ultrasound. She was born at term with club feet and equinus deformation requiring surgery, as well as contractures of the fingers that resolved with physiotherapy. Around 10 months of age, she was noted to have global developmental delay with delayed walking, impaired intellectual development, and speech delay. At age 2 years, she showed seizure-like activity that resolved; EEG was normal. She also developed an enteropathy with chronic diarrhea and poor weight gain. At age 3, she could walk with frequent falls and had muscle atrophy of the lower limbs, but no other signs of muscle disease. Dysmorphic facial features included broad forehead, epicanthus, broad and depressed nasal bridge, abnormally spaced teeth, and short fingers and toes with dysplastic toenails. Exome sequencing identified compound heterozygous mutations in the RYR3 gene (D667G, {180903.0003} and a splice site mutation, {180903.0004}).
disease_name+syn: ['Congenital myopathy 20', 'RYR3', ' CMYP20']

disease_des/def:
Oocyte/zygote/embryo maturation arrest-14 (OZEMA14) is characterized by female infertility due to oocyte maturation arrest, fertilization failure, and/or early embryonic arrest. The rare fertilized embryos that are transferred to the uterus fail to establish pregnancy after transfer ({5:Zhao et al., 2020}, {4:Zhao et al., 2021}, {1:Huang et al., 2021}, {3:Xu et al., 2021}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of OZEMA, see {615774}.
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{5:Zhao et al. (2020)} reported 5 unrelated Chinese women with infertility due to oocyte maturation defects and mutation in the CDC20 gene. In patient 1, of 11 oocytes obtained during an intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) cycle, 10 were arrested at the germinal vesicle (GV) or metaphase I (MI) stage, and the 1 that matured and was fertilized arrested at the 3-cell stage. In patient 2, all retrieved oocytes over 2 cycles of ICSI were arrested at the MI stage. In patient 3, oocytes retrieved during ISCI were immature; most developed into first polar body (PB1) oocytes, but showed fertilization failure or early embryonic arrest. Oocytes from patients 4 and 5 also showed fertilization failure or early embryonic arrest. The authors stated that none of the patients had any abnormalities in somatic tissues or organs.

{1:Huang et al. (2021)} reported a 27-year-old Chinese woman with infertility due to oocyte maturation arrest and mutation in the CDC20 gene. The proband had regular menses and normal reproductive hormone levels. Transvaginal ultrasound showed a total of 8 antral follicles in the ovaries, and hysterosalpingography revealed complete occlusion of the right fallopian tube and incomplete patency of the left tube. She underwent 3 failed in vitro fertilization (IVF)/ICSI attempts: in the first cycle, 7 oocytes were obtained and 3 were successfully fertilized, but 2 embryos arrested at the 4- to 5-cell stage, and the remaining embryo developed to grade 3CC on day 5, but was not selected for transfer; in the second and third cycles, all 13 oocytes retrieved remained in the MI stage.

{4:Zhao et al. (2021)} reported 4 Chinese women from 3 families with infertility due to oocyte maturation arrest and/or fertilization failure, and mutation in the CDC20 gene. The proband in family 1 had oocyte maturation arrest at the MI stage in all 7 oocytes retrieved during 2 failed IVF attempts. In 1 IVF and 2 ICSI attempts, most oocytes from the proband in family 2 were arrested at the GV or MI stage, but several matured to metaphase II (MII); only 1 of the latter was fertilized but arrested at the 8-cell stage. The proband in family 3 also showed most oocytes arrested at MI, and of those that progressed, only 2 were fertilized, and both arrested at the 1-cell stage. The authors designated the phenotype in family 1 to be oocyte maturation arrest, and that of families 2 and 3 as a mixed maturation arrest/fertilization failure phenotype.

{3:Xu et al. (2021)} reported a 33-year-old Chinese woman, born of first-cousin parents, with infertility due to oocyte maturation arrest and mutation in the CDC20 gene. She had a history of 2 unexplained miscarriages before presenting for ICSI. Over 4 cycles of ICSI, 23 oocytes were retrieved, of which 12 were arrested at MI; among the remaining oocytes in MII, only 1 was fertilized successfully, but failed to form a usable embryo for transplant.
disease_name+syn: ['Oocyte/zygote/embryo maturation arrest 14', 'CDC20', ' OZEMA14']

disease_des/def: RECON progeroid syndrome (RECON) is a chromosomal instability disorder characterized by postnatal growth retardation, progeroid facial appearance, hypoplastic nose, prominent premaxilla, skin photosensitivity and xeroderma, muscle wasting with reduced subcutaneous fat, and slender elongated thumbs ({1:Abu-Libdeh et al., 2022}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Abu-Libdeh et al. (2022)} reported 5 patients from 2 Middle Eastern families with a chromosomal instability disorder and mutation in the RECQL gene. In 2 affected sisters from family A, ages 9.75 and 4 years, and a 14.75-year-old affected girl from family B, common features included postnatal growth retardation, progeroid facial appearance, deep-set eyes, hypoplastic nose with anteverted nares, prominent premaxilla, smooth philtrum, dry scaling skin with photosensitivity, slender elongated thumbs with hyperconvex nails, and muscle wasting with reduced subcutaneous fat. Variable features included delayed permanent dentition, absent lower eyelashes, small ears with attached earlobes, hirsutism of the back or extremities, livedo reticularis, keratosis pilaris, elbow hyperextension, minor joint laxity of the fingers, and arachnodactyly. In family A, a brother and sister who were adult first cousins of the affected sisters' parents exhibited similar clinical features, but were unavailable for evaluation. The authors designated the disorder 'RECON syndrome (RECql ONe).'
disease_name+syn: ['RECON progeroid syndrome', 'RECQL', ' RECQL1', ' RECON']

disease_des/def: Immunodeficiency-92 (IMD92) is an autosomal recessive primary immunodeficiency characterized by the onset of recurrent infections in infancy or early childhood. Infectious agents are broad, including bacterial, viral, fungal, and parasitic, including Cryptosporidium and Mycobacteria. Patient lymphocytes show defects in both T- and B-cell proliferation, cytokine secretion, and overall function, and there is also evidence of dysfunction of NK, certain antigen-presenting cells, and myeloid subsets. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may be curative (summary by {1:Beaussant-Cohen et al., 2019} and {2:Levy et al., 2021}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{1:Beaussant-Cohen et al. (2019)} reported a 9-year-old boy, born of consanguineous Arab parents, with a primary immunodeficiency. He received live vaccines, including BCG, in infancy without clinical sequelae. At age 30 months, he had chronic diarrhea associated with multiple infectious organisms, including Salmonella, CMV, and Cryptosporidium, the last of which caused hepatomegaly and sclerosing cholangitis. At age 7, he developed M. tuberculosis osteomyelitis. Detailed laboratory workup showed increased white cell count, thrombocytosis, increased CD4+ and CD8+ T cells with decreased memory CD4+ T cells, and reduced T-cell proliferation to phytohemagglutinin (PHA). There were also decreased numbers of B cells, particularly switched memory B cells, associated with decreased IgG levels, undetectable IgA, and nonprotective vaccine-induced antibody titers. B cells showed impaired proliferation upon stimulation with CD40L ({300386}) and IL21 ({605384}). Patient cells had defective production of IFNG ({147570}), IL12 (see {161560}), and IL21, all of which contributed to the various opportunistic infections. The findings were consistent with a combined immunodeficiency, and the patient was evaluated for hematopoietic stem cell transplant.

{2:Levy et al. (2021)} reported a girl, born of consanguineous Moroccan parents, who presented in early childhood with recurrent infections by various organisms, including chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (CMC) with esophagitis, chronic CMV viremia with fever, HSV-1 oral lesions, gastrointestinal adeno- and enteroviruses, shingles, disseminated BCG following vaccination, and chronic cholangitis due to Cryptosporidium parvum. Immunologic workup showed poor proliferative responses of patient peripheral blood mononuclear cells to stimulation, as well as poor cytokine secretion. The patient had normal serum IgG levels, but very low levels of circulating memory B cells and no detectable specific antibody responses following vaccination. She underwent successful hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, which resulted in a cure.
disease_name+syn: ['Immunodeficiency 92', 'REL', ' IMD92']

disease_des/def:
Megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts-3 (MLC3) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by increased head circumference in infancy followed by progressive motor and cognitive decline in early childhood. Affected individuals either do not achieve walking or lose independent ambulation in the first or second decades. Cognitive impairment is variable and accompanied by poor speech and dysarthria. Most patients have early-onset seizures, which may be mild or refractory. Brain imaging shows unremitting megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts and swelling of the cerebral white matter ({1:Passchier et al., 2023}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts, see MLC1 ({604004}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Passchier et al. (2023)} reported 3 unrelated patients (P1-P3), ranging from 19 to 27 years of age, who presented with increased head circumference between 6 and 9 months of age. P1 and P2 had delayed motor development, with P2 walking at 3 years of age and P1 never achieving walking. P3 had normal early development and walked at 13 months. Slow motor decline was noted in all patients between 4 and 8 years of age, resulting in loss of independent ambulation and full wheelchair dependency by 6 years in P1 and P2 and 12 years in P3. Motor decline was characterized by clumsiness, spasticity of the upper and lower limbs, trunk and limb ataxia, rigidity, and variable dystonia. Cognitive decline was noted at age 4 in P1, and at 14 to 15 years of age in P2 and P3. Dysarthria was present in all 3, and P2 had dysphagia. The seizure phenotype was variable. P1 developed severe refractory epilepsy at age 4, P2 had mild epilepsy beginning at age 14, and P3 had 2 single seizures after a fall as an adult. At age 19, P1 had limited motor function, marked cognitive deficit, and no speech. At 27 years, P2 could handle objects and use a wheelchair, but had mild cognitive and speech deficits. P3 had mild cognitive deficits and mood problems at age 24. Brain imaging in all patients showed classic unremitting megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with diffusely abnormal and swollen cerebral white matter and subcortical cysts in the anterior temporal and frontal white matter.
disease_name+syn: ['Megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts 3', 'GPRC5B', ' RAIG2', ' MLC3']

disease_des/def:
Lymphatic malformation-11 (LMPHM11) is characterized by lower extremity edema, with onset in the second or third decade of life. Some affected individuals may have subclinical lymphatic malformations ({1:Michelini et al., 2020}).

For a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of lymphatic malformation, see LMPHM1 ({153100}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Michelini et al. (2020)} studied 3 Italian female probands with lymphedema and mutation in the TIE1 gene. The first was a 23-year-old woman who was diagnosed with lower extremity edema at age 13 years. Her mother, who was clinically unaffected, was shown to have mild defects of the lymphatic system on lymphoscintigraphy, and her maternal grandmother reported episodes of cyclic edema. The second proband was a 52-year-old woman with edema of the right lower leg since age 25 years. No family history was reported. The third proband was a 47-year-old woman with bilateral lymphedema of the legs below the knees, which was diagnosed at age 15 years. Her mother also had lymphedema.
disease_name+syn: ['Lymphatic malformation 11', 'TIE', ' JTK14', ' TIE1', ' LMPHM11']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Surolia et al. (2010)} identified heterozygous loss-of-function mutations (e.g., T312M; {610079.0001}) and a homozygous defective polymorphic variant (M89V; {610079.0003}) in the SIAE gene in 24 of 923 individuals of European origin with relatively common autoimmune diseases and in 2 of 648 controls of European origin (see MOLECULAR GENETICS). The autoimmune diseases found in individuals with SIAE mutations included juvenile idiopathic arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis (see {180300}), multiple sclerosis (see {126200}), Sjogren syndrome (see {270150}), systemic lupus erythematosus (see {152700}), type I diabetes (see {222100}), ulcerative colitis (see {266600}), and Crohn disease (see {266600}).
disease_name+syn: ['Autoimmune disease, susceptibility to, 6', 'SIAE', ' AIS6']

disease_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with hypotonia and variable intellectual and behavioral abnormalities
disease_des/def: Neurodevelopmental disorder with hypotonia and variable intellectual and behavioral abnormalities (NEDHIB) is characterized by early-onset hypotonia, delayed walking, poor speech, and impaired intellectual development. Additional features may include feeding difficulties, dysmorphic features, and visual defects. Brain imaging tends to show delayed myelination, thin corpus callosum, and/or enlarged ventricles. The severity of the disorder is highly variable; initial evidence suggests that the severity may depend on the type of mutation (summary by {1:Haijes et al., 2019}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Haijes et al. (2019)} reported 11 unrelated patients, ranging from 3 to 18 years of age (patients 2, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13, 14, and 16) with a similar neurodevelopmental disorder with highly variable severity. All patients had some degree of global developmental delay, usually associated with hypotonia, delayed walking, speech and language delay, strabismus, and behavioral abnormalities. One group of patients (patients 2, 7, 9, 11, and 14) had a severe phenotype, including infantile-onset hypotonia manifest as a frog position in infancy, decreased endurance, poor or absent independent walking, and poor or absent speech. Many had feeding difficulties such as dysphagia, choking, or gastroesophageal reflux; 1 patient was tube-fed. More variable features included recurrent respiratory tract infections, disturbed sleeping, microcephaly, brachy/plagiocephaly, strabismus, teeth misalignment, high-palate, hypertelorism, impaired vision, pectus excavatum, muscle atrophy, and inguinal hernia. Variable behavioral abnormalities were observed, such as disturbed sleeping, autistic features, short attention span, and aggression. Two patients had seizures. Another group of patients (patients 5, 6, 8, 12, 13, and 16) had a less severe form of the disorder. The features were similar to those observed in the first group, although either not as severe or not present. For example, only 2 had the frog position in infancy, 1 had sleep disturbances, 1 had impaired vision, and none had microcephaly, muscle atrophy, stagnation episodes, or seizures. Most of these patients achieved independent walking in the first years of life, and although speech delay was common, they were able to communicate. Almost all patients in both groups had brain imaging abnormalities, most commonly delayed myelination, but also thin corpus callosum, cerebellar atrophy, and enlarged ventricles.
disease_name+syn: ['Neurodevelopmental disorder with hypotonia and variable intellectual and behavioral abnormalities', 'POLR2A', ' RPOL2', ' NEDHIB']

Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: Carboxypeptidase N is a serum alpha globulin metalloenzyme that inactivates C3a, C4a, C5a, bradykinin, kallidin, and fibrinopeptides. {4:Mathews et al. (1980)} found a low level of this enzyme (21% of normal) in a 65-year-old man with an 11-year history of episodic angioedema occurring about 40 times a year. The attacks, which lasted about 24 hours, most often involved the face and tongue but sometimes involved larger areas of pruritic, red swellings on the trunk or limbs. His sister had an equally depressed level of enzyme activity. Six children of these 2 sibs had intermediate levels consistent with heterozygous status. Multiple members of the family had allergic manifestations, i.e., angioedema/chronic urticaria, hay fever/asthma, or both.
disease_name+syn: ['Carboxypeptidase N deficiency', 'CPN1', ' SCPN', ' CPN']

disease_des/def:
Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome-2 (BHD2) is characterized by lipomatosis and fibrofolliculomas as well as renal cell carcinoma and other cancers ({1:van de Beek et al., 2023}).

For a general phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of BHD, see BHD1 ({135150}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des: {1:Van de Beek et al. (2023)} reported a 4-generation Dutch family with multiple lipomas and fibrofolliculomas as well as renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and other cancers and with mutation in the PRDM10 gene. The proband was a man who presented at age 33 years with skin and mucosal lesions and multiple lipomas of the trunk. He had multiple skin-colored papules on his face and trunk, skin tags on his trunk, and multiple small yellow-white papules on his right flank. He also exhibited intraoral papules and small papules on the lips. Biopsy showed typical features of fibrofolliculomas/perifollicular fibromas. By age 48, more than 50 lipomas had been removed but there were many still present, and he experienced severe pain limiting his daily physical activity. Histology showed common lipomas without specific features. The proband reported a family history of lipomas, skin lesions, and RCC in many family members, including at least 20 with lipomas. In addition to clear cell, papillary type 2, and unclassified RCC, other cancers in family members included follicular thyroid cancer, lung cancer, prostate cancer, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. CT scan in the proband and 2 other affected relatives did not show pulmonary cysts. The absence of a pulmonary phenotype in the family led the authors to consider this a phenocopy of BHD1, in which pulmonary cysts had been reported in at least 70% of patients.
disease_name+syn: ['Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome 2', 'PRDM10', ' TRIS', ' KIAA1231', ' BHD2']

disease_des/def: Stolerman neurodevelopmental syndrome (NEDSST) is a highly variable disorder characterized by developmental delay, often with motor and speech delay, mildly impaired intellectual development (in most patients), learning difficulties, and behavioral abnormalities, including autism spectrum disorder. Psychosis is observed in a small percentage of individuals over the age of 12 years. Most individuals have nonspecific and mild dysmorphic facial features without a common gestalt. A subset of patients may have involvement of other organ systems, including gastrointestinal with poor early feeding or gastroesophageal reflux, distal skeletal anomalies, and congenital heart defects. Most mutations occur de novo, but rare autosomal dominant inheritance with incomplete penetrance has been observed ({2:Stolerman et al., 2019}; {1:Rots et al., 2023}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{2:Stolerman et al. (2019)} reported 12 unrelated patients, ranging in age from 2 to 17 years, with a neurodevelopmental disorder showing overlapping features. The patients presented in infancy with global developmental delay, mildly delayed walking at 2 to 3 years of age, and poor language acquisition, including delayed speech and speech apraxia or verbal dyspraxia. Some had early feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, and/or hypotonia; overall growth was basically normal. Intellectual development varied: several patients had an IQ between 80 and 97, whereas others were more severely impaired with only a few words. Four were diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder, and some had attention deficit and/or hyperactivity. Most patients had coarse dysmorphic facial features, including prominent forehead, round face with full cheeks, prominent nose, depressed or broad nasal bridge, large ears, prognathism, epicanthal folds, wide mouth, and thick lips. Less common features, observed in only a few patients, included dolichocephaly, strabismus, telecanthus, exotropia, esotropia, short webbed neck, abnormal dentition, hypoplastic nipples, prominent abdomen, pectus excavatum, laryngomalacia, cryptorchidism, and skin hyperpigmentation, hemangioma, or cafe-au-lait spots. One patient had a congenital heart defect with abnormalities of the superior vena cava. One patient had a history of febrile seizures and another patient had complex partial seizures. Musculoskeletal features, present in most patients, included wide hands and thick fingers, joint hypermobility, fifth finger clinodactyly, and 2/3 toe syndactyly.

Through international collaboration, {1:Rots et al. (2023)} identified 73 individuals with rare heterozygous (mostly de novo) likely pathogenic variants in the KDM6B gene found by exome or genome sequencing. Although neurodevelopmental abnormalities were present in all individuals, the phenotype showed variable expressivity with a wide range of clinical manifestations and severity. Developmental delay (including motor delay, speech delay, and global developmental delay) was the most common feature, present in all except 2 individuals. However, neurodevelopmental problems were less prevalent among individuals 5 years or older. Most individuals (63%) had impaired intellectual development, mostly mild, or learning disabilities, autism spectrum disorder (61%), and variable behavioral abnormalities. A psychotic disorder was present in 20% (4 of 20) individuals 12 years of age or older. Additional neurologic abnormalities included hypotonia (57%), sleep disturbances (32%), seizures (13%), and variable movement disorders (24%), such as gait abnormalities, dystonia-like movements, spasticity, and hypertonia with toe-walking. Some individuals presented with movement disorders. About 30% of individuals had postnatal overgrowth (tall stature in 8%, macrocephaly in 26%, increased weight in 14%). About 51% had neonatal feeding difficulties (sometimes requiring tube feeding) or gastroesophageal reflux; constipation was also observed in 18%. Less common features included congenital heart defects (13%), cleft lip/palate (4%), congenital genitourinary anomalies (10%), and skeletal defects, such as syndactyly (9%), spinal anomalies (13%), brachydactyly (9%), and broad fingers and toes (20%). Most had dysmorphic facial features that were highly variable and nonspecific, without a recognizable facial gestalt. Some of these features included anteverted nares with depressed nasal bridge, deep-set eyes, downslanting or narrow palpebral fissures, prominent forehead, flat face, and synophrys. Coarse facial features were noted in about 4%. Overall, the phenotype was extremely variable, ranging from mild motor or speech delay with normal IQ to more severe intellectual disability with involvement of other organ systems.
disease_name+syn: ['Stolerman neurodevelopmental syndrome', 'KDM6B', ' JMJD3', ' KIAA0346', ' NEDSST']

disease_des/def:
Familial adult myoclonic epilepsy-2 (FAME2) is an autosomal dominant neurologic disorder characterized by onset of tremor affecting the fingers, hand, and voice in adolescence or young adulthood with somewhat later onset of rhythmic myoclonic jerks and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Electrophysiologic studies are consistent with cortical reflex myoclonus. Some patients may show cognitive decline or migraines; photosensitivity is common (summary by {4:De Fusco et al., 2014}; {2:Crompton et al., 2012}).

For a phenotypic description and a discussion of genetic heterogeneity of familial adult myoclonic epilepsy, see FAME1 ({601068}).
Clinicalfeatures/Clinical_des:
{5:Guerrini et al. (2001)} reported a large Italian kindred in which 11 individuals (8 living) over 5 generations were affected with an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by distal myoclonus and seizures. All affected members had onset in adulthood (mean 25 years) of distal, rhythmic involuntary movements resembling tremors, and infrequent generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS). Three patients also had intractable complex partial seizures, which were often followed by secondary generalization. EEG showed focal frontotemporal as well as generalized interictal abnormalities. Detailed neurophysiologic studies revealed giant somatosensory evoked potentials (SEPs), enhanced long-loop C-reflexes, and premovement cortical spikes by the jerk-locked averaging method (JLA), suggesting a cortical origin. {5:Guerrini et al. (2001)} concluded that affected patients had diffuse cortical hyperexcitability and a high propensity for intra- and interhemispheric cortical spread. Neuropsychologic testing suggested that 3 members had mild to moderate mental retardation and several patients had low or low-normal intellectual functioning.

{6:Labauge et al. (2002)} reported a 4-generation European family with clinical findings of FAME segregating in an autosomal dominant pattern. Ten living and 3 deceased members had onset of symptoms after age 30 and a history of myoclonic movements of the extremities, and 8 of 13 also had generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Five patients underwent electrophysiologic examination with findings consistent with the diagnosis of FAME. Dementia and cerebellar ataxia were absent. Linkage to FAME1 locus on chromosome 8 was excluded.

{3:De Falco et al. (2003)} reported 2 Italian families with nonprogressive autosomal dominant BAFME. Cortical tremor was the presenting symptom in all affected patients, appearing at age 11 to 40 years (mean in the twenties). Most patients had infrequent seizures, and electrophysiologic studies were consistent with cortical origin. Treatment with adrenergic beta-blockers was ineffective, but anticonvulsants such as clonazepam and valproate were effective.

{9:Striano et al. (2005)} reported a 5-generation Italian family in which 11 individuals had onset of nonprogressive cortical tremor between the age of 13 and 24 years (mean 18.2 years). Seizures started later than the tremor (mean 31.8 years) and were easily controlled by antiepileptic drugs. Brain imaging was generally normal. All had normal psychomotor development and no signs of cognitive impairment, except 1 patient who had an IQ of 70. Electrophysiologic studies showed generalized paroxysmal activity in 10 patients and a photoparoxysmal response in 6.
